Page.Name: Home
Page.MetaDescription: Support for the Australian Curriculum: Digital Technologies with lesson plans, case studies, advice for school leaders, activities for students and for families. See links to the digital technologies industry events and programs. Get support with the development of computational thinking and coding skills in Australian students.

Page.Name: Understanding DT
Page.MetaDescription: Engage with the Digital Technologies curriculum to understand its core concepts and how they progress through each year level. Undertake professional learning to better understand the intent and structure of the DT curriculum.

Page.Name: The DT Curriculum
Page.MetaDescription: Learn more about the structure and core concepts of the Australian Curriculum: Digital Technologies.

Page.Name: Australian Curriculum: Digital Technologies​
Page.MetaDescription: Learn more about the structure and core concepts of the Australian Curriculum: Digital Technologies.

Page.Name: State and territory curriculum
Page.MetaDescription: Check what your state Department of Education or Sector Department is prescribing and/or mandating in terms of the implementation of the Digital Technologies Curriculum.

Page.Name: Core concepts
Page.MetaDescription: Information about the 10 key concepts that underpin the design and content of the Australian Curriculum: Digital Technologies.

Page.Name: Digital Technologies and Digital Literacy
Page.MetaDescription: Resources that can help clarify the relationship between Digital Technologies and Digital Literacy and how they differ.

Page.Name: Professional learning
Page.MetaDescription: A range of options for professional learning to develop teacher capacity to effectively implement the Digital Technologies curriculum.

Page.Name: Plan for professional learning
Page.MetaDescription: This section explores the ways in which connecting your professional learning about digital technologies is of value professionally and how it might be recognised professionally.

Page.Name: TPACK Model​
Page.MetaDescription: Reflect on your own practice and use our framework to self-assess in order to identify which area you are best to devote energy into to be an effective teacher of Digital Technologies.

Page.Name: For families
Page.MetaDescription: Find out about Digital Technologies to support your child to learn skills, create digital solutions and explore related careers. Help your children understand digital citizenship, and encourage their confident and positive engagement with Digital Technologies.

Page.MetaDescription: Students learn to code and create using digital technologies. Learning skills in digital technologies allow students to create digital games, blogs, 3D animations or movies.

Page.MetaDescription: These suggestions are designed to support parents to help their child with Digital Technologies. They provide details about projects, courses, coding and purchasing technology products.

Page.Name: Tech Girls Project
Page.MetaDescription: Watch this video featuring five female students from Gymea Bay Public School that participated in the Tech Girls are Superheroes competition and came second in their state. The group used MIT app inventor to complete their project.

Page.MetaTitle: What and why of Digital Technologies
Page.MetaDescription: These videos explain more about digital technologies including terminology used in the study of Digital Technologies, practical examples to show what it looks like and vox pops of children and adults talking about the purpose of technology.

Page.MetaDescription: This collection of activities has been designed for families to complete in their own homes or in their local communities, to help build children’s knowledge of the Digital Technologies curriculum.

Page.MetaDescription: Around Australia, multiple organisations have developed a range of extra curricula coding programs to engage eager learners in the field of digital technologies. Join a range of coding clubs to further you or your children's Digital Technologies knowledge.

Page.MetaDescription: Artificial intelligence (AI) is a rapidly developing technology that is becoming increasingly prevalent in our daily lives. Discover our classroom resources for use with your students and access our free professional learning.

Page.MetaDescription: These lesson ideas can be used to teach the key concepts of AI.

Page.MetaDescription: Find out more about AI and how you can use it to cover many aspects of the Australian Curriculum.

Page.Name: About the DTHub
Page.MetaDescription: The Digital Technologies Hub provides learning resources and services for teachers, students, school leaders and parents. It aims to support the implementation of quality Digital Technologies programs and curriculum in schools and to support after school activities.

Page.Name: Contact
Page.MetaDescription: This site is hosted and maintained by Education Services Australia Ltd (ESA) for the Australian Government Department of Education.

Page.Name: Parramatta Marist High: Building a programming mindset
Page.MetaDescription: Kelly Bauer explains how video games are the starting point for Year 7 students at Parramatta Marist High to learn about coding.
Page.MainText: Kelly Bauer, STEM and Innovation Coordinator at this school, describes some of the strategies used to promote both problem-solving and deeper engagement with digital technologies.
Page.LinkName: Opens Building a Programming Mindset

Page.Name: Torrens Valley Christian School: New subject at Year 10
Page.MetaTitle: Torrens Valley Christian School: New subject at Year 10
Page.MetaDescription: Fiona Clayton describes how their Year 10 Digital Technologies subject has had an impact on numbers opting to go on and study in this area.
Page.MainText: Fiona Clayton is eLearning Coordinator at Torrens Valley Christian School (TVCS). She describes how their new Year 10 Digital Technologies subject has had an impact both on current students and on numbers opting to go on and study in this area in Years 11 and 12.
Page.LinkName: Opens New Subject at Year 10

Page.Name: Seven Principles for Inclusive STEM Education (Dec 2020)
Page.MetaTitle: Seven Principles for Inclusive STEM Education (Dec 2020)
Page.MetaDescription: This session presents practical classroom strategies and resources, informed by recent research, that bring the Girls in STEM Toolkit(GiST) Seven Principles for Inclusive STEM Education to life.
Page.MainText: This session presents practical classroom strategies and resources, informed by recent research, that bring the Girls in STEM Toolkit(GiST) Seven Principles for Inclusive STEM Education to life. You will walk away with an understanding of the current research landscape, ideas and contemporary resources to help you create an engaging and inclusive STEM classroom or program.
Page.LinkName: Opens Seven Principles for Inclusive STEM Education (Dec 2020)

Page.Name: Developing a whole school plan to implement Digital Technologies (June 2019)
Page.MetaTitle: Developing a whole school plan to implement Digital Technologies (June 2019)
Page.MetaDescription: View this webinar of Martin Richards, Nicola Flanagan and Hilary Purdie as they work through an approach to develop a whole school implementation plan.
Page.MainText: View this recorded webinar of Martin Richards, Nicola Flanagan and Hilary Purdie as they work through an approach to develop a whole school implementation plan. Become more familiar with the suggested stages advocated on our new DT Hub resource. Gain an insight into some of the challenges and tips on how these might be addressed. The session is for schools at the early stages of implementation as well as schools that are well down the track and looking to review and revise their existing approach.
Page.LinkName: Opens Developing a whole school plan to implement Digital Technologies (June 2019)

Page.Name: An Hour of Code… with Artificial Intelligence! (Dec 2019)
Page.MetaTitle: An Hour of Code… with Artificial Intelligence! (Dec 2019)
Page.MetaDescription: In this webinar, Rebecca, Thushari and Martin unpack what AI is, the fascinating real-world applications of AI.
Page.MainText: In this webinar, Rebecca, Thushari and Martin unpack what AI is, the fascinating real-world applications of AI, as well as unplugged and visual programming activities that you can try in the classroom to teach students in both primary and secondary school all about AI! This webinar is based around CSER’s latest free online courses about teaching AI in primary and secondary classrooms. Come join us to learn about this exciting new world of possibilities with AI!
Page.LinkName: Opens An Hour of Code… with Artificial Intelligence! (Dec 2019)

Page.Name: Unpacking Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning (Aug 2019)
Page.MetaTitle: Unpacking Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning (Aug 2019)
Page.MetaDescription: In this webinar, Dr Karsten Schulz, from the Digital Tech Institute, and Martin Richards, from the Digital Technologies Hub, unpack AI and Machine Learning.
Page.MainText: In this webinar, Dr Karsten Schulz, from the Digital Tech Institute, and Martin Richards, from the Digital Technologies Hub, unpack AI and Machine Learning. They clarify key terms and approaches, make connections with the Australian Curriculum and show ways how to implement AI in a classroom environment. They also talk about differences to ‘conventional’ coding and discuss what ‘typical’ application fields for AI have in common to help teachers decide if or when to use it. The webinar includes a small resource roadshow.
Page.LinkName: Opens Unpacking Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning (Aug 2019)

Page.Name: New coding resources (June 2019)
Page.MetaDescription: Jason Vearing takes us through our new programming resources for students who may be transitioning from visual programming to test based programming using a general purpose programming language.
Page.MainText: Jason Vearing takes us through our new programming resources for students who may be transitioning from visual programming to test based programming using a general purpose programming language. He’ll explain the overall structure of the lessons starting with producing an output, storing data in variables and getting user input with easy to build programs.
Page.LinkName: Opens New coding resources (June 2019)

Page.Name: Developing Data Science skills (April 2019)
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar will be about ways to encourage our students to become data scientists and develop their data science skills.
Page.MainText: This webinar is aimed at teachers with Years 5-8 students. New DT Hub resources will be featured to demonstrate how they can be used effectively in your class. These resources provide students with authentic datasets to help them respond to some contemporary issues that require a balance of social, ethical, economic, conservation and cultural perspectives. The four datasets incorporate scientific studies of fauna including saltwater crocodiles, turtles, dugong and whales. The webinar will be presented by Martin Richards, DT Hub and Linda McIver, Australian Data Science Education Institute.
Page.LinkName: Opens Developing Data Science skills (April 2019)

Page.Name: Assessment for Digital Technologies (Oct 2018)
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar was presented by Martin Richards, Content Manager of the Digital Technologies Hub, and Rebecca Vivian, research fellow at Computer Science Education Research (CSER) group.
Page.MainText: This webinar will walk you through an approach to generate assessment activities using Bloom’s Revised Taxonomy. Rebecca will demonstrate how to use the achievement standards and content descriptors as a guide for breaking down and identifying the skills, behaviours and knowledge you are seeking students to demonstrate. We’ll refer to the use of checklists, student interviews (think alouds) and rubrics. We will also use the SOLO Taxonomy as a way of differentiating a task and using this as a basis for assessment.
Page.LinkName: Opens Assessment for Digital Technologies (Oct 2018)

Page.Name: Inclusive education in the digital technologies curriculum (Sep 2018)
Page.MetaTitle: Inclusive education in the digital technologies curriculum (Sep 2018)
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar was presented by Martin Richards, Content Manager of the Digital Technologies Hub, and K. Clark Burt, researcher and educator.
Page.MainText: This webinar explains what is expected of educators who have students with disabilities, in relation to accessing and modifying the digital technologies curriculum. This includes adapting the curriculum and lesson plans for students who need specific accommodations, who are working towards foundation level, or both.
Page.LinkName: Opens Inclusive education in the digital technologies curriculum (Sep 2018)

Page.Name: From Scratch to text (Aug 2018)
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar was presented by Jason Vearing from Queensland Society for Information Technology in Education (QSITE), and Martin Richards, Content Manager of the Digital Technologies Hub.
Page.MainText: This webinar is useful for educators who have students that are transitioning from visual programming to text based programming. Jason Vearing from QSITE (Gold Coast Chapter) demonstrates some useful programming skills such as creating variables and arrays, and putting it all into practice with simple games.
Page.LinkName: Opens From Scratch to text (Aug 2018)

Page.Name: Using data to change the world (July 2018)
Page.MetaTitle: Using data to change the world (July 2018)
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar was presented by Martin Richards, Content Manager of the Digital Technologies Hub, and Dr Linda McIver, Founder and Executive Director of the Australian Data Science Education Institute.
Page.MainText: This webinar will introduce you to a way of integrating STEM problems using data to empower kids to solve problems in their own communities. From foundation through to year 12 and beyond, data can be used to enhance every subject, from Science and Maths through to Geography and History. You don’t need shiny, expensive toys. You don’t even need a lot of new skills. Watch and find out how.
Page.LinkName: Opens Using data to change the world (July 2018)

Page.Name: An introduction to the BBC micro:bit (June 2018)
Page.MetaTitle: An introduction to the BBC micro:bit (June 2018)
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar was presented by Martin Richards, Content Manger of the Digital Technologies Hub, and Tom Bijesse from Code Club.
Page.MainText: This session provided an introduction to the BBC micro:bit, focusing on visual programming.
Page.LinkName: Opens An introduction to the BBC micro:bit (June 2018)

Page.Name: Demystifying Artificial Intelligence (May 2018)
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar was presented by Dr Joshua Ho, computer scientist at the Victor Chang Cardiac Research Institute in Sydney, New South Wales, and Martin Richards, Content Manger of the Digital Technologies Hub.
Page.MainText: This session focused on Artificial Intelligence (AI) and how we can teach AI concepts to primary and secondary school students. We explore the underpinning concepts of AI and discuss how we can prepare our students with the skills to de-mystify AI. Dr Ho also shared his experience on developing AI classroom activities for primary school students.
Page.LinkName: Opens Demystifying Artificial Intelligence (May 2018)

Page.Name: Current technology trends for secondary schools (April 2018)
Page.MetaTitle: Current technology trends for secondary schools (April 2018)
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar was presented by Nathan Alison, Professional Learning Coordinator for Digital Learning and Teaching Victoria, and Martin Richards, Content Manger of the Digital Technologies Hub.
Page.MainText: During this session, we provide a broad overview of popular classroom technologies in secondary schools, grouping the technologies into categories such as robots and electronics kits.
Page.LinkName: Opens Current technology trends for secondary schools (April 2018)

Page.Name: Scope and Sequence Q&A (March 2018)
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar was presented by Martin Richards, Content Manger of the Digital Technologies Hub, and Paula Christophersen, Co-writer of the Australian Curriculum: Digital Technologies.
Page.MainText: During this session, we answered your questions about our new Scope and Sequence for the Digital Technologies curriculum.
Page.LinkName: Opens Scope and Sequence Q&A (March 2018)

Page.Name: Introduction to Python (Feb 2018)
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar was presented by Owen Brasier, from the Australian Computing Academy
Page.MainText: This webinar offers an introduction to python programming, and how to teach it to students in the classroom. It is aimed at the Year 7–8 band of the Australian Curriculum, focusing specifically on the Implementation thread and the requirements of the curriculum. However, this webinar is also relevant for primary teachers who want to see what comes after Scratch and block programming.
Page.LinkName: Opens Introduction to Python (Feb 2018)

Page.Name: Girls in tech (Nov 2017)
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar covered engaging girls in technology.
Page.MainText: This webinar covered engaging girls in technology. Helen introduced a whole school approach to problem solving that can be used to assess how your school is providing programs that promote girls in tech. The webinar offered practical examples, strategies and approaches that schools can use to encourage participation of girls in technology, as well as identifying relevant resources. Part of the webinar also introduced female tech startup founders who are experts in gaming and other technology related careers.
Page.LinkName: Opens Girls in tech (Nov 2017)

Page.Name: Digital citizenship (Oct 2017)
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar covered what digital citizenship is and why it is important.
Page.MainText: This webinar covered what digital citizenship is and why it is important; alignment of digital citizenship to the Australian Curriculum; and practical lesson ideas and approaches to: digital footprints (helping students understand that they have a digital identity), respectful online behaviour, and digital safety.
Page.LinkName: Opens Digital citizenship (Oct 2017)

Page.Name: Scratch and Makey Makey (June 2017)
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar was presented by Jo Klein, and focussed on design thinking by integrating Makey Makey and scratch. It is suitable for Years 3-7.
Page.MainText: Jo provides practical examples of design activities. She covers what Makey Makey is, how to introduce it, and how to integrate it with Scratch programming. Jo talks about how it applies to the Australian Curriculum: Digital Technologies. Jo demonstrates how she introduces a problem solving approach, and offers student examples of projects. Jo also looks at ways to extend design tasks suitable for secondary students.
Page.LinkName: Opens Scratch and Makey Makey (June 2017)

Page.Name: Approaches to support assessment of the Digital Technologies curriculum (Sep 2017)
Page.MetaTitle: Approaches to support assessment of the Digital Technologies curriculum (Sep 2017)
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar was presented by Rebecca Vivian from CSER.
Page.MainText: Rebecca discussed the framework she and her team developed to help teachers with the interpretation of the ACARA achievement stands. She also shared some resources to support assessment of Digital Technologies curriculum. Rebecca discussed approaches that can be used to design assessment tasks, and provided some assessment guides.
Page.LinkName: Opens Approaches to support assessment of the Digital Technologies curriculum (Sep 2017)

Page.Name: Coding and programming with Tim Bell (May 2017)
Page.MainText: This workshop, presented by Prof. Tim Bell, was held live in Melbourne. Tim discusses the big ideas behind coding and programming, why we teach it and what we teach about. Discover how to implement coding and programming tools into your classroom using fun and engaging activities
Page.LinkName: Opens Coding and programming with Tim Bell (May 2017)

Page.Name: Integrating DT into other subject areas (April 2017)
Page.MainText: Anna talks through what the Digital Technologies focus is for each year band: F–2, Years 3–4 and Years 5–6.
Page.LinkName: Opens Integrating DT into other subject areas (April 2017)

Page.Name: Building teacher capacity in Digital Technologies (March 2017)
Page.MainText: In this webinar the Computer Science Education Research (CSER) Group share approaches schools are taking to build teacher capacity, as well as an abundance of opportunities freely available to teachers and schools, including free online professional development courses, face-to-face training, and a national technology lending library. Whether you're a classroom teacher, school leader or professional development provider, you'll leave with ideas to launch or expand professional development in F-10 Digital Technologies.
Page.LinkName: Opens Building teacher capacity in Digital Technologies (March 2017)

Page.Name: Computer Science Unplugged (March 2017)
Page.MainText: Find out how to introduce students to Computational Thinking through concepts such as binary numbers, algorithms and data compression; separated from the distractions and technical challenges of having to use computers. Importantly, no programming is required to engage with these ideas!
Page.LinkName: Opens Computer Science Unplugged (March 2017)

Page.Name: Implementing DT across the school (Feb 2017)
Page.MainText: In our first webinar Chris Harte shared his knowledge and ideas gained from working with schools to discuss approaches to implement DT across the school in three key areas: Audit the technology, Audit curriculum, Audit capacity.
Page.LinkName: Opens Implementing DT across the school (Feb 2017)

Page.Name: Callaghan College VR School project
Page.MetaDescription: The Callaghan College VR School Project has been a two-year partnership between Callaghan College and The University of Newcastle during 2017–2018.
Page.MainText: This project embed highly immersive VR, in this case networked Oculus Rift, in high school classrooms in a curriculum-aligned way.
Page.LinkName: Opens The Callaghan College VR School Project

Page.Name: Clayfield College's Drone Club
Page.MetaDescription: See how a Brisbane school went about organising and implementing drones into the school curriculum.
Page.MainText: Given drones’ wide application, many schools have already started to explore how they can be used within an educational context, to teach students computational thinking and problem solving.
Page.LinkName: Opens Clayfield College's Drone Club

Page.Name: Nazareth Catholic College: NazTECH conference
Page.MetaDescription: Emma Fowler explores the implementation of the NAZTECH - Digital Technologies Conference at the College.
Page.MainText: Emma Fowler is Learning Coordinator (Primary Campus) at Nazareth Catholic College in Adelaide. Here, she explores the implementation of the NAZTECH - Digital Technologies Conference at the College.
Page.LinkName: Opens Naztech Digital Technologies Conference

Page.Name: Nazareth Catholic College: Three key initiatives
Page.MetaTitle: Nazareth Catholic College: Three key initiatives
Page.MetaDescription: Emma Fowler explores strategies that have made a difference at her school.
Page.MainText: Emma Fowler is Learning Coordinator (Primary Campus) at Nazareth Catholic College in Adelaide. Here, she explores strategies that have made a difference at her school.
Page.LinkName: Opens Three Key Initiatives

Page.Name: Oakleigh State School: Building teacher capacity in ICT
Page.MetaDescription: Nicola Flanagan, focuses on the ICT journey undertaken at Oakleigh State School.
Page.MainText: Many schools are grappling with developing the ICT skills of their staff as well as implementing the Digital Technologies curriculum. This article, by Head of Innovation Nicola Flanagan, focuses on the ICT journey undertaken at Oakleigh State School.
Page.LinkName: Opens Building Teacher Capacity in ICT

Page.Name: Oakleigh State School: Writing a letter to the future
Page.MetaTitle: Oakleigh State School: Writing a letter to the future
Page.MetaDescription: Nicola Flanagan shares how she developed an ambitious vision for students and the learning that would be offered at her school.
Page.MainText: In 2015, the parents and teachers of Oakleigh State School in Queensland were invited to write a letter to the future. The outcomes of that activity created an ambitious vision for students and the learning that would be offered at the school.
Page.LinkName: Opens Writing a Future Letter to the Future

Page.Name: Parramatta Marist High: More than just making - STEM in project-based learning
Page.MetaDescription: Kelly Bauer describes some of the strategies used to promote both problem-solving and deeper engagement with digital technologies.
Page.MainText: Kelly describes a four-pronged approach to developing STEM curriculum opportunities at Parramatta Marist.
Page.LinkName: Opens More Than Just Making: Stem in Project-Based Learning

Page.Name: Point Cook College: Our eSmart Journey
Page.MetaTitle: Point Cook College: Our eSmart Journey
Page.MetaDescription: Sally Hill explains the College’s whole school approach to eSafety and being eSmart.
Page.MainText: Sally Hill, eLearning Coach at Point Cook P–9 College, explains some of the key stages working through their eSmart journey with our staff team and our eLeaders. The team planned an inaugural whole school Cyber Safety Day. On this day students would learn about Cyber Safety and being digital citizens.
Page.LinkName: Opens Our Esmart Journey

Page.Name: St Finbarr's School - Professional Development makes a difference
Page.MetaTitle: St Finbarr's School - Professional Development makes a difference
Page.MetaDescription: Emily Olsen describes the key elements that led to change in her school.
Page.MainText: The schools challenge was: growing the engagement, progress and achievement of each student in digital literacy and enhancing teachers’ knowledge, understanding and skills in order to improve pedagogy in Digital Technology.
Page.LinkName: Opens Professional Development Makes a Difference

Page.Name: Torrens Valley Christian School: Robotics at Year 9
Page.MetaTitle: Torrens Valley Christian School: Robotics at Year 9
Page.MetaDescription: Fiona Clayton explores how the introduction of Robotics EV3s and Raspberry Pi’s at Year 9 at TVCS has made a big difference to how students respond to digital technologies.
Page.MainText: In 2016, the school purchased ten Lego Mindstorms EV3 kits, which we use with the Year 9 Computing classes. The students learn the fundamentals of programming, loops, conditions etcetera while programming a robot, which they design and create.
Page.LinkName: Opens Robotics at Year 9

Page.Name: Digital Pets at Ashwood School, Victoria
Page.MetaDescription: Kenneth Clark Burt explains how this P–12 specialist school uses digital pets (robots) to differentiate the Digital Technologies curriculum
Page.MainText: A typical class size at Ashwood is between 10–12 students, with a range of abilities and splinter skills across all learning areas of the curriculum. Most students find abstract concepts challenging, so we support learning through the use of carefully selected concrete materials and visual aids. To ensure that all students can access the Digital Technologies curriculum, we need teaching resources that are both intuitive and that cater to a range of abilities.
Page.LinkName: Opens Digital Pets at Ashwood School

Page.Name: What would my preferred AI future look like?
Page.MetaTitle: What would my preferred AI future look like?
Page.MetaDescription: Malyn Mawby explains how she implemented project-based learning (PBL) with her year 10 class to explore Artificial Intelligence (AI).
Page.MainText: Through the PBL task, students selected an area of interest and investigated what is possible, probable, and preferred.
Page.LinkName: Opens What would my preferred AI future look like?

Page.Name: Implementing STEM using drones in a state high school
Page.MainText: Trinity Bay State High School is an independent public school for students in years 7 to 12. The school offers Excellence programs in Science and the Arts for years 7 to 10 and has a strong STEM focus (or STEAM, to include the Arts). Collaboration between heads of department in Science, Technology and Mathematics, and with teachers of those subjects, started our drone journey at Trinity Bay.
Page.LinkName: Opens Implementing STEM using drones in a state high school

Page.Name: Humanoid robots and re-invigorate a 'sleeping' language
Page.MainText: Two South Australian schools use robotics as a way to learn a traditional language. Students programmed the robot to speak, perform dances and move. that included. They worked with virtual and real humanoid robots to develop their programming skills.
Page.LinkName: Opens Robots in South Australia

Page.Name: Student Makers Conference
Page.MainText: The event was sponsored by Microsoft. The student committee created and planned a series of 20 activities and became teachers for the day. This incredible event was planned by the students from start to finish who then shared their knowledge of Digital Technologies with their peers.
Page.LinkName: Opens Dallas Brooks Community Primary School

Page.Name: Digital technologies outside of the traditional classroom
Page.MainText: The makerspace project engages girls in problem-solving, making, and science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) based learning.
Page.LinkName: Opens St Aidan's Anglican Girl's School

Page.Name: Whole school approach to coding
Page.MainText: What resources make a difference? Get advice, unit outlines, assessment ideas and a host of practical tips in this article by Dan Martinez, Coordinator of Innovation and Learning at St Hilda’s School.

Page.Name: The story of Wi-Fi
Page.MetaDescription: This article and supporting video show how a team of Australian radio astronomers solved the problem of high-speed wireless internet.
Page.MainText: Find out how the major challenge with Wi-Fi of speed was solved.
Page.Copyright: 2016 ABC. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens The story of Wi-Fi in a new window

Page.Name: There and Back Again: A Packet’s Tale. How Does the Internet Work?
Page.MetaDescription: This video follows a packet of data as it flows from your fingertips, through circuits, wires, and cables, to a host server, and then back again.
Page.MainText: Listen to pioneer of the internet Vint Cerf of Google, MIT's Neil Gershenfeld, lawyer and Internet advocate Elizabeth Stark and Alex Wright, director of user experience at The New York Times.
Page.Copyright: 2016 World Science Foundation. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens There and Back Again: A Packet’s Tale. How Does the Internet Work? in a new window

Page.Name: Digital Careers
Page.MetaDescription: Digital Careers supports teachers and encourages students’ understanding of digital technologies and the foundational skills they require in an ever-changing workforce.
Page.MainText: Engaging young minds for Australia's Digital Future. Digital Careers prepares students with the knowledge and skills they need to thrive in the workforce of tomorrow. Growing demand for digital skills isn't just limited to the ICT sector. All jobs of the future will require them, from marketing and multimedia through to agriculture, finance and health. Digital Careers delivers real world, future-focused education initiatives to help students pursue an exciting digital career.
Page.Copyright: Digital Careers. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Digital Careers in a new window

Page.MetaDescription: The Teaching and Learning in South Australia YouTube channel features a range of videos for educators.
Page.MainText: Scroll down to 'STEM subjects – Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics’ for some useful videos. Scroll further to 'Digital Media – New Media – Social Media – Technology and Computers in Education’ for some more videos with a focus on using ICT in the classroom.

Page.MetaDescription: Using a SPRK Sphero for programming, robotics, and maths for students.
Page.MainText: The possibilities resulting from using a SPRK Sphero robot for programming, robotics, and maths are outlined. The video is promotional in flavour but is useful in outlining possible pedagogical benefits. Suggest combining Sphero with the free app programming Tickle.

Page.Name: Teaching creative computer science: Simon Peyton Jones
Page.MainText:
This video describes the challenges and goals of teaching a new computer science curriculum, with references to the UK curriculum. It identifies the creative opportunities for students using digital technologies and the teacher skill development to achieve this.
The focus is on teaching students the foundations of digital technologies in order to develop informed, engaged and imaginative creators.
Page.Copyright: TEDx. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Teaching creative computer science: Simon Peyton Jones in a new window

Page.Name: BBC Secondary Computing
Page.MetaDescription: A wide range of resources, including videos, interactives, learning guides and lesson plans for secondary computing courses in the UK.
Page.MainText: A wide range of resources, including videos, interactives, learning guides and lesson plans for secondary computing courses in the UK. Users will need to register for a free login before accessing the site.
Page.LinkName: Opens BBC Secondary Computing in a new window

Page.Name: Public and private keys: How is your personal information kept secret on the internet?
Page.MetaDescription: Public and private keys are explained using animation.
Page.MainText: A great deal of private data is exchanged over the internet. This video explains how cryptography allows for the secure transfer of data online. It explains how encryption works and what keys are. Today information is encrypted using 256 bit keys. This keeps information safe because it means there are way too many possible key combinations for hackers' computers to try. Two types of keys are described and explained clearly: public keys and private keys.
Page.LinkName: Opens Public and private keys: How is your personal information kept secret on the internet? in a new window

Page.Name: ‘Code Stars’ – Short Film
Page.MetaDescription: This video helps learners and educators to understand the significance of computer programming literacy in a technological world.
Page.MainText:
This video unveils the world of computer programming as described by the creators of the some of the most successful technology applications like Facebook and Microsoft.
These innovators identify what computer programming is, why it is so valuable today, careers and opportunities in programming, and why everyday people, as well as rock stars like Will.i.am, code.
It explores programming in a classroom setting, some progressive and futuristic technologies based on programming, and an ultra-modern and creative workplace producing gaming software.
Page.Copyright: 2013 code.org. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens ‘Code Stars’ – Short Film in a new window

Page.Name: SciGirls
Page.MetaDescription: SciGirls videos promote girls in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM).
Page.MainText:
In each SciGirls video, female mentors offer girls a glimpse of exciting STEM career possibilities.

The series SciGirls Profiles: Women in STEM, model videos of women who are passionate about their work in STEM.

Supporting educational materials provide gender-equitable teaching strategies and hands-on inquiries based on the concepts modelled in SciGirls’ videos.
Page.Copyright: 2016 PBS; WGBH Educational Foundation. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens SciGirls in a new window

Page.Name: The Internet of Things for Banking, Energy and Utilities, and Insurance
Page.MainText:
The video uses an example character and tracks her interactions with technology through her day, including restaurant booking, online purchases, appliance monitoring and exercise tracking.
As the video examines the interactions it also explains how businesses can track these interactions and make use of the data she is creating, raising questions of privacy, data ownership and customer benefits.
Page.Copyright: IBM Corporation 2014. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens The Internet of Things for Banking, Energy and Utilities, and Insurance in a new window

Page.Name: Unpacking the curriculum: Ten key concepts
Page.MetaTitle: Unpacking the curriculum: Ten key concepts
Page.MetaDescription: Use this 4-minute video to understand the ten key concepts that underpin the design and content of the Australian Curriculum: Digital Technologies.
Page.MainText:
James Curran, Associate Professor, School of IT, University of Sydney provides some practical examples of algorithms. In this clip James Curran briefly describes the organisation of Digital technologies and Design technologies subjects. James discusses ten concepts that underpin Digital Technologies curriculum:

  1. Abstraction
  2. Data collection
  3. Data representation
  4. Data interpretation
  5. Specification
  6. Algorithms
  7. Implementation
  8. Digital systems
  9. Interactions
  10. Impact

Page.Name: STEM Strategy DECD
Page.MetaDescription: STEM is science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (incorporating physics and chemistry). These subjects are closely related and are often taught together.
Page.MainText:
The DECD STEM Learning strategy (PDF 5.5MB) will transform public education to enable students at every level of schooling to develop knowledge, skills and understanding in STEM subjects and to apply that learning to shape their world. Students will experience these subjects and apply their skills in new ways using collaboration, problem-solving and interdisciplinary thinking.

The strategy has 3 main areas of action:
  • build expertise in STEM teaching and learning across all years of public education
  • engage students at all year levels in STEM education
  • develop systemic excellence in STEM education.
Page.LinkName: https://www.decd.sa.gov.au/sites/g/files/net691/f/decd-stem-strategy-2016.pdf

Page.Name: A matter of style
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence, students using the Zen Garden website reflect on criteria for effective design.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence, students using the Zen Garden website reflect on criteria for effective design. They then explore the benefits of stylesheets in separating style and content and to learn to how use them.
Page.LinkName: Opens A matter of style

Page.Name: Google CS First: Storytelling
Page.MetaDescription: CS First: Storytelling guides students to use block-based coding in Scratch projects through a series of themed activities.
Page.MainText:
CS First is a free program that offers computer science projects for students aged 9-14 who sign up to be part of the club. In the storytelling project, students move through eight activities that each help develop an aspect of storytelling using computer science skills.

Activities include dialogue and sequencing, setting, premise, characterisation, interactive storytelling and personal narrative. Each activity is supported by a video and project starters which students use to remix and create their own stories.

Lesson plans accompany the student activities.
Page.LinkName: Opens Go to Google CS First: Storytelling in a new window

Page.Name: Baringa State Primary School: Implementation of STEM
Page.MetaDescription: Baringa PS uses a cross-disciplinary approach that integrates STEM disciplines around relevant contexts (ie a problem, question, product or issue).
Page.MainText: Baringa opened its doors at the start of 2018 as Education Queensland’s first purpose-built STEM school. A consistent approach to quality teaching, known as our 'signature practices', ensures that learning is seamless throughout the school.
Page.LinkName: Opens Baringa State Primary School Implementation of Stem

Page.Name: Demystifying DigTech
Page.MetaDescription: This video attempts to Demystify Digital Technologies.

Page.Name: An integrated approach to Digital Technologies
Page.MainText: Is there a philosophical argument for one model over the other? Is it better to take an integrated approach or should we see the Digital Technologies curriculum as a subject apart?

Page.Name: Dive into AR, VR and AI (Nov 2020)
Page.MetaTitle: Dive into AR, VR and AI (Nov 2020)
Page.MetaDescription: Join Rebecca Vivian and Martin Richards as they dive into the world of Augmented Reality (AR), Virtual Reality (VR) and Artificial Intelligence (AI)!
Page.MainText: They demonstrate a range of student-friendly tools and apps that can provide exciting learning experiences and engage students as content creators, along with ways to implement these in primary and secondary classrooms. Rebecca and Martin will share CSER and the Hub's latest resources that aim to support and inspire teachers and schools with the growing field of emerging technologies, including lesson plans with classroom-ready activities and assessment advice. They will also highlight what to look for when viewing the terms and conditions of use for these online tools and applications.
Page.LinkName: Opens Dive into AR, VR and AI (Nov 2020)

Page.Name: Core concepts​
Page.MetaDescription: The Australian Computing Academy has information about the key concepts that underpin the design and content of the Australian Curriculum: Digital Technologies.
Page.MainText: The Australian Computing Academy has information about the key concepts that underpin the design and content of the Australian Curriculum: Digital Technologies. In these videos James Curran, Associate Professor, School of IT, University of Sydney explains key concepts of digital technologies including understanding representation and algorithms.
Page.LinkName: Opens Core concepts

Page.Name: Digital Technologies and ICT​
Page.MainText: A topical question and key consideration for schools is what’s the relationship between ICT Capabilities and Digital Technologies and how do they differ. The following resources can help clarify this. ICT VS DT Information including blog article, video and infographic.
Page.LinkName: Opens Digital Technologies and ICT​

Page.Name: Creating a whole school plan​
Page.MainText: Create a whole-school plan to implement the Digital Technologies curriculum that provides a high-level summary of the coverage of the curriculum area, and reflect the school’s goals, vision and any school priorities. Refer to the templates provided to document your curriculum planning for Digital Technologies. Adjust the document to suit your context. Alternatively use your existing planning documents used for other subject areas.
Page.LinkName: ​Opens Creating a whole-school plan​

Page.Name: Drones, Data, and Digital Technologies - How they all fit together (July 2020)
Page.MetaTitle: Drones, Data, and Digital Technologies - How they all fit together (July 2020)
Page.MetaDescription: Join Clair Allen, Kelly Soenario, and Dr. Karen Joyce, along with co-host Martin Richards, as they work through an approach to bring drones into your school, as part of a Digital Technologies implementation plan.
Page.MainText: Gain insights into some of the challenges, but also opportunities for using emerging technology to engage students who don't traditionally engage in STEM. The session is for primary and high schools at the early stages of implementation as well as schools that are well down the track and looking to review and revise their existing approach.
Page.LinkName: Opens Drones, Data, and Digital Technologies - How they all fit together (July 2020)

Page.Name: Glitch
Page.MainText: Students make their own version of popular projects that are in the form of a poster, postcard, comic, website or basic text. Remix of the projects can involve Editing HTML content, Editing CSS styles, Finding Creative Commons-licensed images or Creating an interactive button with JavaScript. Student resources are accompanied by teaching resources.

Page.Name: ScratchJr
Page.MetaDescription: ScratchJr is an introductory programming language that enables young students (ages 5-7) to create their own interactive stories and games.
Page.MainText:
ScratchJr is available as a free app for iPads and Android tablets. Students snap together graphical programming blocks to make characters move, jump, dance, and sing. This site provides support and guidance for learners and
teachers.
Page.Organisation: MIT Media Lab ScratchJr is a collaboration between the DevTech Research Group at Tufts University, the Lifelong Kindergarten Group at the MIT Media Lab, and the Playful Invention Company.
Page.Copyright: Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Tufts University. Creative Commons BY-SA 4.0.

It identifies some of the interchangeable words used for digital technology in different curriculums. The definition, applications and everyday examples of computational thinking are described.

Page.Name: Danielle Feinberg: The magic ingredient that brings Pixar movies to life

Page.Name: Google for Education webinar
Page.MetaDescription: This webinar, explores how Google Apps for Education, resources and initiatives can be used to support the implementation of coding and computational thinking in the classroom.
Page.MainText:
This webinar explores how Google Apps for Education and resources and initiatives can be used to support the implementation of coding and computational thinking in the classroom.

The video provides examples of how teachers are incorporating coding and computational thinking into the classroom to provide meaningful and integrated learning opportunities.
Suggestions are made for various subject areas at primary level. The video suggests a variety of resources to begin or continue coding in the classroom as well as resources to continue professional learning.
Page.Copyright: Chris Harte/Unstuck Learning Design. Creative Commons BY 4.0

Page.Name: How can we use Google Apps for Education to bring the Digital Technologies Curriculum to life?
Page.MetaDescription: This video is a recording of a webinar for teachers demonstrating how Google Apps for Education can support teaching the Digital Technologies curriculum.
Page.MainText:
This video is a recording of a webinar for teachers about how Google Apps for Education can support teaching the Digital Technologies curriculum.
The video is just over an hour long, and records a presentation focusing on three aspects of the curriculum: Data visualization, Designing algorithms and Collaboration & communication.
The presentation is supported by links to online classroom resources, videos, classroom teaching examples, and professional learning resources.

Page.Name: ASD CyberEXP
Page.MetaDescription: ASD CyberEXP will take you through a day in the life of five cyber specialists experts working in the Australian Signals Directorate helping to secure the government's information, services and personnel.
Page.MainText:
The ASD CyberEXP sponsored by the Australian Signals Directorate, is an interactive online cyber career exploration experience run on the LifeJourney platform. It enables students to test drive a day in the life of five ASD cyber professionals.
Users will participate in challenging real-life cyber scenarios, discover the skills and tools used by these ASD cyber mentors, and explore the vast number of careers available in cyber security today.
Page.Copyright: 2013 - 2018 LifeJourney International PTY Ltd. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
