Page.Name: Creative Computing Curriculum
Page.MainText: The Creative Computing Curriculum is a collection of ideas, strategies, and activities for an introductory creative computing experience using the Scratch programming language.
Page.Copyright: Creative Computing Lab, Harvard Graduate School of Education. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens Creative Computing Curriculum in a new window

Page.Name: A spreadsheet's secret weapon
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence, students learn to use pivot tables which have been described as the most powerful tool within spreadsheets.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence, students learn to use pivot tables which have been described as the most powerful tool within spreadsheets.
Page.LinkName: Opens A spreadsheet's secret weapon

Page.Name: Animal adaptations
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students explore aspects of animal adaptation prior to applying their knowledge to constructing their own digital creature using littleBits electronic sets.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students explore aspects of animal adaptation prior to applying their knowledge to constructing their own digital creature using littleBits electronic sets.
Page.LinkName: Opens Animal adaptations

Page.Name: Behaving with real class - Using a text-based language
Page.MetaTitle: Behaving with real class - Using a text-based language
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson sequence offers an approaches to teaching object-oriented principles using text-based programming.
Page.MainText: This lesson sequence offers an approaches to teaching object-oriented principles using text-based programming. It attempts to address the problem that many of programming languages are too complex and their environments confusing for many students.
Page.LinkName: Opens Behaving with real class - Using a text-based language

Page.Name: Behaving with real class – Using a visual language
Page.MetaTitle: Behaving with real class – Using a visual language
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson sequence offers an approaches to teaching object-oriented principles using visual programming.
Page.MainText: This lesson sequence offers an approaches to teaching object-oriented principles using visual programming. It attempts to address the problem that many of programming languages are too complex and their environments confusing for many students.
Page.LinkName: Opens Behaving with real class – Using a visual language

Page.Name: Breaking up can be good
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson sequence provides an introduction to the skill of decomposition by having students develop discrete modules which together serve a single need: a maths teacher asks for a program that can be used to demonstrate aspects of maths.
Page.MainText: This lesson sequence provides an introduction to the skill of decomposition by having students develop discrete modules which together serve a single need: a maths teacher asks for a program that can be used to demonstrate aspects of maths. This sequence can be used in conjunction with ‘Comparing and selecting appropriate algorithms’.
Page.LinkName: Opens Breaking up can be good

Page.Name: Buzzing with Bee-Bots
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson, students follow and describe a series of steps to program a floor robot.
Page.MainText: In this lesson, students follow and describe a series of steps to program a floor robot. Plan a route to program a robot to follow a path and write a sequence of steps (algorithm).
Page.LinkName: Opens Buzzing with Bee-Bots

Page.Name: Check out the checkout
Page.MetaDescription: This sequence of lessons explores how to incorporate user input, decision-making and loops in programming using the context of a shopping experience, particularly the checkout.
Page.MainText: This sequence of lessons explores how to incorporate user input, decision-making and loops in programming using the context of a shopping experience, particularly the checkout. It combines data in the form of a barcode and programming choices.
Page.LinkName: Opens Check out the checkout

Page.Name: Class blog
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students investigate features of a good blog focusing on such things as the concept, purpose, audience and critical features.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students investigate features of a good blog focusing on such things as the concept, purpose, audience and critical features.
Page.LinkName: Opens Class blog

Page.Name: Clever computers
Page.MetaDescription: In this sequence of lessons explore how to help students understand the elements of a digital system including hardware, software and some commonly used peripheral devices.
Page.MainText: In this sequence of lessons explore how to help students understand the elements of a digital system including hardware, software and some commonly used peripheral devices. Investigate how these elements work together.
Page.LinkName: Opens Clever computers

Page.Name: Communicating safely online
Page.MetaDescription: In this sequence of lessons, use a game to explore the nature of personal information, how data can be recorded to reflect individual identity and how students might protect their personal information.
Page.MainText: In this sequence of lessons, use a game to explore the nature of personal information, how data can be recorded to reflect individual identity and how students might protect their personal information.
Page.LinkName: Opens Communicating safely online

Page.Name: Computer chatter 1: Networks and data transmission
Page.MetaTitle: Computer chatter 1: Networks and data transmission
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students relate the concept of transportation systems to help them develop an understanding of the properties of networked systems and the underlying techniques used to transmit and validate data.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students relate the concept of transportation systems to help them develop an understanding of the properties of networked systems and the underlying techniques used to transmit and validate data.
Page.LinkName: Opens Computer chatter 1: Networks and data transmission

Page.Name: Computer chatter 2: Network performance
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students build on and extend their knowledge of networks and discuss an inquiry question about Wi-Fi speeds and handling bulk of data transfer needs.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students build on and extend their knowledge of networks and discuss an inquiry question about Wi-Fi speeds and handling bulk of data transfer needs.
Page.LinkName: Opens Computer chatter 2: Network performance

Page.Name: Cross age making a robot
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson sequence is a cross-age project that can be used for students in year 5/6 in collaboration with students from years 1-2.
Page.MainText: This lesson sequence is a cross-age project that can be used for students in year 5/6 in collaboration with students from years 1-2. In this project, students collaborate on a code for an unplugged robot. They design, test and modify the robot and create instruction manuals.
Page.LinkName: Opens Cross age making a robot

Page.Name: Data detective
Page.MetaDescription: In this sequence of lessons students conduct a simple survey to collect, organise and present data.
Page.MainText: In this sequence of lessons students conduct a simple survey to collect, organise and present data. In doing so, they demonstrate their understanding of how to use patterns to represent data symbolically.
Page.LinkName: Opens Data detective

Page.Name: Design and deliver
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students create a website that acts as a showcase for a portfolio of their digital work.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students create a website that acts as a showcase for a portfolio of their digital work. They learn about flexible design and how to design a site that can be viewed on a browser using any size of screen.
Page.LinkName: Opens Design and deliver

Page.Name: Eco-calculator
Page.MetaDescription: In this sequence of lessons students make a paper prototype of an eco-calculator to demonstrate human impact on the environment and suggest changes in behaviour.
Page.MainText: In this sequence of lessons students make a paper prototype of an eco-calculator to demonstrate human impact on the environment and suggest changes in behaviour. This is an unplugged activity with an opportunity to extend learning to create a digital solution using Scratch.
Page.LinkName: Opens Eco-calculator

Page.Name: Everything is numbers
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students look at the nature of representation, the variety of ways data is represented in digital systems and the benefits and issues of each approach.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students look at the nature of representation, the variety of ways data is represented in digital systems and the benefits and issues of each approach.
Page.LinkName: Opens Everything is numbers!

Page.Name: Everything you always wanted to know…
Page.MetaTitle: Everything you always wanted to know…
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students design, build and evaluate their own database and perform queries and build reports based on that database.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students design, build and evaluate their own database and perform queries and build reports based on that database. Students should have prior experience creating a flat file database.
Page.LinkName: Opens Everything you always wanted to know…

Page.Name: Fibonacci served three ways
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students learn to code separate modules that perform discrete functions but collectively meet the needs of the solution.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students learn to code separate modules that perform discrete functions but collectively meet the needs of the solution. They select the most appropriate algorithm based on the type of problem.
Page.LinkName: Opens Fibonacci served three ways

Page.Name: Future proofing data
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson sequence aims to identify strengths and weaknesses of past, present and future methods of data storage and recognise the risks and benefits for users.
Page.MainText: This lesson sequence aims to identify strengths and weaknesses of past, present and future methods of data storage and recognise the risks and benefits for users. Students explore specific “data dilemmas”.
Page.LinkName: Opens Future proofing data

Page.Name: Getting warmer
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson sequence intentionally uses a visual based programming tool to introduce designing and validating algorithms.
Page.MainText: This lesson sequence intentionally uses a visual based programming tool to introduce designing and validating algorithms. Those students who complete this task can move to code the result in any text based language with which they are familiar.
Page.LinkName: Opens Getting warmer

Page.Name: Heads or tails
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson we show how to transition from a visual based programming language to using a text-based programming language using the example of a heads or tails coin toss application.
Page.MainText: In this lesson we show how to transition from a visual based programming language to using a text-based programming language using the example of a heads or tails coin toss application.
Page.LinkName: Opens Heads or tails

Page.Name: Home/School communications
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence, students use big data sets and school surveys, to design (and as an extension activity, make) a new digital communication solution for the school.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence, students use big data sets and school surveys, to design (and as an extension activity, make) a new digital communication solution for the school.
Page.LinkName: Opens Home/School communications

Page.Name: Hot or not?
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson sequence focuses on the incremental or Agile approach to development and encourages students to follow the evolution of a temperature conversion tool for a Food Technology teacher.
Page.MainText: This lesson sequence focuses on the incremental or Agile approach to development and encourages students to follow the evolution of a temperature conversion tool for a Food Technology teacher. It uses an Excel spreadsheet application as the prototyping tool.
Page.LinkName: Opens Hot or not?

Page.Name: Introducing algorithms
Page.MetaDescription: In this sequence of lessons, students design a sequence of steps for others to follow.
Page.MainText: In this sequence of lessons, students design a sequence of steps for others to follow. They convey their instructions to peers and evaluate the work of others to determine if the outcome was successful.
Page.LinkName: Opens Introducing algorithms

Page.Name: Introduction to binary
Page.MetaDescription: This sequence of lessons focuses on what a binary number is, what a decimal number is, why binary numbers are important in digital systems and how to read and understand a binary number.
Page.MainText: This sequence of lessons focuses on what a binary number is, what a decimal number is, why binary numbers are important in digital systems and how to read and understand a binary number.
Page.LinkName: Opens Introduction to binary

Page.Name: Introduction to binary - catering for vision impaired students
Page.MetaTitle: Introduction to binary - catering for vision impaired students
Page.MetaDescription: This sequence of lessons focuses on what a binary number is, what a decimal number is, why binary numbers are important in digital systems and how to read and understand a binary number.
Page.MainText: This sequence of lessons focuses on what a binary number is, what a decimal number is, why binary numbers are important in digital systems and how to read and understand a binary number.
Page.LinkName: Opens Introduction to binary - catering for vision impaired students

Page.Name: Is it going to rain today?
Page.MetaTitle: Is it going to rain today?
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students understand the importance of data in effective decision-making, and are able to find, sort and interpret Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) rainfall data, and to collect their own data and analyse the resulting datasets.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students understand the importance of data in effective decision-making, and are able to find, sort and interpret Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) rainfall data, and to collect their own data and analyse the resulting datasets.
Page.LinkName: Opens Is it going to rain today?

Page.Name: Keeping secrets
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students examine cryptography and modern encryption methods for transmitting digital data securely.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students examine cryptography and modern encryption methods for transmitting digital data securely. Encryption of data is a means of protecting data, one example being the use of secret and public keys.
Page.LinkName: Opens Keeping secrets

Page.Name: Makey Makey boards
Page.MetaDescription: In this sequence of lessons students explore how electrical energy can be transferred and transformed in electrical circuits, using Makey Makey boards as the basis for experimentation and recoding of data.
Page.MainText: In this sequence of lessons students explore how electrical energy can be transferred and transformed in electrical circuits, using Makey Makey boards as the basis for experimentation and recoding of data.
Page.LinkName: Opens Makey Makey boards

Page.Name: Making maths quizzes 1: Plan and test our programs
Page.MetaTitle: Making maths quizzes 1: Plan and test our programs
Page.MetaDescription: In this sequence of lessons students plan, create and edit a program that will ask maths questions that are harder or easier depending on user performance.
Page.MainText: In this sequence of lessons students plan, create and edit a program that will ask maths questions that are harder or easier depending on user performance.
Page.LinkName: Opens Making maths quizzes 1: Plan and test our programs

Page.Name: Making maths quizzes 2: Implementing a digital solution
Page.MetaTitle: Making maths quizzes 2: Implementing a digital solution
Page.MetaDescription: In this sequence of lessons students implement a digital solution for a maths quiz.
Page.MainText: In this sequence of lessons students implement a digital solution for a maths quiz. They test and assess how well it works.
Page.LinkName: Opens Making maths quizzes 2: Implementing a digital solution

Page.Name: Morse code network
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson sequence is a hands-on approach to the learning about digital systems for years 7–8.
Page.MainText: This lesson sequence is a hands-on approach to the learning about digital systems for years 7–8.
Page.LinkName: Opens Morse code network

Page.Name: Off to the movies
Page.MetaDescription: Create a simple program using a text-based programming language to generate an output based on two possible input options.
Page.MainText: Create a simple program using a text-based programming language to generate an output based on two possible input options. This is a simple Boolean (true/false) application where its asks the user’s age - if you are over 15 then you can watch G and M rated movies - if you are under 15, then you can only watch G rated movies. This lesson was designed in collaboration with Jason Vearing QSITE (Gold Coast Chapter).
Page.LinkName: Opens Off to the movies

Page.Name: Peripherals
Page.MetaDescription: In this sequence of lessons students explore different types of peripherals used every day in order to identify the data transmitted.
Page.MainText: In this sequence of lessons students explore different types of peripherals used every day in order to identify the data transmitted. A peripheral is an auxiliary device such as a computer mouse or keyboard that connects to and works with a device in some way.
Page.LinkName: Opens Peripherals

Page.Name: Planting fruit and vegetables
Page.MetaDescription: In this sequence of lessons students grow a plant from seed, capturing each step and decision as an algorithmic process and recording data for future learning.
Page.MainText: In this sequence of lessons students grow a plant from seed, capturing each step and decision as an algorithmic process and recording data for future learning.
Page.LinkName: Opens Planting fruit and vegetables

Page.Name: Put the user in user interface
Page.MetaTitle: Put the user in user interface
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students investigate the importance of quality design and design principles in creating an efficient and effective user interface.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students investigate the importance of quality design and design principles in creating an efficient and effective user interface.
Page.LinkName: Opens Put the user in user interface

Page.Name: Rubbish recording and reduction: Part 1
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students survey and collect data concerning what is brought to school each day and subsequently becomes rubbish.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students survey and collect data concerning what is brought to school each day and subsequently becomes rubbish. They then use Excel to present that data in a variety of different ways.
Page.LinkName: Opens Rubbish recording and reduction: Part 1

Page.Name: Rubbish recording and reduction: Part 2
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students use Excel to present data in a variety of ways.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students use Excel to present data in a variety of ways.
Page.LinkName: Opens Rubbish recording and reduction: Part 2

Page.Name: Seeing the big picture
Page.MetaDescription: This practical lesson sequence examines lossy and lossless techniques of data compression.
Page.MainText: This practical lesson sequence examines lossy and lossless techniques of data compression. Students perform comparisons of various compressions on a variety of images.
Page.LinkName: Opens Seeing the big picture

Page.Name: Seeing the wood for the trees
Page.MetaTitle: Seeing the wood for the trees
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students summarise data using advanced filtering and grouping techniques, for example pivot tables in spreadsheets and aggregation functions in databases.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students summarise data using advanced filtering and grouping techniques, for example pivot tables in spreadsheets and aggregation functions in databases.
Page.LinkName: Opens Seeing the wood for the trees

Page.Name: Seven seasons
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students investigate the CSIRO indigenous seasons calendars and produce a searchable database that will capture data using two data sources.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students investigate the CSIRO indigenous seasons calendars and produce a searchable database that will capture data using two data sources.
Page.LinkName: Opens Seven seasons

Page.Name: Spreadsheets come alive
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence use the ‘Odds and evens’ problem as a springboard.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence use the ‘Odds and evens’ problem as a springboard. Students construct interactive spreadsheets designed to address particular needs. This lesson also demonstrates an approach to programming known as rapid application development (RAD).
Page.LinkName: Opens Spreadsheets come alive

Page.Name: Talk to me!
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence that focuses on input devices, students are explore the possibilities and new types of functionality enabled by these technologies over time.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence that focuses on input devices, students are explore the possibilities and new types of functionality enabled by these technologies over time.
Page.LinkName: Opens Talk to me!

Page.Name: The shock of the new
Page.MetaDescription: Using four inventions from 1985, this lesson sequence explores the impact of innovation, supporting circumstances, how individuals contribute to change and the importance of addressing benefits as well as risks in the development of new systems.
Page.MainText: Using four inventions from 1985, this lesson sequence explores the impact of innovation, supporting circumstances, how individuals contribute to change and the importance of addressing benefits as well as risks in the development of new systems.
Page.LinkName: Opens The shock of the new

Page.Name: There can only be one
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students write a simple suite of programs that can be used to facilitate an S.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students write a simple suite of programs that can be used to facilitate an S.R.C. election though the collection and processing of data. It assumes that students have been introduced to Python programming language.
Page.LinkName: Opens There can only be one

Page.Name: Using binary to create on/off pictures
Page.MetaTitle: Using binary to create on/off pictures
Page.MetaDescription: In this sequence of lessons students develop an understanding of how computers store and send digital images and they are able to represent images in a digital format.
Page.MainText: In this sequence of lessons students develop an understanding of how computers store and send digital images and they are able to represent images in a digital format.
Page.LinkName: Opens Using binary to create on/off pictures

Page.Name: Weather forecast from the stratosphere
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson sequence is designed to introduce students to data analysis using a spreadsheet such as MS Excel.
Page.MainText: This lesson sequence is designed to introduce students to data analysis using a spreadsheet such as MS Excel. The project is based on a real world problem and a real data set from a weather balloon launched in Australia earlier this year. The project consists of 5 lessons of variable length, each with a different focus. The lessons are mapped to Digital Technologies outcomes, with a strong association to the science outcomes for water cycles in year 7.
Page.LinkName: Opens Weather forecast from the stratosphere

Page.Name: Who wants to be a millionaire?
Page.MetaTitle: Who wants to be a millionaire?
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson sequence uses the well-known wheat/rice and chessboard problem as students use spreadsheets to simulate iteration and to solve problems.
Page.MainText: This lesson sequence uses the well-known wheat/rice and chessboard problem as students use spreadsheets to simulate iteration and to solve problems.
Page.LinkName: Opens Who wants to be a millionaire?

Page.Name: Working together
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson sequence students, through role-play and other activities, develop understandings of the role of hardware and software in managing, controlling and securing the movement of and access to data in networked digital systems.
Page.MainText: In this lesson sequence students, through role-play and other activities, develop understandings of the role of hardware and software in managing, controlling and securing the movement of and access to data in networked digital systems.
Page.LinkName: Opens Working together

Page.Name: Basic ball control with Sphero
Page.MetaDescription: Students are introduced to Sphero and its main features – direction, speed and colour.
Page.MainText: Students are introduced to Sphero and its main features – direction, speed and colour. This lesson allows students to experiment through playing with Sphero and controlling it with the Sphero app. This lesson idea was created by Steven Payne.
Page.LinkName: Opens Basic ball control with Sphero

Page.Name: Bee Bot Balloon Pop
Page.MetaDescription: During this lesson, students will be required to consider the functions of the Bee-Bot and how a user can interact with this device.
Page.MainText: During this lesson, students will be required to consider the functions of the Bee-Bot and how a user can interact with this device. Students are asked to design a course challenge for another user which will result in the Bee-Bot, with a pin attached, reversing into a balloon to pop it. This lesson idea was created by Lauren Stanhope.
Page.LinkName: Opens Bee Bot Balloon Pop

Page.Name: Choose your Ozo adventure
Page.MetaDescription: Using Ozobots students use and develop unusual types of data: Redefining “What is data?”.
Page.MainText: Using Ozobots students use and develop unusual types of data: Redefining “What is data?”. This lesson idea was created by Ben Jucius.
Page.LinkName: Opens Choose your Ozo adventure

Page.Name: Exploring digital systems with Makey Makey
Page.MetaTitle: Exploring digital systems with Makey Makey
Page.MetaDescription: In this activity, students learn about digital systems and how a circuit works using the Makey Makey toolkit.
Page.MainText: In this activity, students learn about digital systems and how a circuit works using the Makey Makey toolkit. They sort conductive and nonconductive items into groups using an experimental approach. This lesson idea was created by Rebecca Vivian.
Page.LinkName: Opens Exploring digital systems with Makey Makey

Page.Name: Getting to know Bee-Bot
Page.MetaDescription: Students are introduced to the Bee-Bot as a robotic device.
Page.MainText: Students are introduced to the Bee-Bot as a robotic device. They learn about what the Bee-Bot is, the functions and how the Bee-Bot can be used for specific purposes. They learn how to develop a sequence of steps for the Bee-Bot to follow. This lesson idea was created by Rebecca Vivian.
Page.LinkName: Opens Getting to know Bee-Bot

Page.Name: Goldilocks, the Three Bears and BeeBot
Page.MetaTitle: Goldilocks, the Three Bears and BeeBot
Page.MetaDescription: Students explore a sequence of steps using Bee-Bots in the context of familiar narratives.
Page.MainText: Students explore a sequence of steps using Bee-Bots in the context of familiar narratives. They navigate a Bee-Bot to events within the story, first as a whole class and then in small groups. This activity can be integrated with English and the exploration of narratives. This lesson idea was created by Rebecca Vivian.
Page.LinkName: Opens Goldilocks, the Three Bears and BeeBot

Page.Name: Introduction to Ozobot and colour codes
Page.MetaTitle: Introduction to Ozobot and colour codes
Page.MetaDescription: Students are introduced to Ozobot and how drawing lines and colour codes can control it.
Page.MainText: Students are introduced to Ozobot and how drawing lines and colour codes can control it. This lesson allows students to experiment with different lines and codes to create a path for Ozobot to follow. This lesson idea was created by Steven Payne.
Page.LinkName: Opens Introduction to Ozobot and colour codes

Page.Name: Light up soft toy with LilyPad
Page.MetaTitle: Light up soft toy with LilyPad
Page.MetaDescription: This project will explore two ways of controlling the flow of current to a LED using a button and switch.
Page.MainText: This project will explore two ways of controlling the flow of current to a LED using a button and switch. No programming is initially expected in this project, however once students are comfortable with connecting or sewing their circuits and attaching lights, a follow-up project that involves using a pre built Arduino program to light up a series of lights in order would be a useful next step. This lesson idea was created by Peter Lelong.
Page.LinkName: Opens Light up soft toy with LilyPad

Page.Name: Lilypad Personalised Alert Buzzer
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson students will create a personalised musical buzzer by programming the LilyPad Arduino to play a sound using the Main board, Buzzer and Button, coding the note frequency in Arduino IDE.
Page.MainText: In this lesson students will create a personalised musical buzzer by programming the LilyPad Arduino to play a sound using the Main board, Buzzer and Button, coding the note frequency in Arduino IDE. The lesson can be extended to include LED’s that light up or flash according to the note played to enable the buzzer to be used for the hearing impaired. This lesson idea was created by Toni Falusi.
Page.LinkName: Opens Lilypad Personalised Alert Buzzer

Page.Name: Makey makey interactive poster
Page.MetaDescription: Add a Makey Makey to a poster/model or diorama.
Page.MainText: Add a Makey Makey to a poster/model or diorama. The Makey Makey combined with Scratch.mit.edu will enable students to record a voiceover for the poster to add extra information and create an interactive project. This can be applied to any subject area. The target group is Years 3-4, but as not all students have been exposed to coding and physical computing it could be used with secondary students. This lesson idea was created by Meridith Ebbs.
Page.LinkName: Opens Makey makey interactive poster

Page.Name: Ozobot Maze Challenge
Page.MetaDescription: Students are introduced to Ozoblockly and basic programming concepts.
Page.MainText: Students are introduced to Ozoblockly and basic programming concepts. Using Ozoblockly, students program Ozobot to follow a path and travel through a maze that they have created. This lesson idea was created by Steven Payne.
Page.LinkName: Opens Ozobot Maze Challenge

Page.Name: Programming LED circuit with Arduino IDE
Page.MetaTitle: Programming LED circuit with Arduino IDE
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson students will be using components of the LilyPad development kit to create a circuit of LED’s that are controlled using a basic Arduino program, written in the Arduino IDE.
Page.MainText: In this lesson students will be using components of the LilyPad development kit to create a circuit of LED’s that are controlled using a basic Arduino program, written in the Arduino IDE. Starting with a simple sequence of turning a LED on and off, the students can be challenged to choose a piece of music with a steady beat and program the lights to turn on and off in time to the music. This lesson idea was created by Toni Falusi.
Page.LinkName: Opens Programming LED circuit with Arduino IDE

Page.Name: Sphero and the chocolate factory
Page.MetaDescription: This activity allows students to use the visual programming software Lightning Lab to control Sphero to act out the role of a fictional character.
Page.MainText: This activity allows students to use the visual programming software Lightning Lab to control Sphero to act out the role of a fictional character. This activity uses Charlie and the Chocolate Factory by Roald Dahl as an example. This lesson idea was created by Steven Payne.
Page.LinkName: Opens Sphero and the chocolate factory

Page.Name: Sphero Invent a Game
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson will explore how to program the Sphero using functions and show the benefits of decomposing the behaviour of the Sphero into functions, instead of writing line by line repeated behaviours.
Page.MainText: This lesson will explore how to program the Sphero using functions and show the benefits of decomposing the behaviour of the Sphero into functions, instead of writing line by line repeated behaviours. This lesson idea was created by Celia Coffa.
Page.LinkName: Opens Sphero Invent a Game

Page.Name: Sphero maze
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson will explore how to program the Sphero using functions and show the benefits of decomposing the behaviour of the Sphero into functions, instead of writing line by line repeated behaviours.
Page.MainText: This lesson will explore how to program the Sphero using functions and show the benefits of decomposing the behaviour of the Sphero into functions, instead of writing line by line repeated behaviours. This lesson idea was created by Claudia Szabo.
Page.LinkName: Opens Sphero maze

Page.Name: Sphero young inventors
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson students will explore the use of Sphero in the everyday world by adding accessories to invent solutions to workplace or other problems or simply by inventing an adaptation to the device.
Page.MainText: In this lesson students will explore the use of Sphero in the everyday world by adding accessories to invent solutions to workplace or other problems or simply by inventing an adaptation to the device. In each case, they are to build the accessory and create the code required for the device to serve a particular purpose. This lesson idea was created by Celia Coffa.
Page.LinkName: Opens Sphero young inventors

Page.Name: Sphero: Catch me if you can
Page.MetaTitle: Sphero: Catch me if you can
Page.MetaDescription: By years 5 and 6 many students may have had some experience with a visual programming language such as Scratch or Blockly that is the basis of the Hour of Code.
Page.MainText: By years 5 and 6 many students may have had some experience with a visual programming language such as Scratch or Blockly that is the basis of the Hour of Code. Sphero will take the screen based control of an image to the next level by introducing a robotic device controlled by a visual programming language. This lesson idea was created by Peter Lelong.
Page.LinkName: Opens Sphero: Catch me if you can

Page.Name: The wizard of Ozo
Page.MetaDescription: Using OzoBots students move an Ozobot about a map with coordinates.
Page.MainText: Using OzoBots students move an Ozobot about a map with coordinates. This lesson idea was created by Ben Jucius.
Page.LinkName: Opens The wizard of Ozo

Page.Name: User interface design: Controllers for all
Page.MetaTitle: User interface design: Controllers for all
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson, students design and implement a new user-interface that allows a user to interact with a digital program.
Page.MainText: In this lesson, students design and implement a new user-interface that allows a user to interact with a digital program. This lesson idea was created by Rebecca Vivian.
Page.LinkName: Opens User interface design: Controllers for all

Page.Name: What's the buzz?
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson students use BeeBots and Scratch Junior to synthesize what they know about Bees and are introduced to mapping concepts.
Page.MainText: In this lesson students use BeeBots and Scratch Junior to synthesize what they know about Bees and are introduced to mapping concepts. This lesson idea was created by Karen Butler.
Page.LinkName: Opens What's the buzz?

Page.Name: Hot Bots
Page.MetaDescription: For this project, students are introduced to the Arduino microcontroller and Arduino integrated development environment for programming a switch on an air conditioner.
Page.MainText: For this project, students are introduced to the Arduino microcontroller and Arduino integrated development environment for programming a switch on an air conditioner. This lesson was designed by Cindy Thornton, Flinders Island District High School, Tasmania.
Page.LinkName: Opens Hot Bots

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: Index page
Page.MetaTitle: Visual to text coding: Index page
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson sequence provides a bridge between visual coding (eg. Scratch) and General Purpose Programming languages (eg. Python or JavaScript).
Page.MainText: This lesson sequence provides a bridge between visual coding (eg. Scratch) and General Purpose Programming languages (eg. Python or JavaScript). This resource is most suitable if you have never done General Purpose Programming and/or you benefit from slow-paced, step-by-step video tutorials.
Page.LinkName: Opens Visual to text coding course

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: Setting Up
Page.MetaTitle: Visual to text coding: Setting Up
Page.MetaDescription: This series of lessons is to help students to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a general-purpose programming language.
Page.MainText: This series of lessons is to help students to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a general-purpose programming language. This section provides guidance on how to set-up the particular programming environment including Scratch, Python and JavaScript.
Page.LinkName: Opens Setting Up

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: The Basics
Page.MetaTitle: Visual to text coding: The Basics
Page.MetaDescription: This series of lessons is to help students to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a general-purpose programming language.
Page.MainText: This series of lessons is to help students to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a general-purpose programming language. This section provides the basics in order to use the programming environments: Scratch, Python and JavaScript.
Page.LinkName: Opens The Basics

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: Lesson 1
Page.MetaDescription: This is the first in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a general-purpose programming language.
Page.MainText: This is the first in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a general-purpose programming language. This lesson may take two to three 45-minute periods. It introduces how to create variables, get user input and perform maths operations.
Page.LinkName: Lesson 1: Temperature converter

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: Lesson 2
Page.MetaDescription: This is the second in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a general-purpose programming language.
Page.MainText: This is the second in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a general-purpose programming language. This lesson may take two to three 45-minute periods. It introduces how to make decisions (branching) and identify data types.
Page.LinkName: Opens Lesson 2: Calculator

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: Lesson 3
Page.MetaDescription: This is the third in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a general-purpose programming language.
Page.MainText: This is the third in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a general-purpose programming language. This lesson may take two to three 45-minute periods. It introduces how to generate and use random numbers.
Page.LinkName: Opens Lesson 3: Heads or Tails

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: Lesson 4
Page.MetaDescription: This is the fourth in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language.
Page.MainText: This is the fourth in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language. This lesson may take two to three 45-minute periods. It introduces the combining of logical operators and and or for more complex decisions.
Page.LinkName: Opens Lesson 4: Scissors, Paper, Rock

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: Lesson 5
Page.MetaDescription: This is the fifth in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a general purpose programming language.
Page.MainText: This is the fifth in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a general purpose programming language. This lesson may take two to three 45-minute periods. It introduces how to create and use arrays (also called lists).
Page.LinkName: Opens Lesson 5: Password generator

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: Lesson 6
Page.MetaDescription: This is the sixth in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language.
Page.MainText: This is the sixth in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language. This lesson may take two to three 45-minute periods. It builds on the previous introduction to arrays (also called lists) and brings in the length property.
Page.LinkName: Opens Lesson 6: Magic 8 ball

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: Lesson 7
Page.MetaDescription: This is the seventh in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language.
Page.MainText: This is the seventh in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language. This lesson may take two to three 45-minute periods. It introduces iteration (also called loops).
Page.LinkName: Opens Lesson 7: Times tables

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: Lesson 8
Page.MetaDescription: This is the eighth in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language.
Page.MainText: This is the eighth in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language. This lesson may take two to three 45-minute periods. It brings together skills from the previous lessons to design and develop a Higher Lower game, where the player tries to guess a secret number.
Page.LinkName: Opens Lesson 8: Guess the number

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: Lesson 9
Page.MetaDescription: This is the ninth in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language.
Page.MainText: This is the ninth in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language. This lesson may take two to three 45-minute periods. It explores creating powerful programs for managing and analysing data, by combining the previous skills of using loops and working with arrays.
Page.LinkName: Opens Lesson 9: Loops and arrays combined

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: Lesson 10
Page.MetaDescription: This is the tenth in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language.
Page.MainText: This is the tenth in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language. This lesson may take two to three 45-minute periods. It introduces the coding concept of functions. Functions can help organise code, reduce repetition and more to be explored later.
Page.LinkName: Opens Lesson 10: Simple functions

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: Lesson 11
Page.MetaDescription: This is the eleventh in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language.
Page.MainText: This is the eleventh in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language. It builds on the coding concept of functions. With the addition of parameters, functions allow the programmer to adapt their reusable code’s behaviour, tapping into the Computational Thinking skills of generalisation, pattern recognition and abstraction.
Page.LinkName: Opens Lesson 11: Adaptable functions with parameters

Page.Name: Visual to text coding: Lesson 12
Page.MetaDescription: This is the final in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language.
Page.MainText: This is the final in a series of lessons to transition from visual coding to text-based coding with a General Purpose Programming language. See next steps for suggested courses and learning sequences after this lesson. It builds on the coding concept of functions (by introducing the concept of return values. Functions are often written to return a result, which can then be used in the main program.
Page.LinkName: Opens Lesson 12: Functions that give back (return values)

Page.Name: Data compression
Page.MetaDescription: Students will learn how the information in a pixel can be manipulated to change the image, and apply a bitmask filter to an image to remove some information and reduce the memory size of the file.
Page.MainText: Students will learn how the information in a pixel can be manipulated to change the image, and apply a bitmask filter to an image to remove some information and reduce the memory size of the file. Finally, students will modify the filter to find a balance between quality and small file size. Based on the original lessons developed by the Exploring Computational Thinking team at Google.
Page.LinkName: Opens Data compression

Page.Name: Coding a sentimental chatbot in Python
Page.MetaTitle: Coding a sentimental chatbot in Python
Page.MetaDescription: Incorporating 11 tutorial videos and two informative lecture videos, this learning sequence explores natural language processing, a significant application of artificial intelligence.
Page.MainText: Incorporating 11 tutorial videos and two informative lecture videos, this learning sequence explores natural language processing, a significant application of artificial intelligence. Teachers and students are led through the coding in Python of a chatbot, a conversational program capable of responding in varied ways to user input, including with the use of smart sentiment analysis.
Page.LinkName: Opens Coding a sentimental chatbot in Python

Page.Name: Book analysis with AI techniques
Page.MetaDescription: This learning sequence explores text analysis through Natural Language Processing, a significant application of Artificial Intelligence.
Page.MainText: This learning sequence explores text analysis through Natural Language Processing, a significant application of Artificial Intelligence. Teachers and students are led through a series of video tutorials to develop a Python program that can break down and analyse the content of a complete text and use smart sentiment analysis to attempt to determine the villain(s) and hero(s).
Page.LinkName: Opens Book analysis with AI techniques in a new window

Page.Name: Coding for GUIs (JavaScript edition): Index page
Page.MetaTitle: Coding for GUIs (JavaScript edition): Index page
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson sequence provides step-by-step video tutorials and challenges to incorporate Graphical User Interfaces (GUIs) into your General Purpose Programming.
Page.MainText: This lesson sequence provides step-by-step video tutorials and challenges to incorporate Graphical User Interfaces (GUIs) into your General Purpose Programming. It follows on from the Visual To Text Coding lesson series.
Page.LinkName: Opens Coding for GUIs (Javascript edition) course

Page.MetaTitle: Coding for GUIs Lesson 1: Structure, style and function
Page.MetaDescription: This is the first in a series of lessons to incorporate Graphical User Interfaces (GUIs) into your General Purpose Programming.
Page.MainText: This is the first in a series of lessons to incorporate Graphical User Interfaces (GUIs) into your General Purpose Programming. It follows on from the Visual To Text Coding lesson series.

Page.MainText: This is the second in a series of lessons to incorporate graphical user interfaces (GUIs) into your general-purpose programming. The series follows on from the Visual To Text Coding lesson series.

Page.MainText: This is the third in a series of lessons to incorporate graphical user interfaces (GUIs) into your general-purpose programming. The series follows on from the Visual to text coding lesson series.

Page.MetaTitle: Coding for GUIs Lesson 4: Flipping images
Page.MetaDescription: This is the fourth in a series of lessons to incorporate graphical user interfaces (GUIs) into your general-purpose programming.
Page.MainText: This is the fourth in a series of lessons to incorporate graphical user interfaces (GUIs) into your general-purpose programming. The series follows on from the Visual to text coding lesson series.

Page.MainText: This is the fifth in a series of lessons to incorporate Graphical User Interfaces (GUIs) into your General Purpose Programming. The series follows on from the Visual To Text Coding lesson series.

Page.Name: Coding for GUIs Final project: A complete application with GUI
Page.MetaTitle: Coding for GUIs Final project: A complete application with GUI
Page.MetaDescription: This is the final project in a series of lessons to incorporate Graphical User Interfaces (GUIs) into your General Purpose Programming.
Page.MainText: This is the final project in a series of lessons to incorporate Graphical User Interfaces (GUIs) into your General Purpose Programming. The series follows on from the Visual To Text Coding lesson series.

Page.Name: Recognising AI
Page.MetaDescription: Use the tasks in this lesson to introduce concepts that underpin artificial intelligence (AI). Use the downloadable AI cards with your students to explore what they know about AI.
Page.MainText: Use the tasks in this lesson to introduce concepts that underpin artificial intelligence (AI). The majority of the tasks are unplugged (do not require a digital device). Use the downloadable AI cards with your students to explore what they know about AI.
Page.LinkName: Opens Recognising AI

Page.Name: Can a computer recognise your sentiment?
Page.MetaTitle: Can a computer recognise your sentiment?
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson plan enables students to explore how Natural Language Processing (NLP), a subset of Artificial Intelligence (AI), is used to assess and categorise a user’s online comments.
Page.MainText: This lesson plan enables students to explore how Natural Language Processing (NLP), a subset of Artificial Intelligence (AI), is used to assess and categorise a user’s online comments. (AI is the ability of machines to mimic human capabilities in a way that we would consider 'smart'.)
Page.LinkName: Opens Can a computer recognise your sentiment?

Page.Name: Fun projects with language translation
Page.MetaDescription: Natural language processing is growing in importance.
Page.MainText: Natural language processing is growing in importance. We often converse with automatic chatbots for customer service without even knowing. We also use online translation services or mobile apps. But how do these services work? Is there artificial intelligence (AI) in them? Three projects are offered to cater for student interest and different programming skill levels.
Page.LinkName: Opens Fun projects with language translation

Page.Name: Data bias in AI
Page.MetaDescription: Artificial intelligence can sometimes be biased to certain shapes or colours.
Page.MainText: Artificial intelligence can sometimes be biased to certain shapes or colours. When such AI systems are applied to situations that involve people, then this bias can manifest itself as bias against skin colour or gender. This lesson explores bias in AI, where it comes from and what can be done to prevent it.
Page.LinkName: Opens Data bias in AI

Page.Name: Home automation with AI
Page.MetaDescription: Home automation is all the rage.
Page.MainText: Home automation is all the rage. You talk to your mobile phone to control the lights, the fan, the air conditioner, or your pool pump. But how does it work? In this lesson, we explore the AI that could power a home automation system.
Page.LinkName: Opens Home automation with AI

Page.Name: Smartphone security
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson provides an opportunity to investigate security measures, including those powered by artificial intelligence (AI), that are used to protect users from unauthorised (unapproved, unwanted) access to their digital devices.
Page.MainText: This lesson provides an opportunity to investigate security measures, including those powered by artificial intelligence (AI), that are used to protect users from unauthorised (unapproved, unwanted) access to their digital devices.
Page.LinkName: Opens Smartphone security

Page.Name: AI image recognition - exploring limitations and bias
Page.MetaTitle: AI image recognition - exploring limitations and bias
Page.MetaDescription: A hands-on activity to practise training and testing an artificial intelligence (AI) model, using cartoon faces, including a discussion about sources of potential algorithmic bias and how to respond to these sources.
Page.MainText: A hands-on activity to practise training and testing an artificial intelligence (AI) model, using cartoon faces, including a discussion about sources of potential algorithmic bias and how to respond to these sources.
Page.LinkName: Opens AI image recognition - exploring limitations and bias

Page.Name: Note the music
Page.MetaDescription: We can program a computer to play music.
Page.MainText: We can program a computer to play music. Conventionally this is done by hard coding, which is the process of coding all possible expected behaviours. Alternatively, we can train an artificial intelligence (AI) computer about what notes go well with others, so it can play a duet with a human musician. Students can make their own instrument that plays a particular note for a set beat, for example when a piano key is pressed or a guitar string is strummed or a drum skin is hit.
Page.LinkName: Opens Note the music

Page.Name: Anti-bullying AI
Page.MetaDescription: Sometimes we write and post things on social media in a hurry.
Page.MainText: Sometimes we write and post things on social media in a hurry. Such posts can hurt people and even make them feel bullied. Wouldn't it be great if an Artificial Intelligence application could check our posts as we write them, and warn us if they were potentially hurtful?
Page.LinkName: Opens Anti-bullying AI

Page.Name: Can AI guess your emotion?
Page.MetaDescription: Discuss emotions as a class, and introduce the idea of artificial intelligence (AI).
Page.MainText: Discuss emotions as a class, and introduce the idea of artificial intelligence (AI). This lesson can also be used to introduce image classification – a key application of AI. Developed in collaboration with Digital Technologies Institute.
Page.LinkName: Can AI guess your emotion?

Page.Name: Home automation programming (yrs 5-6)
Page.MetaDescription: Investigate home automation systems, including those powered by artificial intelligence (AI) with speech recognition capability.
Page.MainText: Investigate home automation systems, including those powered by artificial intelligence (AI) with speech recognition capability. These suggested activities provide a level of differentiation to cater for students’ range of programming skills. They were developed in collaboration with the Digital Technologies Institute.
Page.LinkName: Opens Home automation programming

Page.Name: Home automation: General purpose programming
Page.MetaDescription: Investigate home automation systems, including those powered by artificial intelligence (AI) with speech recognition capability.
Page.MainText: Investigate home automation systems, including those powered by artificial intelligence (AI) with speech recognition capability. These suggested activities for year levels 7-8 are designed for students using general purpose programming languages JavaScript and Python, with similar content to the visual coding lesson Home automation programming for year levels 5-6.
Page.LinkName: Opens Home automation: General purpose programming

Page.Name: Analysis of AI applications, drawing on ethical understandings
Page.MetaTitle: Analysis of AI applications, drawing on ethical understandings
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson plan explores the ethical aspects of artificial intelligence and the implications on our future lives.
Page.MainText: This lesson plan explores the ethical aspects of artificial intelligence and the implications on our future lives. This lesson was developed by the Digital Technologies Institute in collaboration with the DT Hub.
Page.LinkName: Opens Analysis of AI applications, drawing on ethical understandings

Page.Name: AI ethics - What's possible, probable and preferred?
Page.MetaTitle: AI ethics - What's possible, probable and preferred?
Page.MetaDescription: The development and ubiquity of Artificial Intelligence raise a number of social and ethical matters that students can explore in the Digital Technologies classroom.
Page.MainText: The development and ubiquity of Artificial Intelligence raise a number of social and ethical matters that students can explore in the Digital Technologies classroom. This lesson idea outlines a project to help students frame such discussions using the curriculum Key Idea of Creating preferred futures, tying into Critical and Creative Thinking.
Page.LinkName: Opens AI ethics - What's possible, probable and preferred?

Page.Name: How can AI recognise what it sees?
Page.MetaTitle: How can AI recognise what it sees?
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson is an introduction to the way in which a computer sees.
Page.MainText: This lesson is an introduction to the way in which a computer sees. It focuses on image recognition that involves feature extraction, object detection and classification. This lesson was developed in collaboration with Dr Karsten Schulz, Digital Technologies Institute.
Page.LinkName: Opens How can AI recognise what it sees?

Page.Name: Can an AI recognise what you are drawing
Page.MetaTitle: Can an AI recognise what you are drawing
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson provides an opportunity to incorporate representation of data using a relevant context being studied in the classroom.
Page.MainText: This lesson provides an opportunity to incorporate representation of data using a relevant context being studied in the classroom. Students represent an object using a line drawing, focusing on the features of the object that enable it to be easily recognised. Students experiment with creating representations using an AI drawing tool that guesses what is being drawn.
Page.LinkName: Opens Can an AI recognise what you are drawing

Page.Name: AI quiz
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson provides an opportunity for students to draw on their ethical understanding when asked to respond to different scenarios.
Page.MainText: This lesson provides an opportunity for students to draw on their ethical understanding when asked to respond to different scenarios. The scenarios feature information systems that incorporate an AI application. Students are given four options to select which one they believe to be the ‘right’ thing to do. Students develop a set of guidelines for ethical AI development.
Page.LinkName: Opens AI Quiz

Page.Name: Habits of a Systems Thinker
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson introduces some of the skills and concepts involved with Systems Thinking.
Page.MainText: This lesson introduces some of the skills and concepts involved with Systems Thinking. Students are introduced to a number of Habits of a System Thinker, positive and negative feedback loops and the concept of supra- and subsystems.
Page.LinkName: Opens Habits of a Systems Thinker

Page.Name: Systems Thinking and AI applications
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson takes a systems thinking approach to understanding the place of artificial intelligence (AI) as a component within solutions to real world problems, such as predicting bushfire hotspots, spotting and monitoring animals in the wild, automated horticulture and agriculture, and early detection of medical issues.
Page.MainText: This lesson takes a systems thinking approach to understanding the place of artificial intelligence (AI) as a component within solutions to real world problems, such as predicting bushfire hotspots, spotting and monitoring animals in the wild, automated horticulture and agriculture, and early detection of medical issues.
Page.LinkName: Opens Systems Thinking and AI applications

Page.Name: Rock, Paper, Scissors AI!
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson we use the game rock, paper scissors to investigate how an AI can recognise your hand gestures.
Page.MainText: In this lesson we use the game rock, paper scissors to investigate how an AI can recognise your hand gestures. Firstly students create, train and test their own AI model. They import their AI model into a pre-made JavaScript program to modify the computer program to incorporate game play. The level of game play will depend on the student's level of programming skills.
Page.LinkName: Opens Rock, Paper, Scissors AI!

Page.Name: About me
Page.MetaDescription: Order images to show a sequence of personal events or milestones such as birth, first tooth, beginning to crawl.
Page.MainText: Order images to show a sequence of personal events or milestones such as birth, first tooth, beginning to crawl.
Page.LinkName: Opens About me

Page.Name: Agreeing to an ICT agreement
Page.MetaDescription: Students work together to brainstorm the dangers, problems and pitfalls in using ICT and online spaces.
Page.MainText: Students work together to brainstorm the dangers, problems and pitfalls in using ICT and online spaces. They collaboratively agree upon a set of protocols and rules for using technology, and develop processes and procedures to follow when using ICT.
Page.LinkName: Opens Agreeing to an ICT agreement

Page.Name: Bee-Bot ruler
Page.MetaDescription: Explore the concept of sequencing steps, using Bee-Bots to measure length.
Page.MainText: Explore the concept of sequencing steps, using Bee-Bots to measure length.
Page.LinkName: Opens Bee-Bot ruler

Page.Name: Blue-Bot challenges
Page.MetaDescription: Use these challenges created by Kylie Docherty, QSITE to provide opportunities for students to learn how to design and follow a series of steps to program Blue-Bot.
Page.MainText: Use these challenges created by Kylie Docherty, QSITE to provide opportunities for students to learn how to design and follow a series of steps to program Blue-Bot.
Page.LinkName: Opens Blue-Bot challenges

Page.Name: Create a board game that uses an Ozobot
Page.MetaTitle: Create a board game that uses an Ozobot
Page.MetaDescription: Create a game board where the player is provided with a number of decisions.
Page.MainText: Create a game board where the player is provided with a number of decisions. Using Scratch and Makey Makey, students add multimodal elements to the story. These elements are activated using an Ozobot.
Page.LinkName: Opens Create a board game that uses an Ozobot

Page.Name: Create a language learning program
Page.MetaDescription: Create a computer program to learn a traditional Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander language.
Page.MainText: Create a computer program to learn a traditional Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander language.
Page.LinkName: Opens Create a language learning program

Page.Name: Creating my own spreadsheet to convert binary to decimal
Page.MetaTitle: Creating my own spreadsheet to convert binary to decimal
Page.MetaDescription: A spreadsheet can be used to do calculations quickly using formulas.
Page.MainText: A spreadsheet can be used to do calculations quickly using formulas. How can we make a spreadsheet that converts a binary number to a decimal number? This lesson provides some guidance and Excel files for student and teacher use.
Page.LinkName: Opens Creating my own spreadsheet to convert binary to decimal

Page.Name: Design a flag with Pencil Code
Page.MetaTitle: Design a flag with Pencil Code
Page.MetaDescription: Design your own Australian flag by firstly examining common elements of flags, creating a step by step process (algorithm) to program your design after exploring a ‘block-based’ turtle drawing program such as Pencil Code.
Page.MainText: Design your own Australian flag by firstly examining common elements of flags, creating a step by step process (algorithm) to program your design after exploring a ‘block-based’ turtle drawing program such as Pencil Code.
Page.LinkName: Opens Design a flag with Pencil Code

Page.Name: Design a quiz - Convicts: crime and punishment
Page.MetaTitle: Design a quiz - Convicts: crime and punishment
Page.MetaDescription: Students design and create a simple game/quiz to demonstrate convict crimes and punishments.
Page.MainText: Students design and create a simple game/quiz to demonstrate convict crimes and punishments.
Page.LinkName: Opens Design a quiz - Convicts: crime and punishment

Page.Name: Fairytale fun
Page.MetaDescription: Use the slide sorter function to arrange a set of presentation slides in correct sequence to retell a fairytale.
Page.MainText: Use the slide sorter function to arrange a set of presentation slides in correct sequence to retell a fairytale.
Page.LinkName: Opens Fairytale fun

Page.Name: First to finish
Page.MetaDescription: Compare algorithms designed to complete the same task, and evaluate each for efficiency.
Page.MainText: Compare algorithms designed to complete the same task, and evaluate each for efficiency.
Page.LinkName: Opens First to finish

Page.Name: Have fun with flowcharts
Page.MetaDescription: Create a flowchart to represent a sequence of (branching) steps and decisions needed to solve a mathematical problem.
Page.MainText: Create a flowchart to represent a sequence of (branching) steps and decisions needed to solve a mathematical problem.
Page.LinkName: Opens Have fun with flowcharts

Page.Name: Home energy use
Page.MetaDescription: Reducing carbon dioxide emissions and sustainable energy use and are two of the major issues facing the world today.
Page.MainText: Reducing carbon dioxide emissions and sustainable energy use and are two of the major issues facing the world today. This project explores energy use in homes, and compares individual energy use with the class average and calculate and graph CO2 emissions.
Page.LinkName: Opens Home energy use

Page.Name: Learning to loop
Page.MetaDescription: Students create algorithms with a condition that tells the computer to repeat a sequence of instructions.
Page.MainText: Students create algorithms with a condition that tells the computer to repeat a sequence of instructions.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learning to loop

Page.Name: My digital portfolio
Page.MetaDescription: Students create their own website to record and present their learning.
Page.MainText: Students create their own website to record and present their learning. As part of the process students respectfully and constructively comment on each other’s webpage.
Page.LinkName: Opens My digital portfolio

Page.Name: Plan a 'choose your own adventure' story
Page.MetaTitle: Plan a 'choose your own adventure' story
Page.MetaDescription: Students create a storyboard to plan a ‘choose your own adventure' story, where the reader is provided with a number of decisions that lead to alternative endings.
Page.MainText: Students create a storyboard to plan a ‘choose your own adventure' story, where the reader is provided with a number of decisions that lead to alternative endings.
Page.LinkName: Opens Plan a 'choose your own adventure' story

Page.Name: Programming people
Page.MetaDescription: Play a variation of the game ‘Simon Says’ to develop understanding of sequencing and instructions in programming.
Page.MainText: Play a variation of the game ‘Simon Says’ to develop understanding of sequencing and instructions in programming.
Page.LinkName: Opens Programming people

Page.Name: Schoolyard biodiversity detectives
Page.MetaDescription: Collect data on the biodiversity in garden beds around your school to measure the biodiversity (that is the different types of plants and animals).
Page.MainText: Collect data on the biodiversity in garden beds around your school to measure the biodiversity (that is the different types of plants and animals). Explore ways to represent and present data. This lesson was devised by Linda McIver, Australian Data Science Education Institute.
Page.LinkName: Opens Schoolyard biodiversity detectives

Page.Name: Skip-counting with Bee-bots
Page.MetaDescription: Play a skip counting game where students program the Bee-Bot to stop at multiples of a set number, eg 2, 4, 5, 10 on a number grid.
Page.MainText: Play a skip counting game where students program the Bee-Bot to stop at multiples of a set number, eg 2, 4, 5, 10 on a number grid.
Page.LinkName: Opens Skip-counting with Bee-bots

Page.Name: Snap block models
Page.MetaDescription: Create a model using snap blocks 1 block high and create a code so someone else can build your model.
Page.MainText: Create a model using snap blocks 1 block high and create a code so someone else can build your model.
Page.LinkName: Opens Snap block models

Page.Name: Spelling bee
Page.MetaDescription: Write a set of instructions that program a Bee-Bot to move to letters to spell out a word on an alphabet grid.
Page.MainText: Write a set of instructions that program a Bee-Bot to move to letters to spell out a word on an alphabet grid.
Page.LinkName: Opens Spelling bee

Page.Name: Storm survivor: Input, decision-making and loops
Page.MetaTitle: Storm survivor: Input, decision-making and loops
Page.MetaDescription: Students use a visual programming language to create a game or quiz to help members of a community prepare for a severe weather event.
