Page.Name: When I post something online how permanent is it?
Page.MetaTitle: When I post something online how permanent is it?
Page.MetaDescription: Students engage in a photo rip up activity to emphasize the permanency of online information, they explore factor trees, doubling and line graphs through the lens of sharing information, and they collaboratively develop a set of protocols around sharing information online.
Page.MainText: Students engage in a photo rip up activity to emphasize the permanency of online information, they explore factor trees, doubling and line graphs through the lens of sharing information, and they collaboratively develop a set of protocols around sharing information online.
Page.LinkName: Opens When I post something online how permanent is it?

Page.Name: Solar energy installations
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson uses data about solar energy installations to investigate data analysis.
Page.MainText: This lesson uses data about solar energy installations to investigate data analysis. The dataset shows how many solar systems were installed, in each postcode, from 2001 to 2016. It is a useful way to understand how to explore and characterise datasets as well as to explore the use of data in the media. This lesson was devised by Linda McIver, Australian Data Science Education Institute.
Page.LinkName: Opens Solar energy installations

Page.Name: Automated soil moisture sensor
Page.MetaDescription: The soil moisture sensor project integrates science understandings and computational thinking to solve a problem about sustainable watering practices.
Page.MainText: The soil moisture sensor project integrates science understandings and computational thinking to solve a problem about sustainable watering practices. This lesson was devised by Trudy Ward, Clarendon Vale Primary School, Tasmania.
Page.LinkName: Opens Automated soil moisture sensor

Page.Name: Beeswax wrap project
Page.MetaDescription: This project creates opportunities for students to design, create, market and sell a plastic wrap alternative, and to work with a local business or community group that supplies some materials.
Page.MainText: This project creates opportunities for students to design, create, market and sell a plastic wrap alternative, and to work with a local business or community group that supplies some materials. This lesson was devised by Trudy Ward, Clarendon Vale Primary School, Tasmania.
Page.LinkName: Opens Beeswax wrap project

Page.Name: Data Science STEM resources
Page.MetaDescription: Here are some authentic datasets collected by research scientists studying marine and coastal animal populations.
Page.MainText: Here are some authentic datasets collected by research scientists studying marine and coastal animal populations. Use them to develop your students' data science skills as they analyse the data and use it to answer questions related to real-life management issues.
Page.LinkName: Opens Data Science STEM resources

Page.Name: Saltwater crocs: resourceful or a resource?
Page.MetaTitle: Saltwater crocs: resourceful or a resource?
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson focuses on the analysis of a dataset that records scientific data collected about the crocodile population in the Kimberley region during 2015.
Page.MainText: This lesson focuses on the analysis of a dataset that records scientific data collected about the crocodile population in the Kimberley region during 2015. The lesson follows an inquiry process where students use the dataset to answer relevant questions about the crocodile population. It also provides an opportunity for students to learn about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander histories and cultures, and sustainability.
Page.LinkName: Opens Saltwater crocs: resourceful or a resource?

Page.Name: Humpback whales: what the data reveals
Page.MetaTitle: Humpback whales: what the data reveals
Page.MetaDescription: The lesson follows an inquiry process where students use the dataset to answer relevant questions about the whale population.
Page.MainText: The lesson follows an inquiry process where students use the dataset to answer relevant questions about the whale population. They consider what other data they would need in order to effectively examine the impact on humpback whales of sonar activity and noise from development.
Page.LinkName: Opens Humpback whales: what the data reveals

Page.Name: Turtles: exploring data in turtle population dynamics
Page.MetaTitle: Turtles: exploring data in turtle population dynamics
Page.MetaDescription: The number of eggs a female turtle lays in her lifetime influences the health of that species population.
Page.MainText: The number of eggs a female turtle lays in her lifetime influences the health of that species population. In this lesson we look at modelling data related to the number of eggs a female turtle lays in her lifetime, using real scientific data. Explore ways to model, interpret, represent and present data, creating an infographic to raise awareness about turtle conservation.
Page.LinkName: Opens Turtles: Exploring data in turtle population dynamics

Page.Name: Turtles: exploring data tracking turtle movements
Page.MetaTitle: Turtles: exploring data tracking turtle movements
Page.MetaDescription: By gathering data on marine turtles, scientists have evidence that helps them work out where turtles migrate and the journeys they take.
Page.MainText: By gathering data on marine turtles, scientists have evidence that helps them work out where turtles migrate and the journeys they take. Scientists can then help to reduce the threats to the turtles’ survival. In this lesson we look at satellite tracking using real scientific data. Explore ways to model, interpret, represent and present data.
Page.LinkName: Opens Turtles: Exploring data tracking turtle movements

Page.Name: Turtles: impact of climate change on Flatback turtle populations
Page.MetaTitle: Turtles: impact of climate change on Flatback turtle populations
Page.MetaDescription: The lesson follows an inquiry process in which students use a dataset to answer relevant questions about the turtle population.
Page.MainText: The lesson follows an inquiry process in which students use a dataset to answer relevant questions about the turtle population. They consider how to analyse and display the data in order to effectively examine the impact of rising global temperatures on flatback turtle populations.
Page.LinkName: Opens Turtles: Impact of climate change on Flatback turtle populations

Page.Name: Protecting dugongs
Page.MetaDescription: The Western Australian Marine Science Institution has been collecting data about dugongs off the coast of the Kimberley in Northern WA.
Page.MainText: The Western Australian Marine Science Institution has been collecting data about dugongs off the coast of the Kimberley in Northern WA. We have been provided with the raw data from its sightings trips. In this project students will learn how dugong sightings are conducted, and develop the data-science skills needed to make the sightings data useful for analysis.
Page.LinkName: Opens Protecting dugongs

Page.Name: Pencil code program: Chaos game
Page.MetaDescription: The ‘chaos game’ is a way to see how patterns can result from certain random events.
Page.MainText: The ‘chaos game’ is a way to see how patterns can result from certain random events. Use this program to run the ‘chaos game’, randomly moving the turtle to create a pattern (for more information, search 'chaos game’). Have students analyze or fill in or change parts of the pencil code program.
Page.LinkName: Opens Pencil code program: Chaos game

Page.Name: Ciphering a sentence
Page.MetaDescription: A cipher is a message that has been written in such a way (encoded) that it is unreadable by others.
Page.MainText: A cipher is a message that has been written in such a way (encoded) that it is unreadable by others. In this lesson, students will use mapping to encode a sentence. Students will work with a partner to create an algorithm that describes the encryption process. They will also examine encoded and decoded messages to recognize patterns to help decode messages and develop strategies to decompose the problem.
Page.LinkName: Opens Ciphering a sentence

Page.Name: Describing an everyday object
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson, students act like the inventor of an everyday object that does not yet exist.
Page.MainText: In this lesson, students act like the inventor of an everyday object that does not yet exist. Students abstract the essential details, and describe what need would be fulfilled by the new object and how, specifically, it functions. They will then translate the description into a format appropriate for modeling the object in a computer by representing the data in an organized visual format.
Page.LinkName: Opens Describing an everyday object

Page.Name: Finding the shortest path
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson, students will experiment with different ways of creating a path between two points with algorithm design and generalizing patterns.
Page.MainText: In this lesson, students will experiment with different ways of creating a path between two points with algorithm design and generalizing patterns. From the patterns, they will be able to generate an algorithm for efficiently traveling through cities in a region.
Page.LinkName: Opens Finding the shortest path

Page.Name: Pencil code program: Lady MacBeth Chat Bot
Page.MetaTitle: Pencil code program: Lady MacBeth Chat Bot
Page.MetaDescription: Use this program to create an interactive chat bot who answers questions as if she is Lady Macbeth.
Page.MainText: Use this program to create an interactive chat bot who answers questions as if she is Lady Macbeth. Have students analyze, fill in or change parts of, or use the program to create their own variation and rendition of a character. This program could be used to further your understanding of how you could use Pencil Code in the classroom, as a demonstration or discussion with your students, or as a way to introduce various CT concepts, such as pattern recognition or abstraction, to your students by inviting them to extend the existing functionality of the program.
Page.LinkName: Opens Pencil code program: Lady MacBeth Chat Bot

Page.Name: Water Water everywhere!
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson, students are presented with the challenging problem of measuring a volume of water using containers that are not the exact measurement size.
Page.MainText: In this lesson, students are presented with the challenging problem of measuring a volume of water using containers that are not the exact measurement size. Students will decompose a complex problem into discrete steps, design an algorithm for solving the problem, and evaluate solution efficiencies and optimization in a simulation.
Page.LinkName: Opens Water Water everywhere!

Page.Name: COVID 19 Demystified course
Page.MetaDescription: At the end of this course, learners should be able to better understand the science and numbers behindCOVID-19 and the SARS-CoV-2 virus that causes it.
Page.MainText: At the end of this course, learners should be able to better understand the science and numbers behindCOVID-19 and the SARS-CoV-2 virus that causes it. They should be able to discuss the pandemic with confidence, giving substantiated viewpoints on matters such as public policy with a willingness to accept other viewpoints. They should also understand why governments in different countries make the decisions that they have made.
Page.LinkName: Opens COVID 19 Demystified course

Page.Name: AR Solar System with Metaverse
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson, students explore our Solar System in Augmented Reality (AR).
Page.MainText: In this lesson, students explore our Solar System in Augmented Reality (AR). Students start by exploring a set of AR flashcards that present the Sun and Planets in our Solar System and then go on to use the Metaverse App to create their own AR solar system experience based on research.
Page.LinkName: Opens AR Solar System with Metaverse

Page.Name: Human Anatomy with Virtuali-tee
Page.MetaDescription: In this learning activity, students explore human organ systems using Virtuali-tee.
Page.MainText: In this learning activity, students explore human organ systems using Virtuali-tee. This t-shirt provides an Augmented Reality (AR) experience and deeper 360 degrees Virtual Reality (VR) experience to explore human anatomy.
Page.LinkName: Opens Human Anatomy with Virtuali-tee

Page.Name: Augmented Reality Timelapse Artwork with Artivive
Page.MetaTitle: Augmented Reality Timelapse Artwork with Artivive
Page.MetaDescription: In this project, students build their own augmented reality (AR) artwork using free digital tools with Artivive.
Page.MainText: In this project, students build their own augmented reality (AR) artwork using free digital tools with Artivive. Students can augment an existing artwork or design their own. This new technology allows artists to create new dimensions of art by linking classical with digital art.
Page.LinkName: Opens Augmented Reality Timelapse Artwork with Artivive

Page.Name: Exploring AR Space Rocks
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson, students undertake a research project about “space rocks”.
Page.MainText: In this lesson, students undertake a research project about “space rocks”. They devise a research question to investigate something they would like to know about space rocks and communicate their ideas within an AR or Virtual Reality (VR) experience.
Page.LinkName: Opens Exploring AR Space Rocks

Page.MetaTitle: Creating a Space AR poster using Unity
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson, students explore how to design and implement a simple Augmented Reality (AR) poster experience using Unity 3D and Vuforia SDK for Unity 3D.
Page.MainText: In this lesson, students explore how to design and implement a simple Augmented Reality (AR) poster experience using Unity 3D and Vuforia SDK for Unity 3D. This lesson is within the context of a Space-themed example, however, it could be used for other contexts such as Biology, Geography, Art or more.

Page.MetaTitle: Creating a Biology AR poster using Unity

Page.Name: Design Thinking Process - Empathising
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson students understand design thinking as a process for solving problems creatively.
Page.MainText: In this lesson students understand design thinking as a process for solving problems creatively. Students explore the design thinking process of empathising and seek to understand more about the users and the problem they are trying to solve. This particular lesson explores reducing litter through the design brief although the activities can be used to empathise with any design.
Page.LinkName: Opens Design Thinking Process - Empathising

Page.Name: Design Thinking Process - Ideation
Page.MetaDescription: Students explore the design thinking process of ideation and reflect on different ways we can generate ideas in order to solve a problem with a design brief.
Page.MainText: Students explore the design thinking process of ideation and reflect on different ways we can generate ideas in order to solve a problem with a design brief. This particular lesson explores healthy eating through the design brief although the activities can be used to ideate any design.
Page.LinkName: Opens Design Thinking Process - Ideation

Page.MainText: This sequence of lessons integrates game design using scratch and a Makey Makey programming board.

Page.Name: Learning environments
Page.MetaDescription: This sequence of lessons explores how conditions in the environment can impact on learning.
Page.MainText: This sequence of lessons explores how conditions in the environment can impact on learning. Through investigating the environmental influences on our classroom, and learning environments such as light, noise and temperature, students collect data and identify the optimal learning environment.

Page.Name: What makes a good game?

Page.MainText: This lesson sequence allows students to explore design thinking processes to investigate how games are designed, created and played. Students analyse the audience of games, understanding the importance of empathy in the design process. The learning sequence culminates in a showcase: students sharing the games they have designed with the school community.

Page.MainText: Their findings have shown an increase in student engagement, differentiation of student learning, self-directed learning, deep learning, and a fostering of creativity, collaboration, communication, critical thinking, coding and computational thinking.

Page.Name: Digital Technologies: Integrating across the curriculum

Page.MetaDescription: At Christ the King Primary School the Digital Technologies Curriculum is integrated across all learning areas.
Page.MainText: Students learn through a combination of opportunities for self discovery, as well as lessons which incorporate explicit teaching. Through the learning experiences provided, students build their knowledge through collaboration, sharing of ideas and use of explicit vocabulary related to ‘real world’ and purposeful tasks.

Page.Name: Engaging in Digital Technologies through Geocaching
Page.MetaTitle: Engaging in Digital Technologies through Geocaching
Page.MetaDescription: Geocaching has been around since 2000, but you may not have heard of it as it is a secret game.
Page.MainText: Geocaching is an outdoor recreational activity, in which participants use a global positioning system (GPS) receiver or mobile device and other navigational techniques to hide and seek containers, called “geocaches” or “caches”, anywhere in the world.
Page.Copyright: © 2013-2021 QSITE. May be subject to statutory licence fee.

Page.Name: Computational thinking in a creative learning environment
Page.MetaTitle: Computational thinking in a creative learning environment
Page.MetaDescription: At this small NSW school the teachers at the school embarked on a project focusing on student engagement.
Page.MainText: Green Hill Public School is a very small government school located in Kempsey, New South Wales on the Traditional Lands of the Djangadi/Dhangatti Peoples. It has recently expanded from a K–4 to a K–6 school. It has 28 students, 96 per cent of whom identify as Aboriginal and or Torres Strait Islander. Green Hill Public School was a finalist in the 2018 Australian Education Awards in the Primary School of the Year – Government category. Sarah Atkins is the curriculum officer who works with the school to support implementation of the Australian Curriculum: Digital Technologies, through the NSW Science and Technology syllabus
Page.LinkName: Opens Computational thinking in a creative learning environment in a new window

Page.Name: Impact of STEM culture
Page.MetaDescription: Casula High School shares how STEM promotes student-centred learning and collaboration.
Page.MainText: The aim of this STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) program is to arm our students with the skills they need to enter a workforce where 75% of the fastest growing occupations require STEM skills. STEM education at Casula High School is not just about the deep understanding of STEM, but also about related skills such as problem solving, collaboration, critical thinking and creativity.

Page.Name: Scratch Creative Computing Guide
Page.MetaDescription: The Scratch Creative Computing Guide includes a teacher guide and learner workbook.
Page.MainText: There is also a series of units comprising learning activities, paired with assessment activities and templates that can be used to support use of the Scratch (MIT) platform. The Scratch Creative Computing Guide supports assessment activities with visual programming environments.
Page.LinkName: Opens Scratch Creative Computing Guide

Page.Name: Coding with Scratch Junior
Page.MetaDescription: Students create a simple touch game using Scratch Junior about animals that live on a farm.
Page.MainText: Students create a simple touch game using Scratch Junior about animals that live on a farm.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Coding With Scratch Junior

Page.Name: Creating a visual guide to packing the school bag
Page.MetaTitle: Creating a visual guide to packing the school bag
Page.MetaDescription: Students will capture photos using a peripheral device, e.g. camera, of the items that go into their school bag each day.
Page.MainText: Students will capture photos using a peripheral device, e.g. camera, of the items that go into their school bag each day.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Packing The School Bag 2

Page.Name: Creating a digital system
Page.MetaDescription: After discovering a digital system of interest, create a model of the chosen device that can be used during role-play situations at home.
Page.MainText: After discovering a digital system of interest, create a model of the chosen device that can be used during role-play situations at home.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Digital System Model

Page.Name: Seasonal walk
Page.MetaDescription: Children take a walk around their local area to collect some data about the animals and plants they can find during one of the four seasons.
Page.MainText: Children take a walk around their local area to collect some data about the animals and plants they can find during one of the four seasons.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Seasonal Walk (1)

Page.Name: DT laundry
Page.MetaDescription: Did you know many of your items of clothing need to be washed in different ways?
Page.MainText: Did you know many of your items of clothing need to be washed in different ways?
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together DT Laundry2

Page.Name: Robot dance
Page.MetaDescription: Children create a dance routine based on a set of robot movements.
Page.MainText: They then share their dance instructions with a classmate / family member to see if that dance routine can be easily followed.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Robot Dance1

Page.Name: Is it a pig or a dog?
Page.MetaTitle: Is it a pig or a dog?
Page.MetaDescription: By drawing animals in different circumstances to represent different ideas, students learn about abstraction and data representation.
Page.MainText: This activity suits two siblings working together.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Is It Pig Or Dog1

Page.Name: We're going on a computer hunt
Page.MetaTitle: We're going on a computer hunt
Page.MetaDescription: In this activity students explore digital systems around them and consider the components that make those systems, and what the purpose of the system is.
Page.MainText: In this activity students explore digital systems around them and consider the components that make those systems, and what the purpose of the system is.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together We're Going On A Computer Hunt1

Page.Name: Scratch Parent Guide
Page.MetaDescription: In this activity you will make an animated card using the Scratch programming blocks.
Page.MainText: You will use three functions: selecting a background, make the character (sprite) say something, and moving the sprite.
Page.LinkName: Opens Scratch Parent Guide in a new window

Page.Name: Flow chart
Page.MetaDescription: Your child will describe the sequence of steps and decisions needed to successfully play a simple card game such as Snap.
Page.MainText: Your child will describe the sequence of steps and decisions needed to successfully play a simple card game such as Snap.

Page.Name: Peripherals family task
Page.MetaDescription: This activity is designed for you and your child to explore some commonly used peripheral devices around your home.
Page.MainText: This activity is designed for you and your child to explore some commonly used peripheral devices around your home.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Peripherals (1)

Page.Name: Semaphore system
Page.MetaDescription: Students learn to spell different words using the semaphore system with flags and movement.
Page.MainText: Children can get other members of the family to guess the word they have spelled.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Semaphore System

Page.Name: Information systems changes
Page.MetaDescription: Interview grandparents and parents to find out the different types of information systems available when they were growing up and contrast these to the information systems we have today.
Page.MainText: Interview grandparents and parents to find out the different types of information systems available when they were growing up and contrast these to the information systems we have today.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Information Systems Changes1

Page.Name: Tech Talk Find a Word
Page.MetaDescription: Find all the technology words on the sheet and in your house!
Page.MainText: Find all the technology words on the sheet and in your house!
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Tech Talk Find A Word1

Page.Name: Race up If Mountain
Page.MetaDescription: This activity is designed to teach decision making in programming as well as starting to teach students about variables.
Page.MainText: The game is based on a path up a mountain blocked with a number of smaller ‘if mountains’ that must be passed to reach the finish.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Race Up Mountain2

Page.Name: Setting the rules
Page.MetaDescription: This activity will help you identify and discuss some of the issues that may occur when using technology and communicating online.
Page.MainText: This activity will help you identify and discuss some of the issues that may occur when using technology and communicating online.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Setting The Rules1

Page.Name: Connectivity at home
Page.MetaDescription: As a family you can investigate different forms of connectivity and discover which types can be paired with the digital systems you own.
Page.MainText: As a family you can investigate different forms of connectivity and discover which types can be paired with the digital systems you own.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Connectivity At Home1

Page.Name: Creating a holiday blog
Page.MetaDescription: Together, you will create a blog to document the activities the children participate in or places they visit during their break.
Page.MainText: This is a collaborative activity for you and your children.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Creating A Holiday Blog

Page.Name: Binary memory game
Page.MetaDescription: In this activity you will play the game of Memory, collecting cards when you match a binary and decimal number.
Page.MainText: In this activity you will play the game of Memory, collecting cards when you match a binary and decimal number.

Page.Name: Search and we will find
Page.MetaDescription: Students learn about the power of advanced search options to help narrow results when looking for resources.
Page.MainText: Students learn about the power of advanced search options to help narrow results when looking for resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Search And We Will Find

Page.Name: Cracking a code
Page.MetaDescription: Play a game with a partner where you guess a 3 digit code.
Page.MainText: Change the game to create codes using favourite superheroes, foods or music. Take your new skills and learn how to create passwords with superpowers.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Cracking A Code1

Page.Name: number guessing with Algorithms
Page.MetaDescription: Play a number guessing game, then think about the best way to play the game to win.
Page.MainText: Create a set of instructions anyone can follow to guess a number in the fewest number of guesses. Create an algorithm and use it in a harder version of the game.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Number Guessing

Page.Name: Maze escape
Page.MetaDescription: Create an algorithm, or set of instructions, to navigate through a maze.
Page.MainText: Choose from a finite set of commands, and create the best instructions you can to get through the maze with the fewest number of instructions.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Maze Escape1

Page.Name: Spaceship rescue
Page.MetaDescription: Find the missing spaceships and save the astronauts.
Page.MainText: NASA has lost 4 spaceships in deep space. Probes have been deployed to gather data. Your job is to triangulate the data to find the missing spaceships and save the astronauts. Are you up for the challenge?
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Spaceship Rescue2

Page.Name: Wombot Carrot Hunt
Page.MetaDescription: In this activity students use logic and follow an algorithm to find missing carrots on a grid.
Page.MainText: In this activity students use logic and follow an algorithm to find missing carrots on a grid.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Wombot Carrot Hunt

Page.Name: Basic coding course: Beginners
Page.MetaDescription: This lesson sequence provides a bridge between visual coding (eg. Scratch) and General Purpose Programming languages (eg. Python or JavaScript).
Page.MainText: This lesson sequence provides a bridge between visual coding (eg. Scratch) and General Purpose Programming languages (eg. Python or JavaScript).
Page.LinkName: Opens Visual to text coding course

Page.Name: Coding course Chatbots: Intermediate
Page.MetaDescription: Teachers and students are led through the coding in Python of a chatbot, a conversational program capable of responding in varied ways to user input, including with the use of smart sentiment analysis.
Page.MainText: Teachers and students are led through the coding in Python of a chatbot, a conversational program capable of responding in varied ways to user input, including with the use of smart sentiment analysis.
Page.LinkName: Opens Coding a sentimental chatbot in Python

Page.Name: Unscrambling a secret message
Page.MetaDescription: Unscramble a hidden message by figuring out missing letters in common words.
Page.MainText: This activity uses a a substitution cipher, and students can go on to create their own hidden messages. Substitution ciphers are an example of encryption, which is used when data needs to be sent securely.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Unscrambling A Secret Message

Page.Name: Card switches
Page.MetaDescription: In this challenge students are taught the steps in volved in Bubble sort algorithms by comparing and switching unsorted cards.
Page.MainText: They then use that method to classify how scrambled different card sequences are from their sorted form.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Card Switches2

Page.Name: Tech collect
Page.MetaDescription: A fun find-a-word activity to improve students awareness of Digital Systems and their roles in a wider technology context.
Page.MainText: A fun find-a-word activity to improve students awareness of Digital Systems and their roles in a wider technology context.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Tech Collect1

Page.Name: Scavenger hunt
Page.MetaDescription: In this activity, students solve seven puzzles to navigate their way around the house to find a hidden treasure.
Page.MainText: Puzzles are solved by applying a range of data representation, binary number, pixel graphic, morse code and simple cryptography skills.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Scavenger Hunt2

Page.Name: Convenient stores
Page.MetaDescription: In this activity, students learn about Voroni algorithms and how they are used to determine with certainty the shortest distance to key locations on a map.
Page.MainText: In this activity, students learn about Voroni algorithms and how they are used to determine with certainty the shortest distance to key locations on a map.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Convenient Stores

Page.Name: TV Torment
Page.MetaDescription: Students will consider how different people use their TVs, and how the remote control for TVs either helps or hinders them.
Page.MainText: They'll be guided through the process of coming up with a better design, and some of the things you think about when designing enjoyable user experiences.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together TV Torment

Page.Name: Cellular automoji
Page.MetaDescription: Students apply an algorithm, described by a simple set of rules, to create a self replicating emoji patterns across a grid.
Page.MainText: Students apply an algorithm, described by a simple set of rules, to create a self replicating emoji patterns across a grid.
Page.LinkName: Opens Learn Together Cellular Automoji1

Page.Name: Checklist guide
Page.MetaDescription: This guide desribes how to use checklists to record information and to make judgements about what students know and can do in relation to the targeted Digital Technology outcomes.
Page.MainText: This guide describes ways a checklist can provide an organised way of collecting data about behaviours, knowledge and skills that students demonstrate during a task.
Page.LinkName: Opens Guides And Templates Checklists Guide (1)

Page.Name: Checklist template
Page.MetaDescription: This template can be used for Digital Technologies related tasks that use a checklist to record student progress.
Page.MainText: Focus on the demonstrated knowledge/skills that relate to the elements of the achievement standard.
Page.LinkName: Opens Guides And Templates Checklists Template

Page.Name: Checklist example
Page.MetaDescription: This checklist template example is focused on a task where students collect, explore and sort data about themselves and their classmates using a range of themes.
Page.MainText: Students collect, explore and sort data about themselves and their classmates using a range of themes. A glyph is a pictorial representation of data, in this case, to be presented as a digital artwork
Page.LinkName: Opens Guides And Templates Checklist Example

Page.Name: Think aloud guide
Page.MetaDescription: This guide explains the process of a teacher sitting alongside a student and conducting an interview (think aloud).
Page.MainText: Students are provided the opportunity to demonstrate and explain their work or a particular task. Teachers ask questions that elicit understandings about students’ content knowledge and skills
Page.LinkName: Opens Guides And Templates Think Aloud Guide

Page.MetaDescription: This template can be used for Digital Technologies related tasks when recording notes on a student think aloud.
Page.MainText: This template can be used for Digital Technologies related tasks when recording notes on a student think aloud.
Page.LinkName: Opens Guides And Templates Think Aloud Template

Page.MetaDescription: This assessment resource is a Think-Aloud, in which the teacher interviews the student about their design (including documents) and their implementation of a program.

Page.Name: School implementation​
Page.MetaDescription: Guidance and support to develop and implement a whole-school plan.

Page.LinkName: Opens School Implementation

Page.Name: State and territory curriculum
Page.MetaDescription: Use this information to check what your state Department of Education or Sector Department is prescribing and/or mandating in terms of the implementation of the Digital Technologies Curriculum.
Page.MainText: It is important to know what your jurisdiction or sector has as requirements when implementing the Digital Technologies curriculum. Use this information to check what your state Department of Education or Sector Department is prescribing and/or mandating in terms of the implementation of the Digital Technologies Curriculum.

Page.Name: Engage with the curriculum
Page.MetaDescription: Use these resources to help your leadership team to fully engage with the Digital Technologies curriculum to gain an insight into its intent, structure and content.
Page.MainText: Use these resources to help your leadership team to fully engage with the Digital Technologies curriculum to gain an insight into its intent, structure and content.

Page.Name: Align with school vision
Page.MetaDescription: Review your school’s current vision, mission and aims. Consider creating a vision that supports a future oriented perspective with students as creative, empowered learners.
Page.MainText: Typically a school’s vision, mission and aims capture the essence of the school community’s beliefs about student learning, often acknowledging that we are living in a changing world. Review your school’s current vision, mission and aims. Consider creating a vision that supports a future oriented perspective with students as creative, empowered learners.
Page.LinkName: Opens Align with school vision

Page.Name: Technologies in the classroom​
Page.MetaDescription: A broad overview of popular classroom technologies in schools, grouping the technologies into categories for ease of locating tech of interest.
Page.MainText: A broad overview of popular classroom technologies in schools, grouping the technologies into categories for ease of locating tech of interest.
Page.LinkName: Opens Technologies in the classroom

Page.Name: Programmable robots and drones
Page.MetaDescription: Programmable robots can be used to explore algorithms and implement programs to complete a desired outcome. Progammable robots allow students to use and design more complex algorithms and implement more sophisticated programs that incorporate decisions and repetition. Students draw on computational thinking to solve problems and challenges.
Page.MainText: Programmable robots can be used to explore algorithms and implement programs to complete a desired outcome. Progammable robots allow students to use and design more complex algorithms and implement more sophisticated programs that incorporate decisions and repetition. Students draw on computational thinking to solve problems and challenges.
Page.LinkName: Opens Programmable robots and drones

Page.Name: Buildable robots and kits
Page.MetaDescription: Buildable robots frequently provide an opportunity for students to explore systems, and draw on systems thinking, as they design a robotic solution that incorporates outputs, sensors, on-board microcontroller, actuators, gears and other moving parts.
Page.MainText: Buildable robots frequently provide an opportunity for students to explore systems, and draw on systems thinking, as they design a robotic solution that incorporates outputs, sensors, on-board microcontroller, actuators, gears and other moving parts.
Page.LinkName: Opens Buildable robots and kits

Page.Name: Electronic kits and programming boards
Page.MetaDescription: Discover how different invention kits and electronic programming boards can be used by students to create digital solutions for a range of problems.
Page.MainText: Discover how different invention kits and electronic programming boards can be used by students to create digital solutions for a range of problems.

Page.Name: Programming platforms
Page.MetaDescription: Learn more about programming platforms and the two groups they can be categorised into: visual programming environments and general-purpose programming languages.
Page.MainText: Learn more about programming platforms and the two groups they can be categorised into: visual programming environments and general-purpose programming languages.
Page.LinkName: Opens Programming platforms

Page.Name: AR/VR and emerging technologies
Page.MetaDescription: Find out more about Virtual reality (VR) a 3D computer-generated environment and Augmented reality (AR) which enables computer-generated information and virtual objects to be overlayed on physical object in real time.
Page.MainText: Find out more about Virtual reality (VR) a 3D computer-generated environment and Augmented reality (AR) which enables computer-generated information and virtual objects to be overlayed on physical object in real time.

Page.MetaDescription: Information and support organised in broad categories of disability: physical, cognitive, sensory, and social/emotional.

These resources supports schools to provide learning opportunities that are accessible to every student. Design lessons that consider differences in the ways that students think and engage with content.

Page.Name: Inclusive education principles​
Page.MetaDescription: Inclusive education is making sure that education is accessible to every student.
Page.MainText: It is important for educators to design lessons that consider differences in the ways that students think and engage with content. Universal Design for Learning (UDL) is one such approach to adjusting lessons.
Page.LinkName: Opens ​Inclusive education principles

Page.Name: Disability categories
Page.MetaDescription: The Nationally Consistent Collection of Data on School Students with Disability (NCCD) identifies four broad categories of disability: physical, cognitive, sensory, and social/emotional.
Page.MainText: The Nationally Consistent Collection of Data on School Students with Disability (NCCD) identifies four broad categories of disability: physical, cognitive, sensory, and social/emotional. A student may need adjustments in multiple categories.

Page.Name: Inclusive education and DT: infographic
Page.MetaDescription: A summary of the approaches to inclusive education displayed as an infographic.
Page.MainText: Inclusive education is education that is accessible to every student, including students with additional educational needs. It is important for educators to design lessons that reflect differences in the ways that students think and engage with content. This infographic describes some relevant approaches with examples.
Page.LinkName: Inc Ed Infographic

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Database
Page.MetaDescription: Use these unplugged activities to introduce the idea of database queries.
Page.MainText: Download Databases Unplugged which details a series of computing lessons designed to relate fundamental concepts of database use and design to students in primary and secondary schooling. The unplugged activities culminate in a ‘plugged in’ task based on a several murder mysteries.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Database in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Divide and Conquer
Page.MetaDescription: Use these activities with your students to explore how a computer uses an algorithm to search.
Page.MainText: Use Santa’s Dirty Socks book or video to explore the problem of finding a hidden item in one of 1024 items. This problem uses the strategy, divide and conquer; half of the items can be eliminated each time, making the task faster and easier to complete. Relate the task to the way a computer searches. Support your teaching and learning with video clips and other related resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Divide and Conquer in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Artificial Intelligence
Page.MetaDescription: Use these activities with your students to explore how a computer follows a set of instructions.
Page.MainText: Use the The Intelligent Piece of Paper offline activity to explore the idea of computer intelligence. Through the activity students will realise that the program the computer follows is the intelligent part (which is created by a computer programmer!). Support your teaching and learning with video clips and other related resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Artificial Intelligence in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Image Representation - Colour by Numbers
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Image Representation - Colour by Numbers
Page.MetaDescription: Use these activities with your students to explore how to computers store and transmit data to create a black and white image.
Page.MainText: Use the Colour by Numbers offline activity to explore how a B&W image is made up of pixels, shown as black or white dots which are represented by either a 1 or 0. Using a 0 or 1 to represent a white or black square students create an image on a grid. They supply the coded message for someone else to recreate. Support your teaching and learning with video clips and other related resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Image Representation - Colour by Numbers in a new window

Page.Name: Web Literacy Basics
Page.MetaDescription: This six-part module helps students get familiar with reading, writing and participating on the web.
Page.MainText: This module cover three areas of web literacy including reading for the web, writing for the web and participating on the web. In reading for the web they assess the credibility of a web resource and learn how the web works. In writing for the web they explore remixing and learn about composing for the web. In participating on the web they explore open content and create an online community task to inspire action.
Page.LinkName: Opens Web Literacy Basics in a new window

Page.Name: Privacy Basics: Passwords, Tracking, and Data Retention
Page.MetaTitle: Privacy Basics: Passwords, Tracking, and Data Retention
Page.MetaDescription: Learn how to safeguard your privacy online and develop an awareness of how companies and governments track and collect your data online.
Page.MainText: This module cover three areas of privacy including passwords, basic privacy issues and data retention. Students learn about web mechanics, security, and privacy as they analyse and reflect on common surveillance practices, as well as their own privacy habits.
Page.LinkName: Opens Privacy Basics: Passwords, Tracking, and Data Retention in a new window

Page.Name: Privacy Basics: Online Tracking | Privacy
Page.MetaDescription: Lessons to help students create secure passwords, monitor their online privacy and security, protect their data, and identify online trackers using web literacy skills like evaluate, navigate, open practice, and protect.
Page.MainText: These activities will help your learners understand how to take control of their privacy in a networked world. Learn web literacy skills like evaluate, navigate, open practice, and protect to safeguard your data and identity online.
Page.LinkName: Opens Privacy Basics: Online Tracking | Privacy in a new window

Page.Name: Webmaker App
Page.MetaTitle: Read, Write, and Participate with Webmaker
Page.MetaDescription: Learn how to set up your mobile device to write, publish, and share stories with the Webmaker App from Mozilla Learning Networks.
Page.MainText: Webmaker was Mozilla Foundation’s Android app for creating original content on the mobile web. It allowed users to build pages with unique URLs — and learn the basics of content creation along the way.
Page.LinkName: Opens Webmaker App in a new window

Page.Name: Computing at School: Resources
Page.MetaDescription: Browse the curriculum resources which are tried and classroom tested resources submitted by primary teachers to support Computing for early to middle primary school.
Page.MainText: Browse the curriculum resources which are tried and classroom tested resources submitted by primary teachers to support Computing for early to middle primary school. Topics include: Algorithms, Computer networks, Using search technologies, Using technology purposefully.
Page.LinkName: Opens Computing at School: Resources in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Searching Algorithms
Page.MetaDescription: Learn about Searching Algorithms using Battleships a downloadable offline activity.
Page.MainText: Use the activity with your students to explore how computers are often required to find information in large collections of data. To do this the computer needs quick and efficient ways of doing this. This activity demonstrates three different search methods: linear searching, binary searching and hashing. Support your teaching and learning with the video clips and other related resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Searching Algorithms in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Binary numbers
Page.MetaDescription: Learn about binary numbers using Count the dots, and other downloadable offline activities.
Page.MainText: Use these activities with your students to explore how to computers use just two symbols zero and one to represent information. Support your teaching and learning with video clips and other related resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Binary numbers in a new window

Page.Name: Digital Directions
Page.MetaDescription: A series of brief videos made in Tasmania exploring the advantages of using Digital Technologies for various industries/businesses.
Page.MainText: Business owners share their insights into using Digital Technologies such as Google Hangouts, Google Analytics, Mobile Apps, WiFi, approaches to online marketing and use of social media such as Facebook, Twiiter and Instagram. The videos provide real examples of contexts in which Digital Technologies are used.
Page.LinkName: Opens Digital Directions in a new window

Page.Name: The Office of the eSafety Commissioner: Parent resources
Page.MetaTitle: The Office of the eSafety Commissioner: Parent resources
Page.MetaDescription: Online safety resources for parents and carers.
Page.MainText: A one stop shop to address your concerns about your child's eSafety. View instructional videos covering basic online concepts. Check out the Q&A section about cyberbullying, inappropriate content and screen time. Materials are informative and presented jargon free using a contemporary approach.
Page.Copyright: Commonwealth of Australia. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens The Office of the eSafety Commissioner: Parent resources in a new window

Page.Name: eSafety Commissioner: Video and resource library
Page.MetaTitle: eSafety Commissioner: Video and resource library
Page.MetaDescription: Online safety resources for secondary schools supported by lesson plans and mulitimedia resources. Use the filters to find tailored resources suitable for your classroom needs.
Page.MainText: Organised into lower, middle and upper secondary, these resources can be used to explore issues around online safety, cyberbullying and screen time. Use the resources including the multimedia games to explore appropriate online behaviours and digital citizenship.
Page.Copyright: Commonwealth of Australia. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 2.5 AU
Page.LinkName: Opens eSafety Commissioner: Video and resource library in a new window

Page.Name: Alice
Page.MetaDescription: Alice is a FREE 3D programming environment that makes it easy to create an animation for storytelling, playing an interactive game, or a video to share on the web.
Page.MainText: This website provides tools and materials for teaching and learning computational thinking, problem solving, and computer programming across secondary year levels. Students drag and drop graphic tiles to create a program, where the instructions correspond to standard statements in a production oriented programming language, such as Java, C++, and C#.
Page.LinkName: Opens Alice in a new window

Page.Name: Intro to Algorithms
Page.MetaDescription: Learn with a combination of articles, visualizations, quizzes, and coding challenges.
Page.MainText: Use this website to develop your understanding of algorithms, including searching, sorting, recursion, and graph theory. Learn with a combination of articles, visualizations, quizzes, and coding challenges.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Khan Academy. Content (excluding videos) Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0; Videos Creative Commons BY 3.0
Page.LinkName: Opens Intro to Algorithms in a new window

Page.Name: Agent Cubes
Page.MetaDescription: A programming tool for teaching Computing Science through creating 2D and 3D games.
Page.MainText: AgentCubes is a 2-D and 3-D programming tool for teaching students computing science and computing skills through games design. The associated curriculum is based on constructivist learning theories that involve students in hands-on activities designed to promote mastery of computing fundamentals. AgentCubes is designed to appeal to a diverse range of students.
Page.Copyright: National Center for Women and Information Technology 2014. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Agent Cubes in a new window

Page.Name: Codecademy
Page.MetaDescription: This site provides tutorials on web design tools.
Page.MainText: Codecademy is an online interactive site featuring tutorials on a range of computer languages including Javascript, CSS, HTML, PHP, SQL, JQuery, Java and Python. It has a smooth and intuitive interface which allows short coding exercises to be submitted and auto-marked instantly. Progression is clearly tracked and retained. It also provides other in-depth articles on selected topics.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Codecademy. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Codecademy in a new window

Page.Name: Coding bat
Page.MetaDescription: This site provides a range of exercises to practice coding and to build coding confidence in Java and Python.
Page.MainText: CodingBat is a free site of live coding problems for students to build their skills in Java and Python. CodingBat emphasises building and practicing small code problems as a means of developing these skills. Students can select particular areas of coding on which to concentrate. An interactive interface is provided and CodingBat has a basic authoring feature where anyone can write his or her own problems.
Page.LinkName: Opens Coding bat in a new window

Page.Name: Computer Science For Fun (CS4FN)
Page.MetaDescription: View articles about computational thinking and computing science.
Page.MainText: CS4FN produces a free magazine twice a year as well as a series of special booklets on diverse subjects including magic, Electronic Engineering and Audio Engineering emphasising their links with computing. The site contains over 1000 articles on many CS related topics. Browse by date or topic.
Page.Copyright: Queen Mary, University of London 2005-2011. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Computer Science For Fun (CS4FN) in a new window

Page.Name: Hackety Hack
Page.MetaDescription: Hackety Hack teaches basic programming using the Ruby programming language.
Page.MainText: Hackety Hack teaches the basics of programming from the ground up using the Ruby programming language. No previous programming experience is needed! Hackety Hack uses the Shoes toolkit to build very simple graphical interfaces. Several lessons and example programs are provided. The Programs section provides projects from other Hackety users and users can upload their own. Support via FAQ and online queries after joining are promised.
Page.Copyright: Hackety Hack. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Hackety Hack in a new window

Page.Name: Khan Academy: Computer programming
Page.MetaDescription: Learn how to program using JavaScript and Processing JS, SQL, or how to create webpages with HTML CSS.
Page.MainText: Khan Academy offers interactive online practice exercises and instructional videos for a variety of coding languages, allowing learners to study at their own pace in or outside the classroom. It also provides material for computer science, networking and cryptography.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Khan Academy. Some material is Creative Commons. Otherwise, may be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Khan Academy: Computer programming in a new window

Page.Name: Macquarie ICT Innovations Centre (MacICT)
Page.MetaDescription: MacICT provides professional learning for teachers, bootcamps for students and schools and conducts research on the integration of Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) in teaching and learning.
Page.MainText: MacICT is a collaboration between the NSW Department of Education and Macquarie University, Sydney. MacICT provides professional learning for teachers, students and schools and conducts research on the meaningful integration of Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) in teaching and learning. Courses include Coding, Robotics, Physical Computing, Augmented Reality, 3D printing, Game Design, Technology in Maths, Technology in Science, Multimodal texts, Storytelling, Creative video making and more.
Page.Copyright: 2015 Macquarie ICT Innovations Centre. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Macquarie ICT Innovations Centre (MacICT) in a new window

Page.Name: Code Club Australia
Page.MetaDescription: Code Club Australia provides project materials and student friendly step-by-step tutorials aligned with the Australian Digital Technologies Curriculum. This site allows teachers and club leaders to connect with a volunteering network that supports the running of in-school and after-school coding courses.
Page.MainText: Over 2000 Code Clubs exist across Australia. Code Club creates projects for teachers and volunteers to teach their students the fundamentals of coding and digital technologies. The projects teach children how to program by allowing them to make computer games, animations and websites in a variety of technologies designed for kids age 8-15. A teacher can run their own Code Club by simply using these projects in their classroom. Alternatively, volunteers can team up with their local school or public venue for an hour a week as an after-school activity.
Page.Copyright: Code Club Australia. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Code Club Australia in a new window

Page.Name: Codespark
Page.MetaDescription: Try some of the 2019 Hour of Code activities. Start learning to code with any of 3 activities. Perfect for beginners with no coding experience and intermediate coders.
Page.MainText: Try some of the 2019 Hour of Code activities. Start learning to code with any of 3 activities. Perfect for beginners with no coding experience and intermediate coders.
Page.LinkName: Opens Codespark in a new window

Page.Name: Cool Tools to Help Kids Learn to Code
Page.MetaTitle: Cool Tools to Help Kids Learn to Code
Page.MetaDescription: Here are some suggested apps that encourage children to code and become creators, not just consumers, of the technology they use.
Page.MainText: This list of apps are organised into those suitable for young children (5-8 year olds) and those for older children 10+. Each suggested app has a link and a brief description. Note some suggested apps have a cost associated with them for purchase.
Page.Copyright: Common Sense Media Inc. 2016. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Cool Tools to Help Kids Learn to Code in a new window

Page.Name: Wonder Workshop
Page.MetaDescription: A collection of interactive activity ideas for the Dash and Dot robot toys for young computer programming learners.
Page.MainText: This site contains ‘Ideas’ of activities for early learners based on the Dot and Dash robot toys and related downloadable apps including Blockly and Xylo. Activities are chosen from visual tiles sorted by category and can be filtered by difficulty, robot, app and accessory. Each activity contains a list of requirements and simple steps, as well as educational information relevant to computing curriculum.
Page.Copyright: Wonder Workshop, Inc. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Wonder Workshop in a new window

Page.Name: Wolfram widget builder
Page.MetaDescription: Wolfram widget builder allows students to create their own widget to add to a web site.
Page.MainText: Wolfram widget builder allows students to create their own widget to add to a web site. A widget is a small program that a visitor to a web site can interact with. The Wolfram widget builder allows students to use queries and variables to build a small piece of code and a simple user interface to add to a web site.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Wolfram Alpha LLC - A Wolfram Research Company. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Wolfram widget builder in a new window

Page.Name: Tynker
Page.MetaDescription: Tynker is an online platform designed to teach students how to code using games and stories. Students can learn the fundamentals of programming and design using Tynker's in-built visual programming language.
Page.MainText: Tynker is an online platform designed to teach students how to code using games and stories. Students can learn the fundamentals of programming and design through Tynker's in-built visual programming language. Tynker consists of six free starter lessons that include student activities, teacher notes, automated assessment tools, projects, quizzes and answer keys. Students build simple games, stories and patterns to learn the basics of coding. Further courses, school metrics and administration packages are also available for purchase.
Page.Copyright: May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Tynker in a new window

Page.Name: Tinkercad
Page.MetaDescription: Tinkercad is a free online 3D design and modelling program.
Page.MainText: Using Tinkercad students can make or import three dimensional shapes, then manipulate, edit and group shapes to create their own 3D models. Tinkercad allows students to export their shape to Minecraft or into formats compatible for 3D printing or laser cutting. Students can create and share their designs online, and build on designs from the community-created resource bank.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Autodesk Inc. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Tinkercad in a new window

Page.Name: Kodu Game Lab Communitya
Page.MetaDescription: A broad collection of online courses, lesson plans, resources and supportive material to help educators get started in teaching computer programming.
Page.MainText: Kodu Game Lab contains a variety of materials designed to support teachers to learn about Kodu, a visual programming tool available on multiple platforms including Windows. This online resource contains lesson plans and activities for teachers including a downloadable classroom kit, and links to videos that provide support in getting started. It also contains self-paced courses and tutorials that teachers can use to develop skills in using Kodu and enhance the learning experience for students.
Page.LinkName: Opens Kodu Game Lab Community in a new window

Page.Name: STEM Professionals in Schools
Page.MetaDescription: STEM Professionals in Schools is a national volunteer program that facilitates partnerships between schools and industry to bring real STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Maths) into the classroom.
Page.MainText: STEM Professionals in Schools is a national volunteer program that facilitates partnerships between schools and industry to bring real STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Maths) into the classroom.
Page.Copyright: CSIRO 2007 - 2015. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens STEM Professionals in Schools in a new window

Page.Name: Hour of Code
Page.MetaDescription: Resources to support the Hour of Code, a global movement supporting and inspiring students to code.
Page.MainText: This resource supports and promotes the worldwide Hour of Code event that occurs annually with the aim of improving student access and exposure to coding. This resource contains information, instructions, tutorials, and links to other resources to help students plan and prepare for the Hour of Code event. The Hour of Code occurs globally each year during Computer Science Week in early December.
Page.Copyright: Code.org. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Hour of Code in a new window

Page.Name: Stencyl
Page.MetaDescription: Stencyl is a downloadable programming application designed to teach students how to code.
Page.MainText: Students learn the fundamentals of programming and design through Stencyl's visual programming language. The Stencyl web site contains six simple lessons that include student activities, teacher notes and example code. Students are guided through building simple games to learn the basics of coding. Stencyl is free for students to download for personal use and classroom sets of Stencyl are available for purchase.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Stencyl, LLC. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Stencyl in a new window

Page.Name: Sphero
Page.MetaDescription: The Sphero web site is intended to support students or classrooms who have purchased a Sphero ball.
Page.MainText: Sphero is a programmable robotic ball, designed to teach students different aspects of programming and robotics. The ball can change colour, rolling speed and direction and can be controlled via downloadable tablet apps. The Sphero web site contains videos, teaching materials and an online community for students and teachers to share their projects and ideas. The Sphero ball can be controlled by four different apps of differing complexity, allowing for increasingly sophisticated levels of coding including detecting events, conditional statements and iteration.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Sphero. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Sphero in a new window

Page.Name: Lego Mindstorms
Page.MetaDescription: The Lego Mindstorms web site is intended to support students or classrooms who have purchased a Mindstorms EV3 robotics set.
Page.MainText: Lego Mindstorms is a set of building blocks and programmable components that students can build into various robots, designed to teach students different aspects of programming and robotics. This site contains building instructions, example robots, links to the programming app used to control their robots, videos and other materials to help students develop their robots.
Page.Copyright: 2016 the LEGO Group. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Lego Mindstorms in a new window

Page.Name: Pencil code
Page.MetaDescription: Pencil Code is a free, collaborative site designed for teaching and learning programming.
Page.MainText: Pencil Code uses visual blocks and various programming languages to introduce and develop basic programming concepts through drawing art, playing music, and creating games. This site allows students to experiment with coding, build from example projects and save their programs publicly. It contains student handouts graded for beginners, intermediate and advanced levels of experience, teacher notes, example programs and a detailed unit plan. The concepts covered include input and output, loops, conditional statements, nesting, recursion, basic data structures and differing programming languages and where they are used.
Page.LinkName: Opens Pencil code in a new window

Page.Name: Game star mechanic
Page.MetaDescription: Gamestar Mechanic is a game-based online digital learning platform designed to teach the guiding principles of game design and systems thinking.
Page.MainText: The web site guides students through quests and missions to play games, deconstruct them and next design, test and refine their own games. The site consists of free starter content and then further learning material and content is also available for purchase. There is also managed classroom systems and teacher guides available for purchase.
Page.Copyright: May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Game star mechanic in a new window

Page.Name: Coding in the Classroom
Page.MetaDescription: Through this website, educators can explore and share resources and strategies to teach coding.
Page.MainText: This resource is a website for sharing resources and strategies for teaching primary students computer programming skills and concepts. It contains a discussion board, blogs, videos, articles and case studies on topical learning and computer education concepts and issues. There are links to resources such as Hopscotch, Scratch, code.org and many more.
Page.Copyright: 2016 George Lucas Educational Foundation. Free-for-education material.
Page.LinkName: Opens Coding in the Classroom in a new window

Page.Name: CAS Barefoot
Page.MetaDescription: A broad collection of online resources to support teachers to develop and implement computational thinking, concepts and computer programming.
Page.MainText: This comprehensive collection of materials supports teacher planning and delivery of computer-programming curriculum to primary-aged students. It contains concept materials for teachers to develop computing knowledge; teaching activities for designing lessons; and downloadable files and resources to implement programming activities including software installation. Activities in this resource are largely based on Scratch, a visual programming language as well as Kodu and Hopscotch.
Page.LinkName: Opens CAS Barefoot in a new window

Page.Name: Common Sense Digital Citizenship
Page.MetaDescription: This website offers a free course on digital citizenship.
Page.MainText: Common Sense Education offers a free online curriculum encouraging students to think critically, behave safely, and participate responsibly in the digital world, concentrating on digital literacy and citizenship skills. It addresses subjects such as cyberbullying, digital cheating, and safety and security concerns. The site provides both teacher background information and student lesson materials.
Page.Copyright: Common Sense Media Inc. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 2.0
Page.LinkName: Opens Common Sense Digital Citizenship in a new window

Page.Name: Scratch: Makey Makey - Music
Page.MetaDescription: A Studio for Makey Makey Instruments, providing projects created and uploaded by students.
Page.MainText: These projects show what's possible combing Scratch and the Makey Makey board. Check out the studio for Makey Makey Games too.
Page.LinkName: Opens Scratch: Makey Makey - Music in a new window

Page.Name: What is code?
Page.MetaDescription: This article is devoted to demystifying code explaining what coding is, covering programming, programming languages and provides relevant examples.
Page.MainText: This article was published June 2015 and written by Paul Ford a programmer and writer. This article explains some of the aspects of programming languages such as C, C++, Objective-C, C#, JavaScript, PHP, and Python.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Bloomberg L.P. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens What is code? in a new window

Page.Name: Tech girls: resources
Page.MetaDescription: This site offers a range of suitable programs and sites to support girls in computing.
Page.MainText: The United Nations set October 11 aside as a time to recognize that empowerment of and investment in girls is critical for our future. Find resources here to support International Day of the Girl.
Page.Copyright: Tech-Girls and Charlottesville Women in Tech. Creative Commons BY-SA 3.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens Tech girls: resources in a new window

Page.Name: P–10 Technologies Australian Curriculum and resources
Page.MetaTitle: P–10 Technologies Australian Curriculum and resources
Page.MetaDescription: This site has developed advice, guidelines and resources developed by the Queensland Curriculum and Assessment Authority (QCAA) to support the implementation of the Technologies Australian Curriculum.
Page.MainText: The site provides guidance for both Digital Technologies and Design Technologies for P-10. Advice on time allocation, planning and assessment are included.
Page.Organisation: The State of Queensland (Queensland Curriculum and Assessment Authority)
Page.Copyright: The State of Queensland (Queensland Curriculum and Assessment Authority) 2016. Free-for-education material.

Page.Name: @MrAColley
Page.MetaDescription: This is a blog created by Andy Colley a lead practitioner of computing in the UK.
Page.MainText: Check out Andy's ICT and Computing resources. There are links to some great units of work for secondary students downloadable from dropbox. Previous posts are available as archives.
Page.Copyright: Mr A Colley. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens @MrAColley in a new window

Page.Name: A Visual Introduction to Machine Learning
Page.MetaTitle: A Visual Introduction to Machine Learning
Page.MetaDescription: This site explains how 'machine learning' is used to make highly accurate predictions using interactive visualisations.
Page.MainText: Using a data set about homes, see how a machine learning model is created to distinguish homes in New York from homes in San Francisco. One example of a machine learning method is a decision tree. See how a decision tree model works. An example decision tree demonstrates how if-then statements are used to define patterns in data. Adding split points and repeating processes (recursion) is also explained. Finally it shows how the tree performs on previously-unseen data.
Page.LinkName: Opens A Visual Introduction to Machine Learning in a new window

Page.Name: Google CS First: Sports
Page.MetaDescription: CS First: Sports guides students to use block-based coding in Scratch projects through a series of themed activities.
Page.MainText: CS First is a free program that offers computer science projects for students aged 9-14 who sign up to be part of the club. In the sports project, students move through eight sports themed activities that develop computer science skills. Activities include animating a victory celebration, a sports commentary, making a ball game, a commercial, an extreme sports game and a post-game interview. Each activity is supported by a video and project starters which students use to remix and create their own stories. Lesson plans accompany the student activities.
Page.LinkName: Opens Google CS First: Sports in a new window

Page.Name: Google CS First: Social media
Page.MetaDescription: CS First: Social media guides students to use block-based coding in Scratch projects through a series of themed activities.
Page.MainText: CS First is a free program that offers computer science projects for students aged 9-14 who sign up to be part of the club. In the social media project, students move through eight activities that focus on an aspect of social media and develop computer science skills. Activities include animating a character, creating a profile page, making a game and a quiz, designing a style board, building a viral video and making a time lapse animation. Each activity is supported by a video and project starters which students use to remix and create their own stories. Lesson plans accompany the student activities.
Page.LinkName: Opens Google CS First: Social media in a new window

Page.MetaDescription: CS First: Music & sound guides students to use block-based coding in Scratch projects through a series of themed activities.
Page.MainText: CS First is a free program that offers computer science projects for students aged 9-14 who sign up to be part of the club. In the music & sound project, students move through eight musical activities that develop computer science skills. Activities include creating a dance party, a musical talent show, a music video, a DJ mixing show and movie sound effects and music. Each activity is supported by a video and project starters which students use to remix and create their own stories. Lesson plans accompany the student activities.
Page.LinkName: Opens Google CS First: Music & sound in a new window

Page.MetaDescription: CS First: Game design guides students to use block-based coding in Scratch projects through a series of themed activities.
Page.MainText: CS First is a free program that offers computer science projects for students aged 9-14 who sign up to be part of the club. In the game design project, students move through eight activities that focus on an aspect of computer games and develop computer science skills. Activities include creating a racing game, a maze game, a platform game, and escape game and a quest game. Each activity is supported by a video and project starters which students use to remix and create their own stories. Lesson plans accompany the student activities.

Page.Name: Google CS First: Friends
Page.MetaDescription: CS First: Friends guides students to use block-based coding in Scratch projects through a series of themed activities.
Page.MainText: CS First is a free program that offers computer science projects for students aged 9-14 who sign up to be part of the club. In the friends project, students move through eight activities that focus on an creating programs with a friend and developing computer science skills. Activities include creating a truth and lie game, designing an imaginary future, making a collaborative game, creating advertising for a joint company and a reflective scrapbook. Each activity is supported by a video and project starters which students use to remix and create their own stories. Lesson plans accompany the student activities.

In the fashion and design project, students move through eight activities that focus on an aspect of fashion design and develop computer science skills. Activities include telling a fashion story, styling, fashion innovation, a fashion poll, making patterns and holding a fashion awards ceremony. Page.Name: Khan Academy: Journey into cryptography
Page.MetaDescription: This tutorial provides a detailed treatment of cryptographic methods with comprehensive explanations of their operation.
Page.MainText: Commencing with ancient cryptography, these comprehensive online lessons cover ciphers, modern cryptography (including public/private key and RSA), modular arithmetic and the significance of large prime numbers in modern cryptographic methods. This is a comprehensive treatment of the topic however much of initial sections are accessible to middle high school students.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Khan Academy. Some material is Creative Commons. Otherwise, may be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.

Page.Name: Mobilize
Page.MetaDescription: The core intent of this project is to develop methods for data collection and analysis for students.
Page.MainText: The core intent of this project is to develop methods for data collection and analysis for students. Through Mobilize units, students will engage with and learn about the nature of data. Mobilize centers its curricula around participatory sensing campaigns in which students use their mobile devices to collect and share data about their communities and their lives, and to analyze these data to gain understanding. The UCLA MobilizingCS app is a cross-platform mobile application available in the Android and Apple stores. Once installed, users can download the data collection projects and start collecting data. To access the materials users must register.
Page.Copyright: 2015 Mobilize. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Mobilize in a new window

Page.Name: Taleblazer
Page.MetaDescription: TaleBlazer allows users to play and make their own location-based mobile games.
Page.MainText: TaleBlazer is an augmented reality (AR) software platform. Developed by the MIT (STEP) lab, TaleBlazer allows users to play and make their own location-based mobile games. By situating games in the real world, AR games combine real landscapes and other aspects of the physical environment with additional digital information supplied by smartphones.
Page.Copyright: 2013-2016 MIT STEP Lab. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.

Page.MainText: This 2014 report describes the demand for STEM skills within the Australian workplace.This 2014 report describes the demand for STEM skills within the Australian workplace.
