Page.Name: BOSTES: A Guide to Coding and Computational Thinking Across the Curriculum
Page.MetaTitle: BOSTES: A Guide to Coding and Computational Thinking Across the Curriculum
Page.MetaDescription: This website includes links to useful resources, and outlines where computational thinking can be leveraged within current NSW K-8 syllabuses.
Page.MainText: The site offers definitions of terms, such as coding, computational thinking, and algorithmic thinking; and provides suggestions for implementing these key areas across the curriculum.
Page.Organisation: Board of Studies, Teaching and Educational Standards NSW
Page.Copyright: 2016 Copyright Board of Studies, Teaching and Educational Standards NSW for and on behalf of the Crown in right of the State of New South Wales. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence
Page.LinkName: Opens BOSTES: A Guide to Coding and Computational Thinking Across the Curriculum in a new window

Page.Name: Primo
Page.MetaDescription: A play set available for purchase that introduces young learners, from 3 years old and up, to programming basics as they create steps using blocks that instruct a wooden robot.
Page.MainText: A hands-on, wooden play set that uses tactile programming blocks for Cubetto, a wooden robot to follow. Introducing young learners to basic programming skills, this resource provides a unique opportunity to experiment with code in a physical setting and without screens. Cubetto is available for purchase and is supported by a range of online teacher resources.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Primo Toys Ltd. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Primo in a new window

Page.Name: Robot Turtles
Page.MetaDescription: A programmable turtle that moves around a board according to simple directional steps to collect its jewels and win the game.
Page.MainText: This board game featuring a programmable turtle supports learning about the basic principles of programming. Players move their turtles according to simple directions on instructional cards in order to collect robot jewels.
Page.Copyright: 2013-2014 Robot Turtles LLC. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Robot Turtles in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Error Detection
Page.MetaDescription: Use these activities with your students to explore how a computer figures out if an error has occurred in stored and transmitted data.
Page.MainText: Use the Error Detection offline activity to explore how a computer uses parity error checking to find errors. A parity bit is a single bit added to binary data. This task uses a 'magic trick' to engage learners and introduce the idea of adding a parity bit to data. It relies on the parity bit indicating whether a column of data is an odd or even value. The activity also shows real examples of this error detection technique using a ten-digit code ISBN (International Standard Book Number) and Bar code. Support your teaching and learning with video clips and other related resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Error Detection in a new window

Page.Name: Grok learning resources
Page.MetaDescription: Grok provides online interactive programming courses for individuals or classrooms.
Page.MainText: Grok provides online interactive programming courses for individuals or classrooms in Python, HTML, CSS, Blockly at all levels. Grok's courses are well paced and provide student coding efforts with immediate feedback along with helpful suggestions. Grok conducts the established NCSS (National Computing Science School annual programming competitions).
Page.Copyright: Grok Learning Pty Ltd. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Grok learning resources in a new window

Page.Name: Gameblox
Page.MetaDescription: Gameblox is a blocks-based programming tool designed specifically to provide an accessible introduction to game design.
Page.MainText: Gameblox provides an environment in which novices can create entertaining games by embedding some of the more complex programming tasks such as collisions, physics and gravity within the blocks. More advanced game designers might also find Gameblox a useful tool for rapid prototyping in their iterative design process. edX offers courses to support the use of Gameblox in game design.
Page.Copyright: MIT Scheller Teacher Education Program. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Gameblox in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Computer Vision
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Computer Vision
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Computer Vision.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Computer Vision. This chapter covers the impact on computer vision as a result of increases in computer power, decrease in the size of computers and progressively more advanced algorithms.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Field guide: Computer Vision in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Complexity and tractability
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Complexity and tractability
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on complexity and tractability.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on complexity and tractability. This chapter covers problems where it's easy to tell the computer what to do --- by writing a program --- but the computer can’t do what we want because it takes far too long. Find out about what is meant by tractable and an intractable problem. Learn about complexity, why its an important concept and how it relates to algorithms.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Field guide: Complexity and tractability in a new window

Page.Name: Your Course to Success
Page.MetaDescription: Build your skills in computer science. Explore topics such as Data science, Computer Science and Information Technology. Register for online courses available for free.
Page.MainText: Build your skills in computer science. Explore topics such as Data science, Computer Science and Information Technology. Register for online courses available for free.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Coursera Inc. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Your Course to Success in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Software Engineering
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Software Engineering
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Software Engineering.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Software Engineering. This chapter, cover the basics of software engineering. The chapter explores the steps of analysing the problem; how to structure and design software, avoiding software bugs and testing the software.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Field guide: Software Engineering in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Programming Languages
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Programming Languages
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Programming Languages.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Programming Languages. This chapter covers what happens when you write and run a program, and how this affects the way that you distribute the program for others to use.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Field guide: Programming Languages in a new window

Page.Name: Code yourself! An introduction
Page.MetaDescription: This is a beginner course for teachers interested in programming with Scratch.
Page.MainText: This online signup course teaches how to program in Scratch, an easy-to-use visual programming language. It introduces the fundamental principles of computing.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Coursera Inc. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Code yourself! An introduction in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Network Communication Protocols
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Network Communication Protocols
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Network Communication Protocols.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Network Communication Protocols. This chapter introduces some concepts, algorithms, techniques, applications and problems that relate to network protocols.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Field guide: Network Communication Protocols in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Formal Languages
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Formal Languages
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Formal Languages.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Formal Languages. This chapter covers the strict rules specified in formal languages and describes examples of its use. Find out about regular expressions including an example, Finite state automata.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Field guide: Formal Languages in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Data Representation
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Data Representation
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focuses on Data Representation.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focuses on Data Representation. This chapter is about some of the different methods that computers use to code different kinds of information in patterns of bits, and how this affects the cost and quality of what we do on the computer.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Field guide: Data Representation in a new window

Page.Name: Code like a girl
Page.MetaDescription: This website supports females who are into coding with events, a blog and virtual events.
Page.MainText: Code like a girl conducts tech-focused events and workshops, primarily around Melbourne, bringing together local talents and like-minded girls who enjoy coding and technology.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Code like a Girl. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Code like a girl in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Computer Graphics
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Computer Graphics
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Coding - Computer Graphics.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Coding - Computer Graphics. This chapter covers basic techniques that are used to create computer graphics. Use the interactives to explore graphics transformations. Learn more about the fundamental operation of drawing lines and circles as computer graphics. This chapter has a strong connection to mathematics curricula.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Field guide: Computer Graphics in a new window

Page.Name: Bee-Bots – getting started
Page.MetaDescription: Suggestions for introducing Bee Bots in the Primary Curriculum.
Page.MainText: Suggestions for introducing Bee Bots in the Primary Curriculum. General principles are discussed and some student example videos are included.
Page.Copyright: 2015 Laura Barker. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Bee-Bots – getting started in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Coding - Introduction
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Coding - Introduction
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter provides an introduction to Coding.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter provides an introduction to Coding. This brief chapter explains the three main reasons that we use more complex representations of binary data.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Field guide: Coding - Introduction in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Coding - Error Control
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Coding - Error Control
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Coding - Error Control.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Coding - Error Control. This chapter is about guarding against errors in data in its many different forms. Use the parity interactive and Check digit calculator to explore error control coding.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Field guide: Coding - Error Control in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Coding - Encryption
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Coding - Encryption
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Coding - Encryption.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Coding - Encryption. This chapter covers encryption and provides examples of different ways used to keep data secret. Find out about ciphers, what they are and the problems that may occur. Use the interactives to encrypt and decrypt messages.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Field guide: Coding - Encryption in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Coding - Compression
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Coding - Compression
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Coding - Compression.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Coding - Compression. This chapter looks at common forms of compression and issues related to quality of data and time taken to compress and decompress the data.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Field guide: Coding - Compression in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Artificial Intelligence
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Artificial Intelligence
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Artificial Intelligence.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Artificial Intelligence. This chapter explores a range of intelligent systems and also considers ethical and philosophical issues that often are part of the Artificial Intelligence (AI) landscape. Find out about computer programs (chatterbots) designed to have a conversation with a human and sound intelligent.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Field guide: Artificial Intelligence in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Algorithms
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Algorithms.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Algorithms. This chapter covers what an algorithm is, and why they are such a fundamental idea in computer science. Find out more about the two most common and important types of algorithms - Searching and Sorting.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Algorithms

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Human Computer Interaction
Page.MetaTitle: CS Unplugged: Field guide: Human Computer Interaction
Page.MetaDescription: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Human Computer Interaction.
Page.MainText: An online resource for teaching Computer Science to students, this chapter focusses on Human Computer Interaction. This chapter provides advice about how to make programs useful, usable, and accessible to humans. The chapter covers areas of Users and tasks, Interface usability and Usability heuristics.
Page.Copyright: University of Canterbury, New Zealand. Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Field guide: Human Computer Interaction in a new window

Page.Name: Digital Technologies: An Introduction
Page.MetaDescription: This introduction to the Digital Technologies curriculum helps teachers become familiar with the framework, features, and relevance of this subject.
Page.MainText: This introduction to the Digital Technologies curriculum helps teachers become familiar with the framework, features, and relevance of this subject. This video describes the structure, features, and application of the Australian Curriculum: Digital Technologies curriculum. The framework of the Digital Technologies curriculum is explained including its place within the broader Technologies Learning Area, its two strands, and the dimensions within which students develop ICT learning. Features of the Digital Technologies curriculum to keep it relevant and future-proof are described, as well as identifying the application of multimedia to digital technologies.
Page.LinkName: Opens Digital Technologies: An Introduction in a new window

Page.Name: w3schools
Page.MetaDescription: Use this website with your students to follow tutorials on popular web design tools.
Page.MainText: Use this website with your students to follow tutorials on popular web design tools.
Page.Copyright: 1999-2016 Refsnes Data. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens w3schools in a new window

Page.Name: Project Euler
Page.MetaDescription: A collection of mathematical problems to solve using programmatic techniques.
Page.MainText: Project Euler is a series of challenging mathematical/computer programming problems that can be solved using programming skills. The motivation is to provide a platform to delve into unfamiliar types of problems and learn new concepts in a fun and recreational context. The problems range in difficulty.
Page.LinkName: Opens Project Euler in a new window

Page.Name: MIT App Inventor
Page.MetaDescription: Use this site with your students to follow OOP principles to build a mobile app.
Page.MainText: MIT App Inventor provides a beginner's introduction to programming and app creation that replaces text-based coding with visual, drag-and-drop building blocks. The simple graphical interface allows an inexperienced beginner the ability to create a basic, fully functional app. An emphasis is placed on OOP principles. The tool is web-based and runs on both Windows and Mac computers. An emulator allows product to be viewed on the desktop on Mac or Win. Apps can be run on an Android mobile device.
Page.Copyright: 2012-2015 Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Creative Commons BY-SA 3.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens MIT App Inventor in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Human Interface Design
Page.MetaDescription: Use these activities with your students to explore human-centred interface design.
Page.MainText: Use The chocolate factory—Human interface design offline activity to explore interface design issues and what makes good interface design. Support your teaching and learning with video clips and other related resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Human Interface Design in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Sorting Networks
Page.MetaDescription: This activity demonstrates how computers sort random numbers into order using something called a 'sorting network'.
Page.MainText: Use the Sorting Networks! offline activity to explore how a number of computers can be networked to complete a task faster than a single computer. Students in groups are the 'network of computers' and sort random numbers into order. The task combines knowledge of place value in number and computation in computer science. Support your teaching and learning with video clips and other related resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Sorting Networks in a new window

Page.Name: Sudoku!
Page.MetaDescription: In this project, students program the fun and challenging game of Sudoku using Python programming language.
Page.MainText: Download the pdf which provides useful guidance and support that explains suggested key steps to solve the task. It is recommended that students program includes loops and nested loops instead of repeating code.
Page.LinkName: Opens Sudoku! in a new window

Page.Name: Battleship!
Page.MetaDescription: In this project, students build a battleship-playing program using Python.
Page.MainText: Download the Battleship [PDF] which provides useful guidance and support that explains suggested key steps to solve the task. In this task students practice functions and loops.
Page.LinkName: Opens Battleship! in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Harold the Robot
Page.MetaDescription: In this activity students give verbal instructions to a person role playing a robot as an introduction to programing language.
Page.MainText: Use the Harold The Robot offline activity to consider the type of instructions a robot could interpret and follow.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Harold the Robot in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Programming languages
Page.MetaDescription: Use these activities with your students to explore how a computer program is a sequence of instructions that the computer must follow.
Page.MainText: Use the Marching Orders— Programming Languages offline activity to explore how a computer follows a set of instructions. Support your teaching and learning with video clips and other related resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Programming languages in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Sorting Algorithms
Page.MetaDescription: Use these activities with your students to explore how information is easier to find if it is sorted.
Page.MainText: Use the Lightest and Heaviest—Sorting Algorithms offline activity to explore how a computer lists information to make it easier to find. Support your teaching and learning with video clips and other related resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Sorting Algorithms in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Text Compression
Page.MetaDescription: Use these activities with your students to explore how a computer stores information as efficiently as possible.
Page.MainText: Use the You Can Say That Again! offline activity to explore how a computer stores information as efficiently as possible. Support your teaching and learning with video clips and other related resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Text Compression in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Information Theory
Page.MetaDescription: Use these activities with your students to introduce the way a computer compresses information.
Page.MainText: Use the Twenty Guesses— Information Theory offline activity to explore how a computer stores information as efficiently as possible. This activity introduces a way of measuring information content. Support your teaching and learning with video clips and other related resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Information Theory in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Modems Unplugged
Page.MetaDescription: This activity involves listening to songs and finding hidden messages based on the same principle as a modem.
Page.MainText: Use the Sound Representation activity to explore how binary digits are converted to sound, and decoded at the other end, using a modem. Support your teaching and learning with video clips, sound files and other related resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Modems Unplugged in a new window

Page.Name: CS Unplugged: Finite State Automata
Page.MetaDescription: This task shows how automated telephone messages that offer a range of selections and automated teller machines (ATM) use Finite-state automata.
Page.MainText: Use the Treasure Hunt— Finite-State Automata offline activity to explore how a computer processes a sequence of symbols. The task uses a pirate treasure map to follow a set of instructions and record the journey using a sequence of symbols. Finite-state automata is used in Computer Science to help a computer process a sequence of characters or events. Support your teaching and learning with video clips and other related resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens CS Unplugged: Finite State Automata in a new window

Page.Name: Lightbot
Page.MetaDescription: A programming puzzle app, available for use on multiple devices, teaching students coding concepts as they guide a robot to solve problems and light up tiles.
Page.MainText: Lightbot is a programming game featuring a robot that completes a sequence of commands to solve puzzles and light up the tiles. As students move through the levels they learn about programming language and coding constructs such as sequential commands, procedures and loops. Lightbot is available to purchase for iOS and android devices, as well as web-based, and there are also teacher resources and explanations available on the lightbot resources website.
Page.Copyright: Lightbot. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Lightbot in a new window

Page.Name: Dot and Dash Robots
Page.MetaDescription: Robots that can be programmed by iOS and android devices to fulfill designed behaviours including moving and singing.
Page.MainText: Dot and Dash Robots are robot toys that can be programmed using iOS and android devices and free downloadable apps. Students unleash their creativity and experiment with programming as they design a set of behaviours for their robot including the ability to navigate objects, respond to voice, dance, move, and sing. Dot and Dash Robots are available for purchase and are supported by a range of online teacher resources. Tickle is a useful app for iOS devices to program Dot and Dash Robots.
Page.Copyright: Wonder Workshop, Inc. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Dot and Dash Robots in a new window

Page.Name: Daisy the Dinosaur
Page.MetaDescription: A free iPad app featuring a dinosaur that can be programmed to complete a series of simple tasks including instructions to produce a desired outcome.
Page.MainText: A coding game featuring a cute dinosaur that introduces young students to programming including writing basic commands with conditions and repeats. Students drag commands from a provided list, into the program window, press play, and watch as the dinosaur carries out the instructions. There are two modes: free-play mode and challenge mode.
Page.Copyright: 2011 Hopscotch Inc. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Daisy the Dinosaur in a new window

Page.Name: Code Studio
Page.MetaDescription: A broad and comprehensive collection of online courses and materials to teach coding and computer programming fundamentals to students of all ages.
Page.MainText: Code Studio contains a multitude of online courses and other resources to support the development of computer programming skills in students of all ages. Select the most appropriate activity based on student age and ability and progress through many levels of increasing difficulty. As well as online courses, Code Studio contains other resources including instructional videos, activity background, related unplugged activities, tutorials and teacher lesson plans.
Page.Copyright: Code.org, 2016. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Code Studio in a new window

Page.Name: Blockly Games
Page.MetaDescription: A series of self-paced interactive games that progressively introduce programming concepts and challenge students to apply these to solve problems.
Page.MainText: Blockly Games is a series of interactive and challenging games designed to develop student skills in a range of computer programming techniques and algorithm-based solutions. Students solve problems from simple puzzles to more complex challenges involving loops, conditions, blocks and text-based languages. Students can select from several games, most of which contain ten levels, and some contain supportive information describing the use of functions, logic, loops and variables.
Page.LinkName: Opens Blockly Games in a new window

Page.Name: Bee-Bot
Page.MetaDescription: A programmable bee robot that completes a sequence of directional steps to produce a desired outcome such as herding sheep or collecting eggs.
Page.MainText: A coding game featuring a programmable bee robot that introduces students to basic programming skills based on directional language. Students create a sequence of steps using the controls: forwards, backwards, left and right turns, which the bee bot follows in order to solve simple problems such as herding sheep into a pen. Bee bot game is set on farms and a flower garden and becomes increasingly complex as students progress through the levels.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Terrapin Software. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Bee-Bot in a new window

Page.Name: Ideas to Try: Digital learning activities for Foundation teachers
Page.MetaTitle: Ideas to Try: Digital learning activities for Foundation teachers
Page.MetaDescription: Here are some practical ideas for teachers and students at Foundation level (Prep) to use digital technologies in learning and teaching.
Page.MainText: Linked to all areas of the Victorian Curriculum (VC) this is a handy resource when planning to integrate technologies. The activities use many different types of technologies including iPads, computers, notebooks and cameras.
Page.Organisation: State of Victoria (Department of Education and Training)
Page.LinkName: Opens Ideas to Try: Digital learning activities for Foundation teachers in a new window

Page.Name: Chrome Experiments
Page.MetaDescription: Chrome Experiments is a showcase of work by coders who are pushing the boundaries of web technology, creating beautiful, unique web experiences.
Page.MainText: You'll find helpful links throughout the site for creating your own experiments, and you can also explore resources like WebGL Globe and our workshop of tools.
Page.Copyright: Google Inc. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Chrome Experiments in a new window

Page.Name: SPI 2016: STEM programme index 2016
Page.MetaDescription: In this document you'll find over 250 active programmes operating across Australia, categorised under the umbrella of STEM.
Page.MainText: The programmes are organised into 10 chapters. The chapter on Digital Technology and ICT includes programmes identified by type that include: After school club and holiday programmes, In-school programmes, Resources, Competitions; University enrichment, Professional development, Excursion, Mentoring, school visits and careers.
Page.Copyright: Commonwealth of Australia 2016. Creative Commons BY 3.0 AU.
Page.LinkName: Opens Spi 2016 Stem Programme Index 2016

Page.Name: Code Monster
Page.MetaDescription: Code Monster is an interactive Javascript editor and tutorial for students to learn basic coding concepts.
Page.MainText: The code monster character provides example code snippets with dynamic output and students are prompted to experiment with parts of the code to see how it affects the output. Code monster guides students through coding concepts like variables, conditional statements, iteration and nesting, functions and arrays. Students can navigate to different sections of Code monster using lesson sections.
Page.LinkName: Opens Code Monster in a new window

Page.Name: The new basics: Big data reveals the skills young people need for the New Work Order
Page.MetaTitle: The new basics: Big data reveals the skills young people need for the New Work Order
Page.MetaDescription: This report presents findings and argues for action to build the enterprise skills of the next generation.
Page.MainText: This report is part of FYA's series the 'New Work Order'. The report defines enterprise skills and technical skills. Figures indicate that the demand for enterprise skills is on the rise. The report discusses implications for educators and education systems.
Page.Copyright: 2016 The Foundation for Young Australians. Creative Commons BY-NC-ND 3.0 AU.
Page.LinkName: Opens The New Basics Web Final

Page.Name: GAfE and the Digital Technologies Curriculum - handout
Page.MetaTitle: GAfE and the Digital Technologies Curriculum - handout
Page.MetaDescription: This document outlines a webinar for teachers about how Google Apps for Education can support teaching the Digital Technologies curriculum.
Page.MainText: The recorded webinar is hyperlinked from the document for teachers to access. The webinar focuses on three aspects of the curriculum: Data visualization, Designing algorithms and Collaboration & communication. The document includes links to online classroom resources, videos, classroom teaching examples, and professional learning resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens Gafe And The Australian Digital Technologies Curriculum Docx

Page.Name: GAfE and the Digital Technologies Curriculum
Page.MetaTitle: GAfE and the Digital Technologies Curriculum
Page.MetaDescription: This slide show outlines a webinar for teachers about how Google Apps for Education can support teaching the Digital Technologies curriculum.
Page.MainText: The slide show focuses on three aspects of the curriculum: Data visualization, Designing algorithms and Collaboration & communication. The presentation is supported by links to online classroom resources, videos, classroom teaching examples, and professional learning resources.
Page.LinkName: Opens Gafe And The Australian Digital Technologies Curriculum Docx

Page.Name: Hopscotch
Page.MetaDescription: Hopscotch is an app for iOS devices that allows students to create their own applications using a visual block-based programming environment.
Page.MainText: This web page links to the app store to purchase and download Hopscotch, describes example programs that can be made and links to help videos and resources. Hopscotch is designed for students aged 9-11 and can be used to create animations, games, simple web sites and algorithmically generated art. Students can publish their programs and view programs others have made.
Page.Copyright: Hopscotch Technologies, Inc. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Hopscotch in a new window

Page.Name: Problem-solving using algorithms
Page.MetaDescription: This 6-minute video explores some of the criteria and complexities of creating an algorithm that solves problems efficiently.
Page.MainText: James Curran, Associate Professor, School of IT, University of Sydney provides some practical examples of algorithms. This video follows on from the clip 'What are algorithms?'

Page.Name: Understanding representation, part 1
Page.MetaDescription: This 7-minute video explores the nature of representation as an arbitrary communication device.
Page.MainText: James Curran, Associate Professor, School of IT, University of Sydney provides some practical examples of representation. Representation of data is an important aspect of any mode of communication including within digital devices. At one stage in the video (2 min 40 sec mark) you will be invited to participate by pausing the video and creating a quick sketch. You may wish to have a pen and paper available. The video 'Understanding representation, part 2' follows up ideas discussed in this clip.

Page.Name: Understanding representation, part 2
Page.MetaDescription: This 11-minute video explores number representations, including the development of the binary system.
Page.MainText: James Curran, Associate Professor, School of IT, University of Sydney provides some practical examples of representation. Representation of data is an important aspect of any mode of communication including within digital devices. This video follows on ideas presented in 'Understanding representation, part 1'

Page.Name: What are algorithms?
Page.MetaDescription: This 5-minute video explores the making of a vegemite sandwich and other processes to explain algorithms.
Page.MainText: James Curran, Associate Professor, School of IT, University of Sydney provides some practical examples of algorithms. This clip encourages thinking about the ways in which algorithms can be taught in a range of curriculum areas. The video Problem-solving using algorithms follows up ideas discussed in this clip.

Page.Name: Digital Technologies skills vs ICT skills
Page.MetaTitle: Digital Technologies skills vs ICT skills
Page.MetaDescription: This 2-min video describes the how the Digital Technologies curriculum embodies a shift in thinking about digital skills.
Page.MainText: James Curran, Associate Professor, School of IT, University of Sydney provides some practical examples of algorithms. James discusses the place of ICT skills in the curriculum and using these in conjunction with key concepts of digital technologies.

Page.Name: Scratch
Page.MetaDescription: Scratch, an online tool that uses visual block-based programming language, enables students to create their own interactive stories and games.
Page.MainText: Students snap together graphical programming blocks to make characters move, jump, dance, and sing. Short targeted tutorials provide easy to understand instructions to help students create fun projects.
Page.Copyright: Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Tufts University. Creative Commons BY-SA 4.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens Scratch in a new window

Page.Name: Why Digital Technologies?
Page.MetaDescription: Digital Technologies gives students a range of skills that allow them to express themselves creatively in ways that we haven't even thought of before.' This 4-minute video provides a persuasive rationale for this learning area.
Page.MainText: Digital Technologies gives students a range of skills that allow them to express themselves creatively in ways that we haven't even thought of before.' This 4-minute video provides a persuasive rationale for this learning area. James Curran, Associate Professor, School of IT, University of Sydney provides some practical examples of algorithms.

Page.Name: Looking Glass Help
Page.MetaDescription: This is the help web site for Looking Glass; free downloadable programming software designed to teach students the basics of coding through animated stories and simple games.
Page.MainText: Looking Glass is free downloadable programming software designed to teach students the basics of coding through animated stories and simple games. This website provides help for students engaged with the software, including FAQs and video tutorials. From this part of the web site, students can also navigate to the main page to download the software and share and download example code.
Page.Copyright: Washington University in St Louis. Creative Commons BY 3.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens Looking Glass Help in a new window

Page.Name: Looking Glass
Page.MetaDescription: Looking Glass is free downloadable programming software designed to teach students the basics of coding through animated stories and simple games.
Page.MainText: Looking Glass is free downloadable programming software designed to teach students the basics of coding through animated stories and simple games. Students use a visual block-based coding language to manipulate in-built sprites and story templates as well as community-created remixes to create their stories and games. Students can upload and share their projects with the online community for feedback and advice. The web site also contains a link to a showcase of examples and help.
Page.Copyright: Washington University in St Louis. Creative Commons BY 3.0.
Page.LinkName: Opens Looking Glass in a new window

Page.Name: Find the Right Board
Page.MetaDescription: This newsletter provides a detailed list of program boards and microcontrollers.
Page.MainText: Selecting the link provides details of the program board including specs and a brief description. Costs are is US dollars. Look for local suppliers when purchasing.
Page.Copyright: 2004-2016 Maker Media, Inc. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Find the Right Board in a new window

Page.Name: Minecraft: Education edition
Page.MetaDescription: This web site contains a link for teachers, schools and students to download a free version of Minecraft and resources for the teacher and classroom.
Page.MainText: Minecraft: Education edition is a free downloadable version of Minecraft, an open world building game. This web site contains a link for teachers, schools and students to download the game for free, as well as videos describing education applications of the game, lesson plans, tutorials, example worlds and online help and support. The lesson plans outline cross curricular activities for primary and secondary students, including developing story settings, exploring biodiversity, and building a virtual Rube Goldberg machine.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Mojang. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Minecraft: Education edition in a new window

Page.Name: Move the Turtle
Page.MetaDescription: Move the Turtle is a purchasable app for iOS devices designed to teach primary students the basic concepts of programming.
Page.MainText: In Move the Turtle, students use a graphical interface to issue movement, colour, sound and rotation commands to a turtle to navigate obstacles and achieve a goal. Commands are added sequentially, and can be looped, stored as procedures and shared.
Page.Copyright: 2012-2015 Next is Great. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Move the Turtle in a new window

Page.Name: Pro-bot
Page.MetaDescription: Pro-Bot is a programmable turtle robot, cleverly disguised as a race car.
Page.MainText: Pro-Bot will follow the sequence of commands that are entered step-by-step. You can also program the robot using Logo programming language. The Pro-Bot connects to your PC with a special USB cable. Terrapin Logo 4 contains commands to upload all procedures stored on the Pro-Bot to the Logo workspace, where you can edit these procedures, run them, and download them to the Pro-Bot again.
Page.Copyright: 2016 Terrapin Software. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Pro-bot in a new window

Page.Name: Raspberry Pi
Page.MetaDescription: This website contains resources for using, teaching and learning with the Raspberry Pi a small, low cost computer.
Page.MainText: The Raspberry Pi is a small, low cost computer designed for schools. This website contains resources for using, teaching and learning with the Raspberry Pi, including teaching units, projects for students, links to online communities, discussion forums and help resources. The many teaching and learning resources have an emphasis on learning about programming. Some of the activities include using Scratch and cardboard to make a robot, using Python and the twitter API to live stream tweets, using GPIOs and a programming language to make weather sensors. All activities assume students have access to a Raspberry Pi.
Page.Copyright: Raspberry Pi Foundation. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Raspberry Pi in a new window

Page.Name: Python
Page.MetaDescription: Python is a free programming language. This web page includes resources for learning to program with Python.
Page.MainText: Python is a free programming language. This web page contains resources for learning to program with Python, including beginners’ guides, example code, community resources and information about its open licensing. The beginners' guides include links to free online books and interactive courses to learn the basics of programming, including resources recommended for a K-12 classroom.
Page.Copyright: 2001-2016 Python Software Foundation. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Python in a new window

Page.Name: Snap!
Page.MetaDescription: Snap! is a free, browser-based visual coding environment designed to teach students the basic concepts of programming.
Page.MainText: Students use a block-based coding language to manipulate sprites and story templates as well as community-created code snippets to create stories and games. The web site also contains a link to the help manual, discussions on the Scratch forum, import and export tools and a showcase of example programs created in Snap!.
Page.Copyright: University of California at Berkeley. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Snap! in a new window

Page.Name: Network Protocols
Page.MetaDescription: Use this unplugged activity to explore how computers talk to each other over the internet via messages.
Page.MainText: In this activity students consider how different methods of communication operate successfully. By looking at rules and procedures in place, students are introduced to communication protocols. By working through a role-play scenario, pupils test their own protocol operating in an unreliable environment similar to that found in packet switching on the Internet, specifically, TCP/ IP.
Page.LinkName: Opens Network Protocols in a new window

Page.Name: InTEACT: Teaching and Learning Resources
Page.MetaDescription: This site supports educators of ICT and Computer Science particularly in the ACT including resources for teaching and learning.
Page.MainText: InTEACT supports teachers with ICT integration for learning in all areas of the curriculum and support the teaching of computing in primary and secondary schools particularly in the ACT. InTEACT (Information Technology Educators ACT) is the professional association for educators of ICT and Computer Science in the ACT. The site offers free online resources and research.
Page.Copyright: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.
Page.LinkName: Opens InTEACT: Teaching and Learning Resources in a new window

Page.MainText: The Makerspaces in schools sections has information about how to set up a makerspace in your school.Get some tips on how to use Arduino an open-source electronics prototyping platform often found in Makerspaces.View video which demonstrates what the Raspberry Pi is and its potential uses. Use YOUmedia to enable connected learning networking with schools and libraries that utilize Makerspaces.

Page.Name: Ozobot
Page.MetaDescription: Ozobot is a tiny robot that uses a colour code language to navigate game-based activities.
Page.MainText: Ozobots use sensors to follow tracks which can be hand drawn or constructed using apps. The OzoBlockly app is a visual programming language for the robots. Ozobots come with sample tracks and the STREAM program available on the website contains lesson plans.

Page.Name: Lego WeDo 2.0
Page.MetaDescription: LEGO WeDo 2.0 enables students to create and program solutions using science and engineering practices and computational thinking.
Page.MainText: LEGO WeDo 2.0 is appropriate for students in Years 2-4. Using bluetooth the creations can be controlled using tablet apps as well as bluetooth enabled computers. WeDo robots can be controlled using Scratch. LEGO WeDo 2.0 is compatible with Chromebooks, Mac, Windows and Android.
Page.Copyright: 2016 The LEGO Group. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Lego WeDo 2.0 in a new window

Page.Name: Wink - Learn to code with this entry level robot.
Page.MetaTitle: Wink - Learn to code with this entry level robot.
Page.MetaDescription: Wink is an Arduino-based robot that enables students to transition from graphical programming to more powerful text code languages.
Page.MainText: Wink was designed as a learning platform for people who are totally new to writing computer code. Wink's motors are fast and can be independently driven forward or backward and at any variable speed. Wink's eyes can be programmed to any color. Three light sensors on the top side enable light seeking and behaviors activated by lights. An infrared barrier headlight can be used together with the ambient light sensors to detect obstacles several inches in front of the robot. An array of four bottom sensors allow for high speed line following as well as edge detection.
Page.Copyright: 2015-2016 Plum Geek, LLC. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Wink - Learn to code with this entry level robot. in a new window

Page.Name: What's The Difference Between ICT Capabilities & the Digital Technologies Learning Area?
Page.MetaTitle: What's The Difference Between ICT Capabilities & the Digital Technologies Learning Area?
Page.MetaDescription: This blog summarises the differences between ICT Capabilities & the Digital Technologies Learning Area. The blog article is written by Dr Rebecca Vivian a leader in Digital Technologies working in the Computer Science Education Research Group based at The University of Adelaide.
Page.MainText: The article describes examples across the primary school curriculum where students create digital solutions, this is used to convey a key difference between Digital Technologies and ICT capability.
Page.Copyright: Dr Rebecca Vivian. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens What's The Difference Between ICT Capabilities & the Digital Technologies Learning Area? in a new window

Page.Name: STEM Integration Approaches DECD
Page.MetaDescription: There are a number of ways that STEM can be integrated. These approaches are dynamic, not sequential and movement between the approaches may occur. Just as the shifting role between educators and students in consuming and producing knowledge occurs depending on your learning intentions.
Page.MainText: In South Australia the Teaching for Effective Learning Framework (TfEL) uses Learning Design to bring the How? and What? of teaching STEM together.

Page.Name: Abstraction
Page.MetaDescription: Want to find out more about what abstraction is and its role is in computational thinking? This resource outlines: What is abstraction, why is abstraction important and what abstraction looks like in the primary curriculum.
Page.MainText: Abstraction is simplifying things. Abstraction is identifying what is important without worrying too much about the detail. Abstraction allows us to manage complexity.

Page.Name: The New Work Mindset
Page.MetaDescription: This FYA report, The New Work Mindset identifies seven new job clusters to help young people navigate the new work order.
Page.MainText: There is an urgent need to shift mindsets in our approach to jobs, careers and work. New big data analysis provides us with insights into the patterns of skills young people now require to navigate complex and uncertain working lives. This report shows that we need to shift our focus from jobs to skills to prepare young people for the future of work.

Page.Name: Building Machines That Emulate Humans
Page.MetaDescription: Students build robotic models from cardboard and straws to understand the anatomy and biomechanics of the human hand. Then, they conduct trials visualizing data in Excel to generate new ideas for improving it’s performance.
Page.MainText: Instructions provide a step-by-step guide for building the Sensorized Glove and the Robotic Hand. Includes templates, a list of things you need and detailed instructions. A customized Excel workbook visualizes real-time biomechanical data from sensor equipped gloves.

Page.Name: NovaLab: Cyber security

Page.Name: Literature review: Supporting teachers to assess F–10 Digital Technologies
Page.MetaTitle: Literature review: Supporting teachers to assess F–10 Digital Technologies
Page.MetaDescription: This paper provides some examples and approaches to assessment for Digital Technologies, linking to resources and tools that teachers may adopt in the classroom or utilise in the design of assessment activities.
Page.MainText: This paper provides some examples and approaches to assessment for Digital Technologies, linking to resources and tools that teachers may adopt in the classroom or utilise in the design of assessment activities. The report provides advice about designing assessment activities and assessment approaches and strategies that includes programming assignments, artefact analysis,cognitive interviewing (think aloud), test questions, problem-based puzzle projects and rubrics.

Page.Name: Crack the code
Page.MetaDescription: Using control technologies, students are required to individually design, produce and evaluate an alarm/alert system using a coding software (e.g. Arduino) and relevant hardware.
Page.MainText: Using control technologies, students are required to individually design, produce and evaluate an alarm/alert system using a coding software (e.g. Arduino) and relevant hardware. The system must include correct coding, working inputs and outputs and include a specified end-use application. Throughout the unit, students will learn programming concepts and commands and how to modify code to suit an identified need. Students will also learn how to assemble basic electronic circuits using a microcontroller to produce their final design idea.
Page.Copyright: State of New South Wales (Department of Education), 2018. Copyright material available on this website is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0) licence.

Page.Name: Schools Cyber Security Challenges
Page.MetaDescription: The Schools Cyber Security Challenges are designed to provide high school teachers with resources to support the teaching of cyber security concepts, and to inform students of career opportunities in the field. Note schools need to register and create a log-in.
Page.MainText: The Challenges explore general topics like personal information security and data sharing, as well as technical topics such as cryptography and network security. A range of engaging activities involving investigation, deduction and programming develop student knowledge, skills and dispositions as they work their way through increasingly difficult problems.
Page.Copyright: Unless otherwise indicated, this material may be used in accordance with the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Schools Cyber Security Challenges in a new window

Page.Name: Career profile: Marlee Hutton, CSIRO research scientist
Page.MetaTitle: Career profile: Marlee Hutton, CSIRO research scientist
Page.MetaDescription: This is one of a series of career profiles on Western Australian scientists involved in marine science and data science. The aim is to inspire students to consider a STEM career by highlighting the scientist's background and interests, a snap shot of their current role and the pathways they have taken to enter their profession. Marlee Hutton is an indigenous research scientist working for CSIRO.

Page.Name: My Computer Brain
Page.MetaDescription: Use these resources to gain a deeper and more intuitive understanding of Digital Technologies core concepts and their practical application.
Page.MainText: Explore how binary numbers work, how a computer adds, subtracts and how it remembers data. See algorithms at work when a computer performs multiplication and division. See mathematics in computer science when calculating Fibonacci numbers. Create beautiful pixel graphics and explore the foundations of artificial intelligence (AI). Teachers register free, subscription cost for students.
Page.Copyright: 2016-18 AD Digital Technologies Institute PTY LTD
Page.LinkName: Opens My Computer Brain in a new window

Page.Name: Ballyland apps for iPad
Page.MetaDescription: Sonokids has specifically designed a suite of educational ('Ballyland') apps that provide an accessible learning pathway for students who are blind or vision impaired.
Page.MainText: Sonokids has specifically designed a suite of educational ('Ballyland') apps that provide an accessible learning pathway for students who are blind or vision impaired. They can develop skills to use an iPad, spatial awareness on a touch screen, navigating by way of touch gestures on a touch screen, and coding/computational thinking.
Page.Copyright: Sonokids. May be subject to Copyright Statutory Licence Act.

Page.Name: Quick, Draw!
Page.MetaDescription: This is a game built with machine learning. You draw, and a neural network tries to guess what you're drawing. Of course, it doesn't always work. But the more you (and others) play with it, the more it will learn. It's just one example of how you can use machine learning in fun ways. See also other Google AI Experiments.

Page.Name: Computational Thinking for a Computational World
Page.MetaTitle: Computational Thinking for a Computational World
Page.MetaDescription: As computational technology advances, it is imperative that we educate young people and working adults to thrive in a computational world. In a computational world, what is important to know and know how to do?
Page.MainText: This paper argues that computational thinking is both central to computer science and widely applicable throughout education and the workforce. It is a skillset for solving complex problems, a way to learn topics in any discipline, and a necessity for fully participating in a computational world. The paper concludes with recommendations for integrating computational thinking across K-12 curriculum.
Page.Copyright: Digital Promise. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.
Page.LinkName: Opens Computational Thinking For A Computational World

They can be used for activities to support building knowledge and understanding of digital systems with a focus on the components of digital systems; in particular, hardware and peripheral devices.

The tutorial is designed for educators who would like to learn how to use Scratch.

Discover ways to protect yourself from becoming a victim of hackers or data criminals and useful resources.

Page.Name: Visiting Anne Frank’s House in VR
Page.MetaTitle: Visiting Anne Frank’s House in VR
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson, students learn about World War II, the tragic impact of the Holocaust on individuals and families. Students learn about Anne Frank and her life and the location where her and her family were in hiding. Students visit Anne's house in VR and explore the environment to discover more about who she was and where she lived.
Page.MainText: In this lesson, students learn about World War II, the tragic impact of the Holocaust on individuals and families. Students learn about Anne Frank and her life and the location where her and her family were in hiding. Students visit Anne's house in VR and explore the environment to discover more about who she was and where she lived.

Page.Name: A Virtual Reality Twist on Paintings
Page.MetaTitle: A Virtual Reality Twist on Paintings
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson, students take a classic well-known painting and put a virtual reality twist on it with their own interpretation. Students work in groups to view artwork and then design and plan their own which they create in the Tiltbrush application. Tiltbrush is a VR experience that enables users to create and design in a 3D immersive environment with a VR headset.
Page.MainText: In this lesson, students take a classic well-known painting and put a virtual reality twist on it with their own interpretation. Students work in groups to view artwork and then design and plan their own which they create in the Tiltbrush application. Tiltbrush is a VR experience that enables users to create and design in a 3D immersive environment with a VR headset.

Page.Name: Creating a virtual costume in Tiltbrush
Page.MetaTitle: Creating a virtual costume in Tiltbrush
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson, students create a costume in Virtual Reality (VR) using the Tiltbrush application and the Tiltbrush Dress Form template. Tiltbrush is a VR experience that enables users to create and design in a 3D immersive environment with a VR headset.
Page.MainText: In this lesson, students create a costume in Virtual Reality (VR) using the Tiltbrush application and the Tiltbrush Dress Form template. Tiltbrush is a VR experience that enables users to create and design in a 3D immersive environment with a VR headset.

Page.Name: Discovering the Body with Google Tours
Page.MetaTitle: Discovering the Body with Google Tours
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson, students explore the Respiratory System using Google Tours. The teacher can guide the students through a tour together or the teacher can allow students to freely navigate and explore the system on their own or in small groups.
Page.MainText: In this lesson, students explore the Respiratory System using Google Tours. The teacher can guide the students through a tour together or the teacher can allow students to freely navigate and explore the system on their own or in small groups. After experiencing the Virtual Tour, students then go on to remix the project by extending it to include additional content about the Human "mammal" Respiratory System and by also comparing it to another class of animal. For example, students could choose to compare the human respiratory system with that of fish, amphibians, birds or vertebrates.
Page.Copyright: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License. Computer Science Education Research (CSER) Group, The University of Adelaide.
Page.LinkName: Opens Discovering the Body with Google Tours in a new window

Page.Name: Experience ‘Okavango Delta’ in Southern Africa with VR
Page.MetaTitle: Experience ‘Okavango Delta’ in Southern Africa with VR
Page.MetaDescription: In this lesson, students will virtually explore one of the wonders of nature called ‘Okavango Delta’ using immersive VR technology.
Page.MainText: In this lesson, students will virtually explore one of the wonders of nature called ‘Okavango Delta’ using immersive VR technology. The Okavango Delta which is located in Botswana is known as the largest wetland in Southern Africa and one of the most biodiverse places on Earth. The VR scientific expedition is built by National Geographic and Youtube. Students start the lesson by researching geography topics related to river deltas suggested by the teacher. The whole class will then experience the four episodes with the ‘National Geographic’ VR app using the Lenovo Mirage Solo Daydream headset. This lesson can be undertaken by students in groups.
Page.Copyright: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License. Computer Science Education Research (CSER) Group, The University of Adelaide.
Page.LinkName: Opens Experience ‘Okavango Delta’ in Southern Africa with VR in a new window

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 5/6 Blockly - Satellite
Page.MetaDescription: Use Blockly to draw your own awesome satellite!
Page.MainText: Learn how to use the Turtle in Blockly to draw and create with code. You'll draw a satellite piece by piece, building up your coding skills and learning advanced programming concepts like loops and functions.
Page.LinkName: Opens Dt Challenge 56 Blockly Satellite Offline Challenge

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 5/6 Blockly - Intro to Micro:Bit
Page.MetaTitle: DT Challenge - 5/6 Blockly - Intro to Micro:Bit
Page.MetaDescription: Learn about the BBC micro:bit while creating your own virtual pet!
Page.MainText: Learn how to program a BBC micro:bit using Blockly. No experience required. Learn the basics of programming in Blockly with our full BBC micro:bit simulator.
Page.LinkName: Opens Dt Challenge 56 Blockly Microbit Intro Offline Challenge

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 5/6 Blockly - Space Invaders - Mini
Page.MetaTitle: DT Challenge - 5/6 Blockly - Space Invaders - Mini
Page.MetaDescription: Use Blockly to learn how to create a Space Invaders game!
Page.MainText: Command an alien space fleet to save your home planet from global catastrophe. Build a fleet of drone ships using advanced top-secret technologies. On your journey to Earth, slingshot around a black hole and mine for valuable resources. Your mission is to outsmart Earth’s Global Defense System in your quest for precious water. We are counting on you, Commander! Long live the Zargan Empire.
Page.LinkName: Opens Dt Challenge 56 Blockly Space Invaders Mini Offline Challenge

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 3/4 Blockly - Micro:Bit Blast Off
Page.MetaTitle: DT Challenge - 3/4 Blockly - Micro:Bit Blast Off
Page.MetaDescription: Make a cool rocket ship with the BBC micro:bit using the Blockly visual programming environment.
Page.MainText: Prepare for launch with the micro:bit! Set your sights on the stars by making a rocket ship, complete with countdown. You don't need a real micro:bit to participate. Use our full micro:bit simulator to learn, explore what the micro:bit can do! Blast-off in 3, 2, 1! If you have a micro:bit you can use our resources to build a cardboard rocket.
Page.LinkName: Opens Dt Challenge 34 Blockly Microbit Blastoff Offline Challenge

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 7/8 Python - Smart garden
Page.MetaDescription: Learn about the BBC micro:bit while creating your own super-sensing Smart Garden!
Page.MainText: Learn how to program a BBC micro:bit using Python — no experience required. Learn the basics of programming in Python with our full BBC micro:bit simulator. Create a Smart Garden device to monitor the health of your plants, measuring temperature and wiring up a simple soil moisture sensor.
Page.LinkName: Opens Dt Challenge 78 Python Smart Garden Lesson Plan

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 7/8 Python - Sport Micro:Bit
Page.MetaDescription: Get fit by combining Health and Physical Education and Digital Technologies!
Page.MainText: Use Python to program a micro:bit for sport! Get excited about coding even if you have no experience. You'll use the Python language to write your own programs, and make interactive games and tools to improve your health.
Page.LinkName: Opens Dt Challenge 78 Python Sport Microbit Lesson Plan

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 3/4 Blockly - Wombot
Page.MetaDescription: Write code to help Wombot move, turn and find delicious carrots to eat!
Page.MainText: Wombot is hungry and wants a carrot! With simple code, help Wombot through mazes, and learn to draw lines and shapes with code. In this challenge you'll learn the fundamentals of programming by using instructions to position Wombot on the screen. You'll help Wombot move and turn, and along the way learn to draw lines, patterns and shapes in the same way computers draw images on the screen.
Page.LinkName: Opens Dt Challenge 34 56 Blockly Wombot Lesson Plan

Page.Name: Exploring pedagogies for teaching programming in school
Page.MetaTitle: Exploring pedagogies for teaching programming in school
Page.MetaDescription: This approach expands on the approach Use-Modify-Create.
Page.MainText: This approach expands on the approach Use-Modify-Create. This is when a learner runs (uses) an existing program to see what it does, then modifies it, and then when able, creates a new project of their own. Exploring pedagogies for teaching programming in school
Page.LinkName: Opens Exploring pedagogies for teaching programming in school in a new window

Page.Name: PRIMM: A structured approach to teaching programming
Page.MetaTitle: PRIMM: A structured approach to teaching programming
Page.MetaDescription: PRIMM is one approach that can help teachers structure lessons in programming.
Page.MainText: PRIMM stands for Predict, Run, Investigate, Modify, Make
Page.LinkName: Opens PRIMM: A structured approach to teaching programming in a new window

Page.Name: A continuum of scaffolding: from copying code to tinkering
Page.MetaTitle: A continuum of scaffolding: from copying code to tinkering
Page.MetaDescription: This is simple model, presented as a linear continuum of different instructional approaches.
Page.MainText: This is simple model, presented as a linear continuum of different instructional approaches. These include: Copy code, Targeted tasks, Shared programming, Guided exploration, Projects (use/imitate/remix/new/share) and Tinkering
Page.LinkName: Opens A continuum of scaffolding in a new window

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 5/6 Blockly - Chatbot
Page.MetaDescription: Write code to create word games and develop a Pirate Chatbot. Arrr, me hearties!
Page.MainText:
Write programs to solve problems with code and create word games! In this DT Challenge, you'll learn how to play Mad Libs, Questions, Taboo, and Word Chain, and even write your very own Pirate Chatbot! Can you fool your friends into thinking they're talking to a real person?

Learn how to create a series of word games with code. You'll start out with simple word games and work up to creating your very own Pirate Chatbot! Arrr, me hearties! So get cracking and we'll have you hacking like a pirate in no time!

To do the challenge offlineuse this guide to support students.
Page.LinkName: Opens Dt Challenge 5 6 Blockly Chatbot Lesson Plan in a new window

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 7/8 Arduino - Sound
Page.MetaDescription: Learn to write code to create your own musical instrument!
Page.MainText:
Let's make our own devices with the Arduino! We'll take a deep dive into building devices from the ground up, and you'll see how all pieces of technology are built! Learn how to create a temperature monitor, or a musical instrument, or make an automatic torch! Jump right in and let's make some noise!

To do the challenge offline use this guide to support students.
Page.LinkName: Dt Challenge 7 8 Arduino Sound Lesson Plan

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 7/8 Python - Chatbot
Page.MetaDescription: Write code to create word games and develop a Pirate Chatbot. Arrr, me hearties!
Page.MainText:
Write programs to solve problems with code and create word games! In this DT Challenge, you'll learn how to play Mad Libs, Questions, Taboo, and Word Chain, and even write your very own Pirate Chatbot! Can you fool your friends into thinking they're talking to a real person?

Learn how to create a series of word games with code. You'll start out with simple word games and work up to creating your very own Pirate Chatbot! Arrr, me hearties! So get cracking and we'll have you hacking like a pirate in no time!

To do the challenge offline use this guide to support students.
Page.LinkName: Dt Challenge 7 8 Python Chatbot Lesson Plan

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 7/8 Blockly - Geometry
Page.MetaDescription: Explore geometry through programming, and draw intricate patterns and explosive fireworks!
Page.MainText:
Explore geometry through programming, and draw intricate patterns and explosive fireworks! In this challenge, you’ll learn about how computers use angles, parallel lines and geometric transformations to generate the text and images you see on your screen every day. Use what you learn to develop your own fonts, pattern generators and even create a scene of colourful fireworks.

Colours, lines, drawings - all of these are produced through numbers, and with a bit of guidance and support, you’ll learn the coding techniques game, animation and application developers use to bring your computer experience to life. Unlock the power of Maths + Code!

To do the challenge offline use this guide to support students.
Page.LinkName: Dt Challenge 78 Blockly Geometry Lesson Plan

Page.Name: Artificial Intelligence Explainers: Video 1: Introduction to AI & machine learning
Page.MetaTitle: Artificial Intelligence Explainers: Video 1: Introduction to AI & machine learning
Page.MetaDescription: Use this video to introduce Artificial Intelligence (AI).
Page.MainText: In this video we find out why it is a challenge for a computer to easily recognise one object from another. Discover how a machine learns using labelled images rather than following a specific set of rules. See how AI connects with human learning.
Page.Copyright: Creative Commons Attribution 4.0, unless otherwise indicated. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.

Page.Name: Artificial Intelligence Explainers: Video 2: AI in our everyday life
Page.MetaDescription: Use this video to discuss how Artificial Intelligence (AI) impacts our everyday life.
Page.MainText:
In this video we look at the ways AI is making decisions that can affect your daily life. Discover some AI applications that are designed to make our lives easier. See how a machine can be considered smart as it performs human-like behaviours such as recognising speech, text, images and being able to reason.

This is the second video in a series. The first in the series is Introduction to AI & machine learning.
Page.Copyright: Creative Commons Attribution 4.0, unless otherwise indicated. May be subject to Copyright Act statutory licence.

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 7/8 Javascript - Cookie Clicker
Page.MetaDescription: Learn JavaScript and Web programming to create a Cookie Clicker game!
Page.MainText:
Learn how to make interactive webpages and build a surprisingly addictive game! In this DT Challenge, you'll learn the web technologies that form the foundations of the internet.

In this course you'll learn the basics of HTML, CSS and JavaScript! You'll build webpages using text and images, and learn how to make them interactive as you add more complex UI elements.

So get your clicking fingers ready, and watch out how that cookie crumbles!

To do the challenge offline use this guide to support students.

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 5/6 Blockly - Space Invaders
Page.MetaDescription: Use Blockly to learn how to create a Space Invaders game!
Page.MainText:
Enlist now to command an alien space fleet to save your home planet from global catastrophe. Build a fleet of drone ships using advanced top-secret technologies, like algorithms, sequence, iteration and branching. On your journey to Earth, meet the Doctor, slingshot around a black hole, land on distant moons and mine for valuable resources. Your mission is to outsmart Earth’s Global Defense System in your quest for precious water.

We are counting on you, Commander! Long live the Zargan Empire.

Watch the mission briefing here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U6tq8UuUpXw

To do the challenge offline use this guide to support students.

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 7/8 Javascript - Space Invaders
Page.MetaDescription: Learn JavaScript and Web programming to create a Space Invaders game!
Page.MainText:
Enlist now to command an alien space fleet to save your home planet from global catastrophe. Build a fleet of drone ships using advanced top-secret technologies, like algorithms, sequence, iteration and branching. On your journey to Earth, meet the Doctor, slingshot around a black hole, land on distant moons and mine for valuable resources. Your mission is to outsmart Earth’s Global Defense System in your quest for precious water.

We are counting on you, Commander! Long live the Zargan Empire.

Watch the mission briefing here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U6tq8UuUpXw

To do the challenge offlineuse this guide to support students.

Page.Name: DT Challenge - 7-8 Python - Turtle
Page.MetaDescription: Write code to control a turtle and draw fantastic pictures!
Page.MainText:
Control a turtle and draw amazing pictures with code. In this challenge you'll learn the fundamentals of programming by using instructions to position a turtle on the screen, drawing lines, patterns and shapes in the same way computers draw images.

Computers use the input from users and the environment to give us feedback about the world around us. They display that feedback in lots of different ways. Everything - from games to web browsers and apps like Netflix - generates images on the screen, and it all starts with code!

To do the challenge offline use this guide to support students.

Page.MetaDescription: As a general purpose programming language, python has a number of libraries that can be used for different purposes. PyGame is a free and open source python library that makes it easier to make multimedia applications like games.
